Indian Civilisations [FC-0201] [FC-0201-3]

Faculty Name
Nayanjot Kaur Lahiri [nayanjot.lahiri@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

This is a small course about a large and fascinating subject, that of Indian Civilizations. It has been structured in a way that it can be immersed in, one hopes, with enjoyment. The course will draw out civilizational elements from prehistory till the present – through accounts of travels and lives, through ideas and  through art – in which small phenomena are linked to the larger frame of the Indian subcontinent and beyond. The course will explore a varied and rich tapestry that includes rock art, the Harappan Civilization, iconic emperors like Ashoka and Akbar,  the words of the Buddha and the Bhakti saints, modern statesmen like B.R. Ambedkar and Jawaharlal Nehru. How social and gender inequalities cut across Indian history will also  be explored.  Indian civilizations, as the course will emphasize, are not   part of the 'old' and  ‘dead’ past but  are made up of elements that continue to be present in contemporary India. Readings will be electronically shared with students.

Learning Outcomes

A nuanced understanding of India's past and present through the civilizational lens

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Readings will have to be engaged with on a weekly basis

Mind and Behaviour [FC-0503] [FC-0503-1]

Faculty Name
Aarthy Vaidyanathan [aarthy.vaidyanathan@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

Emotions, Responsibility, and Morality

We sometimes judge actions as morally right or wrong. But what makes an action morally right or wrong?  Blame seems detrimental in some clinical contexts. In such contexts, how can clinical service providers hold users responsible for wrongdoing without blaming them? Anger is often an understandable emotional response to injustice. What is the value of such anger? This course will engage with such philosophical questions about moral judgments, responsibility, and the emotions. 

Learning Outcomes

Students of this course will learn to explain the core ideas we engage with clearly and succinctly. They will also learn to critically engage with philosophical arguments and to articulate and support their views.   

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Sample readings:
Rachels, ‘The Challenge of Cultural Relativism.’
Selections from Mill, Utilitarianism
Singer, ‘Famine, Affluence, and Morality’
Pickard, ‘Responsibility without Blame’
Srinivasan, ‘The Aptness of Anger’

Excused absence(s) are not applicable in this course lecture.
Additional excused absence(s) are not applicable for sportspersons in this course lecture.
Additional Comments:

Attendance is required. You are permitted three no-questions-asked absences. 3 further absences may be excused but must be requested ahead of class via email. 

Doors will remain closed during class time, but there will be a short five-minute break approximately half-way through class. Attendance will be recorded during both halves. 

The failure to meet the attendance requirement is subject to a penalty of up to 5 points on the final course score.

Mind and Behaviour [FC-0503] [FC-0503-5]

Faculty Name
Nandini Chatterjee Singh [ns@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

Vision/Philosophy/Purpose

This foundation course seeks to address overarching questions about the human brain, mind, and behavior which form the core of human experience. The brain is the biological foundation for mental processes, the mind creates the internal experience of these processes, and together they are manifested in behaviour in the form observable actions and responses. Using theoretical frameworks, cool psychological experiments, and state of the art brain imaging methods, this course will unravel how human beings acquire language, learn to read, develop number sense, experience emotion, feel music, pay attention and exhibit kindness, from a psychological and neurobiological perspective. The course will raise significant questions about cognitive processes, brain organisation and processing, psychological constructs and human diversity. Students will be encouraged to find answers using approaches that blend both the sciences and the arts.  

 

The course will be structured into three parts as described below

In the first part students will be introduced to terminology and vocabulary in psychology and neuroscience. They will also be introduced to the organisation of the brain and different cognitive processes.

The second part of the course will discuss different cognitive abilities like reading, number processing, emotion processing, attention etc.. from a psychological and neurobiological perspective.

The third part of the course will discuss neurodiversity - how some of these cognitive processes vary across the human condition and thus render each human unique.

Learning Outcomes

To introduce the broad areas and varied approaches that comprise the field of psychology and neuroscience.

Learn about different cognitive processes.

Develop an understanding of how different cognitive processes work in concert to develop skills/abilities.

Identify the value brought in by the sciences and the arts in understanding human behaviour. Understand the design and contributions of experiments in neuroscience and psychology in our understanding of the brain.

Use knowledge of neuroscience and psychology to understand nature and nurture.

Name and identify regions of the brain and their role in processing information and skills like memory, motor skills, etc.

 

By the end of this course, students will learn to: 

To recognise and identify diversity of human thought and perspective.

To develop flexibility in ideas, approaches and response.

To appreciate the power of empirical and replicable research

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Prescribed Texts: No prescribed texts. Reading handouts and articles will be provided.

Supporting texts - 

Cognitive Neuroscience - The biology of the mind (Michael Gazzaniga)

Behave - The Biology of Humans at our best and our worst - Robert Sapolsky

Additional excused absence(s) are not applicable for sportspersons in this course lecture.

Grading
Grading Components
Grading Rubric

Evaluation Components

Syllabus Quiz (best of 4 out of 5 quizzes): 20%

Class participation and attendance: 10%

Collaborative project: 20%

Midterm Exam(s):  15%

Final Exam: 25%

Academic Integrity: 10% 

Quiz (20%)

Four quizzes (two before the mid term and two after) will be administered during class hours. One will be a surprise quiz. The quizzes will be based on content discussed in the classroom in the multiple choice format.

Attendance and class participation (10%)

Attendance of at least 80% will contribute 5%. Class participation will be assessed through engagement and participation in discussions and class interactions. 

Midterm Exam(s) (15%)

We will have one mid-term exam that will count towards 15% of the total grade and will assess all topics covered till Week 3. It will consist of a combination of multiple-choice questions and short-answer questions.

Final Exam (25%)

The final exam will consist of a combination of multiple-choice questions and short-answer questions. You will be assessed on portions covered after the midterm break. 

Collaborative Project (20%)

Develop a clear research question. Review the literature. Indicate gaps in current knowledge. State how you will fill the gap. Combine scientific knowledge with artistic expression to address the gap. 

The details of project rubric will be provided later. Group sizes will consist of 5 students. We will send around a sign-up sheet  to form groups.  Each group submits ONE group report. It will not exceed 1000 words (not including references, figures, and tables) and will be formatted in APA style. Points will be deducted from the total score of this project for overshooting the word limit and not following APA format. A “Basic guide to APA style formatting” will be made available.

Academic Integrity (10%). Cheating on exams, plagiarism, taking help of AI, proxy attendance, or any other form of dishonesty is unacceptable. Acknowledging and citing all external sources is a must and points will be deducted if this is not adhered to. In that case, any quotations used should be enclosed within quotation marks and the author should be given due credit. A lack of understanding is not an acceptable excuse for any violation of these guidelines.

Disclaimer: The syllabus is tentative and any deviation is contingent on students’ feedback/ interest and/or instructor’s discretion for the benefit of understanding the subject.

Mind and Behaviour [FC-0503] [FC-0503-6]

Overview

Professor Merve Rumeysa Tapınç

This course explores how we should understand the human mind, human nature, our responsibility for one another within social and political contexts. We will discuss whether a pleasurable life or a radically moral life can be considered good, and whether a meaningful life is necessarily a happy one. In the first unit, we will examine the question of how we should live and what it means to lead a good life. We will also consider our relationship to death and how the meaning of life might change if we were immortal. In the second unit, we will focus on our responsibility for one another and explore whether a truly altruistic or moral life constitutes a good life. In the third unit, we will turn to recent discussions on social injustice and artificial intelligence. Understanding how machines think will shed light on our own understanding of the human mind.

Learning Outcomes
  • to support an argument with good reasons, rather than assert an opinion,
  • to formulate an argument for a thesis and defend it against objections,
  • to defend one's interpretation of a philosophical text,
  • to define and use key philosophical concepts correctly.
  • to learn about various philosophical theories about how one should live one’s life.

All required readings will be available through Canvas.

Week 6

UNIT III What is the Meaning of Life?

          Wolf Continued, “Why it Matters” 34-63

Introduction to Literary Theory [ENG-1002] [ENG-1002-1]

Faculty Name
Mandakini Dubey [mandakini.dubey@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

The field of English is shaped by literary theory, with its profound engagements with big questions of language, reality, identity, power, desire, history – most broadly, the self and the world. When studying literature, we often seek out ways of uncovering the workings  of these engagements in the texts we read. This course turns to the questions and answers posed by theory itself, rather than applications through the reading of literary texts. 

Theory can seem complex and intimidating, but its questions are fundamental: how do we make meaning? How do we constitute texts, and how do texts constitute us? How are we to know those parts of ourselves that refuse knowledge? How do our bodies, our given identities, and the material conditions of our lives shape who we are and how we feel, think, act, desire, and read? Keeping these and other basic questions in mind, this course will survey the key approaches and texts of contemporary literary theory.

Learning Outcomes

1. To read broadly and deeply through a range of significant arguments from across different schools of theory; 

2. To learn how to grasp complex theoretical concepts, to become acquainted with theoretical writing and reasoning;

3. To write about theory clearly and to trace it in literature and culture.

Introduction to Literary Theory [ENG-1002] [ENG-1002-2]

Faculty Name
Huzaifa Omair Siddiqi [huzaifa.siddiqi@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

Introduction to Literary Theory

Literary theory encompasses texts by phenomenologists, existentialists, linguists, psychoanalysts, Marxists, structuralists, deconstructionists, feminists, queer theorists, Critical Race and anti-caste theorists. What this course seeks to explore is why the study of literature needs ‘theory’ in all its various guises. What kind of relation does literature have with theory that is manifestly different, and indeed incompatible with, the traditional understanding of object and knowledge in philosophy and the sciences? The advent of ‘theory’ (as contrasted with ‘philosophy’ and ‘science’) has to be seen, not just as the beginning of a radical critique of the purportedly self-evident notions of subject, class, caste, race, gender and identity but also as a revolution in the very concepts of knowledge, truth and reality themselves. What happens to these concepts when literature (which has for so long been the catch-all term for illusion, falsity, imitation and error) becomes the site of truth; when theory replaces philosophy?

This course seeks to enter into these questions raised by literary theory. We will read texts by major theorists to see how theory displaces traditional philosophy and necessitates a practice that may be artistic, political, ethical or a combination of all three.

Learning Outcomes

Course Objectives:

To understand the importance of literary theory for literary studies.

To be able to write and think about theoretical texts.

To introduce students to the basics and make them understand the strengths and weaknesses of various theoretical approaches

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Course Requirements:

Presentations: 2 oral presentations in groups of 2 during the semester, one before the midterm break and one after. (30% of the final grade)
Grading rubric for presentation:
i) Clear Explanations: You'll be graded on how well you break down the themes and ideas, especially when it comes to making tough sections of the text easier to follow.
ii) Understanding the Material: Your grade will reflect how well you understand the text, particularly the parts that aren’t immediately clear.
iii) Asking Thoughtful Questions: You’ll get points for asking good questions about the text. Whether your questions show sharp thinking, help guide how we read the text, or come from genuine curiosity, they’ll be valued.
iv) Getting the Conversation Going: You’ll earn marks for getting your classmates talking about the text, especially if you steer the discussion towards critical or deep topics.

In-class participation: 20% of the final grade

Summaries: Post summaries of each day’s reading of around 400-500 words. If there is more than one reading allotted for the day, post the summary of any one. (10% of the final grade)

End term paper: 10 to 12 page essay (maximum 3000 words) on a topic of your choice. Topic to be decided after consultation with me. (40% of the final grade)
Grading rubric for the paper:
i) Engagement with primary and secondary sources
ii) Salience of the research question
iii) Citation and formatting
iv) Potential for further research

Introduction to Literary Theory [ENG-1002] [ENG-1002-3]

Faculty Name
Mandakini Dubey [mandakini.dubey@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

The field of English is shaped by literary theory, with its profound engagements with big questions of language, reality, identity, power, desire, history – most broadly, the self and the world. When studying literature, we often seek out ways of uncovering the workings  of these engagements in the texts we read. This course turns to the questions and answers posed by theory itself, rather than applications through the reading of literary texts. 

Theory can seem complex and intimidating, but its questions are fundamental: how do we make meaning? How do we constitute texts, and how do texts constitute us? How are we to know those parts of ourselves that refuse knowledge? How do our bodies, our given identities, and the material conditions of our lives shape who we are and how we feel, think, act, desire, and read? Keeping these and other basic questions in mind, this course will survey the key approaches and texts of contemporary literary theory.

 

Learning Outcomes

1. To read broadly and deeply through a range of significant arguments from across different schools of theory; 

2. To learn how to grasp complex theoretical concepts, to become acquainted with theoretical writing and reasoning;

3. To write about theory clearly and to trace it in literature and culture. 

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Introduction to Literary Theory [ENG-1002] [ENG-1002-4]

Overview

This course is structured around Laurent Binet’s novel The Seventh Function of Language, a contemporary work of historical fiction that introduces readers to the “who’s who” of literary theory through a gripping murder mystery. Along the way we will get acquainted with foundational figures of postwar literary theory (primarily from Europe): Roland Barthes, Jacques Derrida, Michel Foucault, Julia Kristeva, and others. As we read this whodunit, we will think about literary theory itself as a form of investigation, understanding Marxism, feminism, psychoanalysis and postcolonial theory—as they develop in the 20th century—as modes of investigative reading. Finally, we will explore critiques of literary theory as positing a “hermeneutics of suspicion,” and recent debates around surface reading and close reading, to think about different orientations one might have towards a literary text. 

 

Learning Outcomes

description:
Algebra 1 [MAT-2001] [MAT-2001-1]

Faculty Name
Conjeeveram Srirangachari Rajan [cs.rajan@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

Algebra is to mathematics what mathematics is to the rest of the physical sciences. Algebra is the 

abstraction and study of frequently used types of mathematical reasoning.   One of the basic concepts 

underlying many aspects of our lives is symmetry, whose underlying mathematical concepts are groups 

and group actions. The course will mainly focus on groups and its role in the study of diverse mathematical 

objects. It will be based on examples arsising from linear algebra and its associated geometry. 

Learning Outcomes

Group and group actions, linear algebra and group theory, examples of 

groups. Some basic ring theory. 

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

The course is newly designed and it will not follow any book in a linear manner. 

The closest in approach is `Algebra' by Michael Artin. 

Other good books are those by Dummit and Foote, Fraleigh, etc.

Cognitive Psychology [PSY-2021] [PSY-2021-1]

Faculty Name
Dipanjan Ray Ray [dipanjan.ray@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

This course is currently undergoing design and modification. Please check this location frequently for updates and changes.

Cognitive psychology is the study of how we think, and how we make sense of the external (and internal) environment using our prior experiences, and determine how to respond to an ever changing environment. While the main purpose of this course is to introduce you to the scientific study of the mind, you will also begin to understand the central role cognition plays in our everyday lives. 

Learning Outcomes

Upon completing this course, students should be able to:
• Trace the history of cognitive psychology and its influence on other fields of psychology.
• Critically compare and contrast different theories of cognitive function.
• Demonstrate knowledge of the basic methods of cognitive research, plus their strengths and weaknesses.
• Apply communication skills using oral and written materials to discuss topics related to human cognition or to critically review a paper.
• Explain how theories and research findings from cognitive psychology can inform everyday problems

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Goldstein, E. B. (2014). Cognitive psychology: Connecting mind, research and everyday experience. Cengage Learning.
Recommended Text

Other

Social Psychology [PSY-2051] [PSY-2051-1]

Faculty Name
Shitika Chowdhary [shitika.chowdhary@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

Course description: Social psychology is the branch of psychological science that examines how an individual's thoughts, emotions and behavior are shaped by social norms and the larger social context. We will explore how the presence of others shapes and influences our motivations, cognition, attitudes, emotions and behavior, by looking at group processes involved in cooperation, conflict and competition.

 

 

Learning Outcomes

To introduce major theories, concepts, empirical findings and debates in social psychology. 

To familiarize students with methods within social psychological research.

To critically engage with social psychological findings and explore how they apply to our cultural contexts. 

To understand the intersections between ‘social’ and ‘individual’ and the multi-layered problems that social psychologists examine. 

To facilitate the development of interest in exploring social psychological questions of enquiry among students. 

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Prerequisites- SRM 1 & Introduction to Psychology/ Thinking Like A Psychologist

Developing Performance Skills [PA-1003] [PA-1003-1]

Overview

Taught by Kriti Pant & Veena Kumar

Movement, text, sound, music- these are some of the areas touched upon while developing skills in performance. The emphasis is on building a vocabulary of performance techniques. These techniques can include breathing, movement improvisation, and voice modulation, as well as exercises in awareness and musicality. These ‘tools of performance’ are often tempered by a plethora of contemporary performance outlooks. The emphasis in this most preliminary of Ashoka’s performing arts courses is on the individual as a performing entity. The consciousness of one’s own self vis-à-vis performative potential lays the foundations for the group work so essential to later performing arts courses.  The course work will proceed in a series of ‘etudes’ or studies which will result in small performance ‘moments’ or phrases. Some of the coursework will be based on texts and scripts to be chosen afresh each semester.  Other coursework can be based on non-textual concepts.

No previous experience is required. This course is a presumed prerequisite for higher-level performing arts courses.

This course is mandatory for all students wanting to pursue a minor in performing arts.

Developmental Psychology [PSY-2031] [PSY-2031-1]

Faculty Name
Annie Baxi [annie.baxi@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

Developmental Psychology is a systematic approach to study the biopsychosocial dimensions of human development across the lifespan. The course will cover fundamental theories relative to cognitive development, moral development, language development, identity formation etc from the period of the prenatal period to death. During the course, students will engage in key theoretical concepts in human development and their cultural application, critique the idea of normative development and develop a grounded sensibility towards development oriented concerns and challenges. The course will follow a critically reflexive pedagogy, urging students to consistently question developmental givens, introspect on their development and hence develop a nuanced understanding of technical concepts. Pedagogical tools will include a combination of play, reflexive exercises, art work and film clippings. The course intends to  ask the following questions: How do nature and nurture together shape development? How do children shape their own development? In what ways is development continuous, and in what ways is it discontinuous? How does the socio-cultural context influence development? What are the ethical research practices when studying developmental patterns?

Learning Outcomes
  • Develop a thorough understanding of major development theories.
  • Develop a critical approach to linear models of human development.
  • Relate key concepts of the scientific method to research in child development.
  • Identify and illustrate how biological, cognitive and social-emotional processes interact to influence human development.
Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Course Requirement

Introduction to Psychology/ Thinking like a Psychologist, SRM-I

Feldman, R.S., & Babu, N. (2022). Discovering the LifeSpan. Pearson.

Santrock, J.W. (2020). A topical approach to life-span development (10th edition). McGraw-Hill Education.

Crain, W. (2024). Theories of Development (7th edition). Taylor & Francis.

Burman, E. (2024). Child as Method; Othering, Interiority, and Materialism. Routledge

Reddy, V. (2008). How Infants Know Minds. Harvard University Press.

Kerig, P.K., Schulz M.S., & Hauser S.T. (2012). Adolescence and Beyond; Family Processes and Development. Oxford University Press.

description:
Statistics and Research Methods II [PSY-2002] [PSY-2002-1]

Faculty Name
Krishna Venkata Melnattur [krishna.melnattur@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

Quantitative psychological data is frequently a bunch of structured numbers. These cannot be interpreted meaningfully until one understands and appreciates how the data came about and what can be properly inferred from the data. In this course, we will focus on quantitative methodology. This course is for students who know the basics of statistical analyses. The aim is to develop a trained eye for sound methodology to better evaluate other scientists’ research, as well as their own. Students will also learn about planning, ethical conduct, and reporting of findings from a survey and experimental study. Along with some of the most widely-used quantitative methods in psychology (e.g., surveys and experiments), students will also understand how these methods are different from alternative methodologies (i.e., qualitative methods, mixed methods).



 

Learning Outcomes

By the end of this course, you will be able to:

  • Understand various quantitative methods that psychologists use to investigate research questions.
  • Plan, design, and conduct a psychometrically-sound survey; formulate hypotheses, test them, analyze the results, interpret them
  • Write report of a survey study to effectively communicate your results
  • Plan, design, and conduct an experimental study; formulate hypotheses, design and conduct an experiment to test the hypotheses, analyze the results, interpret them
  • Write report of an experimental study to effectively communicate your results
  • Understand alternative methodologies available for researchers (qualitative and mixed-method) and when to use them
  • Grasp, analyze, and critique academics research papers in psychology
  • Become literate consumers of scientific information.
Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Prerequisites: Pass in Statistics and Research Methodology I, or equivalent modules in math, or economics.

Required materials:

Shaughnessy J. J., Zechmeister, E. B., Zechmeister, J. S., & (2012). Essentials of research methods in psychology. (9th ed.) Tata McGraw-Hill.

 

Attendance

Attendance will be taken within the first five minutes of every class. I expect students to attend all lecture and discussion sessions. All lecture and discussion sessions will count towards attendance. The following rules will apply for absences:

Missing 5 classes: Excused (no grade cut)

Missing 6 classes: One grade cut on the final grade for the course

Missing 8 classes: Two grade cuts on the final grade for the course

Missing 10 or more classes: A ‘Fail’ grade for the course

The five excused absences can be used in case you miss a class due to illness. You do not need to show me a doctor’s note in order to take these five excused absences. However, if illness prevents you from attending class for a longer period of time and you would like more absences excused, you will be asked for documentation from a doctor or nurse practitioner for each of the past absences to determine if that is possible. Additional excused absences are possible only if the past five absences have been due to health reasons and have proper documentation. In previous iterations of the course, we have seen students taking discussion sessions lightly. The discussion sessions are very important, and help consolidate learning from lectures. Please treat discussion sessions on par with lectures.

Excused absence(s) are not applicable in this course lecture.
Additional excused absence(s) are not applicable for sportspersons in this course lecture.

description:
Statistics and Research Methods II [PSY-2002] [PSY-2002-3]

Faculty Name
Naseer Ahmad Bhat [naseer.bhat@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

Quantitative psychological data is frequently a bunch of structured numbers. These cannot be interpreted meaningfully until one understands and appreciates how the data came about and what can be properly inferred from the data. In this course, we will focus on quantitative methodology. This course is for students who know the basics of statistical analyses. The aim is to develop a trained eye for sound methodology to better evaluate other scientists’ research, as well as their own. Students will also learn about planning, ethical conduct, and reporting of findings from a survey and experimental study. Along with some of the most widely-used quantitative methods in psychology (e.g., surveys and experiments), students will also understand how these methods are different from alternative methodologies (i.e., qualitative methods, mixed methods).



 

Learning Outcomes

By the end of this course, you will be able to:

  • Understand various quantitative methods that psychologists use to investigate research questions.
  • Plan, design, and conduct a psychometrically-sound survey; formulate hypotheses, test them, analyze the results, interpret them
  • Write report of a survey study to effectively communicate your results
  • Plan, design, and conduct an experimental study; formulate hypotheses, design and conduct an experiment to test the hypotheses, analyze the results, interpret them
  • Write report of an experimental study to effectively communicate your results
  • Understand alternative methodologies available for researchers (qualitative and mixed-method) and when to use them
  • Grasp, analyze, and critique academics research papers in psychology
  • Become literate consumers of scientific information.
Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Prerequisites: Pass in Statistics and Research Methodology I, or equivalent modules in math, or economics.

Required materials:

Shaughnessy J. J., Zechmeister, E. B., Zechmeister, J. S., & (2012). Essentials of research methods in psychology. (9th ed.) Tata McGraw-Hill.

description:
Clinical Psychology [PSY-2041] [PSY-2041-1]

Faculty Name
Simi Ghosh [simi@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

This course focuses on understanding the phenomenology (description), etiology (causes), and treatment of abnormal behavior. Major psychological syndromes will be discussed along with the current APA classification system (DSM-5) and other classification systems. Genetic, biological, social, and psychological parameters implicated in the etiology of these syndromes will be introduced. Students will learn the principles of clinical assessment and the 5P model of psychological assessment and case formulation

 

Link to Spring 2025 Sylllabus

Learning Outcomes
  1. Understand the merits and limitations of research methods and assessment techniques for clinical psychology
  2. Learn the basics of critical and analytical skills required to read a journal article on clinical psychology
  3. Understand and be able to describe the current APA classification system (DSM-5) and show appreciation for other classification systems internationally
  4. Understand and be able to describe the major psychological disorders
  5. Describe the genetic, biological, social, and psychological influences on these disorders
  6. Understand the influence of societal, cultural, historical, and environmental influences on these disorders
  7. Appreciate the concept of comorbidity
  8. Discuss mental health services historically, and in today’s USA, and appreciate international differences
  9. Understand ethical issues involved with mental health services
  10. Learn the importance of vocabulary, empathy and nuances in abnormal behavior
  11. Be able to navigate and think through elementary clinical problems in practice
  12. Learn to write an interview questionnaire based on a clinical case study
Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

  • Course Readings

    Text: Butcher J.N, Mineka S, Hooley J.M, Kapoor P (2019) Abnormal Psychology (18th ed) Pearson India https://www.amazon.in/dp/9353065593?tag=pearindieduc-21 ( Rs.781 from amazon India for paperback, Rs. 389 for Kindle edition)

    Reference: Nevid, J.S., Rathus, S.A., & Greene, B (2021). Abnormal Psychology in a Changing World (11th ed.) New Jersey: Pearson Higher Education.

Development Economics [ECO-3500] [ECO-3500-3]

Faculty Name
Anisha Sharma [anisha.sharma@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

Why do some nations remain poor while others achieve lasting prosperity? Can targeted public policy overcome structural barriers to development? This course tackles these questions at the heart of development economics. We investigate how markets, institutions, education, and health interact to shape economic growth, poverty, and inequality. Drawing on contemporary research and real-world interventions in low- and middle-income countries, students evaluate both theoretical models and empirical evidence — emphasising causal inference and rigorous econometric methods. By the end, students will be able to analyse development challenges critically and assess the policy tools available to address them.

Designed for third-year economics majors, the course assumes prior completion of Microeconomics I and Econometrics.

 

Learning Outcomes

By the end of this course, students will be able to:

  1. Apply foundational microeconomic and macroeconomic frameworks to analyze key issues in development economics;
  2. Engage critically with contemporary policy debates in developing countries, particularly in areas such as education, health, labour, and capital markets;
  3. Interpret and evaluate empirical research using econometric tools, with a focus on understanding causal identification strategies and the strengths and limitations of evidence-based policymaking.
Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

I will supply most articles via a shared google drive.

A note on the readings: I list recommended readings by topic. Often, this list will be quite long because it covers several aspects of a particular issue we are discussing in a given week, including recent empirical research on it. For example, if I mention a finding from a paper in class, I will list that paper under the readings for the week. However, you will not be expected to read all of the readings before every single class. I will specify the readings you must complete ahead of class. The longer reading list will help you gain a deeper understanding of the different topics, and I encourage you to further pursue topics you’re interested in, or follow up on a paper that you want to better understand.

Introduction to Newswriting and Reporting [MS-1101] [MS-1101-1]

Faculty Name
Maya Mirchandani [maya.mirchandani@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

This course is an introduction to the practice of journalism. Students will learn how to identify, report and write news pieces and learn skills of observation and research. 

In the course of the semester, students will be introduced to journalistic ethics, fundamental concepts of newsworthiness, and the techniques of writing news reports. Students will be introduced to the different sources of information, and learn the basics of interviewing for reportage. Through field based practice students will be taught to evaluate, analyse and present information as reports with accuracy, context, clarity and conciseness. 

 

 

Learning Outcomes

Learning Outcomes

Basic newspaper reporting skills 

Introduction to different formats of news - print, broadcast, digital and social media 

Learn about different sources of information and the use of social media for journalistic purposes. 

the art of listening, observing, interviewing and note-taking.

Quantitative Reasoning and Mathematical Thinking [FC-0306] [FC-0306-2]

Faculty Name
Mihir Bhattacharya [mihir.bhattacharya@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

The course will begin with pre-requisite tools of quantitative thinking vis-a-vis the number system, set theory, logic, proofs, probability and statistics. We will then learn how to use some of these tools to study (i) fairness in division of scarce resources, (ii) collective decisions in committees and democracies around the world (voting methods), and (iii) how to act optimally in competitive social interactions, i.e. game theory. By the end of the course, students would have a basic understanding of the most widely used mathematical tools in the liberal arts. They will learn how to approach different economic problems- by reducing them to their bare essentials (via modelling) and to mathematically analyse their underlying structural and logical patterns. 

 

 

Learning Outcomes

Students will be able to think quantitatively and mathematically across various disciplines and applications. They will learn to use mathematical symbols, to develop an intuition for proofs and to write formal arguments. 

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Some recommended books:

Mathematics for Liberal Arts Majors, Christopher Thomas, Schaum’s outline series, McGraw Hill, 2008

Games of Strategy, Avinash Dixit, David H. Reiley (Jr.) and Susan Skeath, W.W. Norton & Company (2009) (or Viva Books, 2017, Indian edition).

Lecture slides will be shared in class.

Attendance is compulsory. Entering the classroom more than 5 minutes late and leaving before the class has ended will be counted as an absence. Students with more than 6 absences will be penalized with multiple grade cuts. The use of laptops and mobiles is strictly prohibited in the classroom. You may use writing-based tablets and notebooks. No repeat exams will be conducted except in case of own medical emergency (a formal proof is required).

Quantitative Reasoning and Mathematical Thinking [FC-0306] [FC-0306-4]

Overview

This course is meant for students who are either intimidated by mathematics or those who like mathematics but want to find ways of applying mathematics to the real world. It will be split into two sections. The first will build data literacy, the process of starting with raw numbers and using simple but powerful methods of interpreting the stories that the numbers tell. It will enable students to follow a systematic approach in building a toolkit to analyse numbers. The approach would be to draw constantly on real world examples to illustrate how simple quantitative tools are used to analyse and address complex problems.

How for instance, is standard deviation used to understand financial market behaviour? How can it be used to have a deeper insight into cost-of-living challenges for communities? Does ice-cream consumption actually drive up the crime rate in American cities as the data seems to suggest? What does a car-buyer’s choice of colour tell us about dependent, independent and control variables? Students will be asked to process raw data (cricket scores, monthly expenditures of classmates etc) to arrive at interesting insights and hypotheses.

The second section will focus on the intuition behind key ideas in mathematics. We will look at shapes of curves and optimization, set theory, game theory and Nash equilibrium, voting models and fair division as well as the mathematics of networks as well as financial mathematics. Here again, the focus will be on applications of these ideas in the real world. For example, why do countries find it difficult on agree on climate change measures even when it appears to be a good thing for everyone? When does it make sense to rent a house instead of taking a loan to buy one? What was the intuition behind ranked-choice voting used in the elections for New York city mayor? What do tangents tell us about Usain Bolt’s running style?

We will also look at some of the contemporary issues in mathematics and statistics such as the use of “ Big Data” and “Black Swans” and tail risks.

A diverse set of resources including videos, blogs, number games along with a textbook will be used.  

Learning Outcomes

Course evaluation:

4 quizzes—40 per cent

Class participation –15 per cent

Group project: 45 per cent

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Textbook: Math for Liberal Arts Majors, Schaum’s Outline Series

English Graduate Pro-Seminar: Thesis Preparation [ENG-4001] [ENG-4001-1]

Faculty Name
Alexander Robert Phillips [alexander.phillips@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

The proseminar is a meeting of writers. Its aim is to provide participants with structure, support, and community during the thesis writing process. The proseminar will guide writers from the initial intuition, through formulating a provisional argument, dialoguing with extent scholarship, and making a case for why their ideas deserve the attention of readers. Lecture and discussion sections will primarily focus on targeted aspects of writing, such as strategies for structuring a close reading, working effectively with “theory,” and responding to others’ arguments. In addition, participants will have ample opportunity to develop their ideas through scholarly dialogue with their peers. By the end of the monsoon semester, students will have a concrete plan for the thesis, as well as the beginnings of a working draft to be developed in spring semester.

English Graduate Pro-Seminar: Thesis Preparation [ENG-4001] [ENG-4001-2]

Faculty Name
Vivek Venkitaraman Narayan [v.v.narayan@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

The Graduate Proseminar is an academic writing workshop designed to help ASP and MA students turn in the best version of their thesis. In the Monsoon semester, students will learn to identify their research interests, frame research questions, read and respond to theoretical writing, develop research methods, and eventually produce a rough draft of the thesis. In Spring, students will present ideas from their thesis in a workshop environment, edit and revise their writing in conversation with their advisor and peers, articulate their theoretical contributions, and eventually submit a revised—and hopefully, refined—draft of the thesis.

Learning Outcomes

Upon completing this course, students will be able to:  

  • Conceptualize a research project in dialogue with existing literature on the subject.
  • Write an abstract of a research project. 
  • Describe the scope and stakes of their project in a prospectus.
  • Present and defend their writing in a workshop environment.
  • Develop a productive writing routine.  
  • Share peer reviews of drafts.
  • Engage with feedback and edit their writing.

Environmental Studies [FC-0102] [FC-0102-1]

Faculty Name
Ghazala Shahabuddin [ghazala.shahabuddin@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

The contemporary world is beset with growing environmental problems. The global focus on economic growth and development has led us onto an unsustainable path: growing scientific evidence now suggests that the Earth may not be able to cope with the demands imposed on it.  This has created an urgent need to critically examine complex environmental issues from a variety of perspectives. It is necessary to inculcate holistic thinking on environmental challenges and their purported solutions, that includes concerns of social and ecological sustainability.  

This course will discuss some of the most current concerns related to the environment, as well as societal responses to them, from a multidisciplinary perspective. Water scarcity, climate change, forest degradation, biological extinction, pollution and agrarian distress are some of the issues that will be studied. This course is intended to familiarise students with environmental problems  and engender a holistic perspective in understanding causes and possible solutions through the lenses of both science and equity. This course will encourage students to synthesize information across a variety of sources.

Practically the course will be taught using a combination of lectures, movies, slideshows and in-class discussions. Discussion on assigned readings will engender critical thinking and debate in class. Students will undertake group projects on current case studies (such as river pollution, tiger tourism etc.). Assessments will be based on class tests, group projects and class participation.

Learning Outcomes
  • The course will create an awareness of, and sensitivity to the complexities of contemporary environmental challenges;
  • Students will learn to analyse environmental issues from a multidisciplinary perspective;
  • Students will learn to think and write analytically about complex issues
  • They will be taught to synthesize knowledge from different sources including scholarly papers, government documents, visual media and local tradition.
Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Course Topics (Each module=1.5 lecture-hour)

Module 1: Introduction to Contemporary Environmental Challenges

The students will be introduced to contemporary environmental issues such as climate change, biological extinction, pollution, food security, waste, water scarcity and forest degradation. The concepts of social equity and ecological and economic sustainability   will be introduced as ways of understanding environmental challenges globally and in developing societies such as India. 

Module 2,3: Population Growth and Sustainability

This module focuses on the relationship between population and the environment. Issues of population growth, stability, consumption patterns, demographic transition, coupled with human development challenges, social security, disease and scarcity will be addressed.

Module 4: Environment as a Commons

This module explores the understanding of  'environment' as a common. If indeed it is difficult to set up exclusive access to the environment then what kind of challenges may one anticipate in sharing the environment as a common? The module expects the students to familiarize themselves with Hardin's argument wherein commons are understood to fail, thus qualifying as a tragedy. A  counter to this argument is presented through Elinor Ostrom's work which argues for the possibility of successfully governing commons.

Module 5: Resource Scarcity at the Margins

This module explores the relationship between poverty, and environmental degradation, asking the larger questions of who suffers the most from environmental problems and disasters, and who pays the price. Do the interests of biodiversity and human well-being necessarily coincide? This module delves into the forms of resource and environmental governance that exist. We revisit the critical role of commons and the varying implications of environmental governance for social-ecological sustainability of ecosystem-dependent livelihoods at the margins.

Module 6,7: Climate Change I : Science and Impacts

In this module, the students will be introduced to the scientific debates on climate change and the symptoms and manifestations of global warming, which will be interpreted in context of climate history. The students will explore the impacts of climate change on agriculture, health, livelihoods and biodiversity, based on analysis of three short movies on climate-induced displacement.

Module 8,9: Climate Change II: Mitigation and Adaptation

In this module, we discuss climate change mitigation and adaptation, particularly in the context of current international agreements and initiatives. We focus on the apparent inequities between the developed and developing world, and how these may affect the mitigative pathways being adopted, such as recent ‘net-zero’ commitments. There will be a focus on climate justice and carbon markets particularly in the context of the latest international negotiations on climate change at COP-26 held at Glasgow, 2020.

Module 10,11: Biodiversity Loss

The students will be introduced to the causes and consequences of species extinction and ecosystem degradation from the scientific and socio-political perspectives.  Varied paradigms of biological conservation in terms of  their socio-economic, political and biological implications and impacts.

Module 12: Water Scarcity and Conservation

Water, the source of all life, has become one of the most contentious issues on the planet. Growing scarcity and pollution of water, as well as the increasing unpredictability of floods and droughts, has necessitated a deeper look at the traditional strategies for water conservation, and how they can be revived.

Module 13: Water Bodies and their Governance

Using Indian rivers and lakes as examples, we explore the complex interplay amongst religious traditions, local needs, governmental authority, policy-making and ecological factors in perpetuating water pollution and mismanagement, one of the major environmental issues we are living with. Break-out sessions, created around different stake-holder groups, will debate the problem of river pollution.

Module 14,15: Agrarian Crisis and Livelihoods

The agrarian crisis in India has serious implications for rural livelihoods and food security. In this module, we explore the ecological and political perspectives on the abandonment of agriculture and declining productivity in India.

Module 16,17: Human-Wildlife Conflicts

With growing degradation and fragmentation of natural habitats, and expansion of human settlements, conflict situations with wildlife are occurring more frequently, resulting in grievous human injury and losses. In this module, we explore the causes and consequences of such conflict from different perspectives- behavioural, economic and social. Students will be encouraged to apply the concept of environmental commons to conflict management.

Module 18: Development as Disaster ?

A large number of environmental problems are created by large-scale industrial development and infrastructure that are undertaken without sufficient precautions. Thus it is necessary to explore the repercussions of the adopted development models for ecology and local livelihoods. We then explore the development processes and amelioratory laws and policies for environmental damage caused by infrastructural development in India.

Module 19,20: Governmental Responses: Environment Laws, Policies and Regulation

This module explores the historical context of environmental law-making and implementation in India. The role of government in environmental conservation will be analysed by the students, through discussion on key environmental laws in India such as the Forest Conservation Act, Forest Rights Act, the Wildlife Protection Act and the Environmental Protection Act. Regulatory laws such as Environmental Impact Assessment and Coastal Zone Regulation will also be covered. The aim will be to explore not only the contours and details of these laws but also their implementation, as well as their impacts on society and biodiversity.

Module 21: Role of Local Government

Local Governance is of utmost importance for environmental sustainability and conservation and rural well-being. Students will be introduced to local governmental mechanisms and institutions in India. The case study of Western Himalaya will be discussed based on the role of forest councils in environmental conservation.

Module 22,23 People’s response: Environmental Movements

Environmental movements in India are significant for their grassroots base and role in highlighting (and resolving) growing resource conflicts, particularly in view of the visible contestation among rural communities, corporate sector and governments. Students will compare and contrast various environmental movements in India from the points of view of sustainability. Three landmark environmental movements will be discussed in class: Chipko Andolan, Ralegaon Siddhi and Narmada Bachao Andolan.

Module 24: Ecosystem Services and their Valuation

Monetization of ecosystem services has emerged as one of the possible solutions for safe-guarding nature. We will discuss the concept of ecosystem services, their valuation and the potential of such understanding for conservation. The advantages and pitfalls of using this approach will be debated. The concept of green GDP will be introduced as a way to stem the degradation of ecosystem services globally.

Module 25, 26: Traditional Knowledge and the Environment

Traditional knowledge has historically been the crucible for understanding and conservation of nature, which empowers indigenous communities and economies. It is important to explore the concept, as well as its applicability and usefulness for human well-being in modern times. Convention on Biological Diversity and Biological Diversity Act will be discussed in the context of safe-guarding indigenous people’s intellectual Property Rights.

Environmental Studies [FC-0102] [FC-0102-4]

Faculty Name
Mukul Sharma [mukul.sharma@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

ENVIRONMENT, POLITICS, SOCIETY

Environment has become an important area of interactions between society, politics, economy and culture. This foundation course will focus on diverse sets of social, economic and cultural values and political, ideological and religious views expressed through environment. The course will discuss how ecological issues are understood in different political and economic systems, ideologies and institutions. In turn, the political, ideological and social essence of ecological problems is manifested by deeply contrasting visions of what structuring society according to nature might mean. Taking a historical approach, the course will strengthen the interaction of natural and social sciences in understanding contemporary environmental politics. The course will give close attention to some prominent environmental and social movements in India, which will significantly enhance the knowledge about new developments in environment/politics/society interface.    

Learning Outcomes

The course is organized around weekly lectures and discussions based on the readings. Students will be asked to write an essay on one of the topics of the course, with footnotes and bibliography, and further readings will be given to them on their chosen topic, so that they can go in much more depth on a particular topic

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Course Content:

Unit 1: (Week 1 & 2): Environment, Politics, Society: The Dialectices of Civilisational, Historical, Natural, Material, Economic, Ideological and Political Aspects of the Ecological Issues and Changes

Unit 2: (Week 3): Environment, Green Village, Authority and Democracy: Ralegaon Sidhi and Anna Hazare

Unit 3: (Week 4 ): Nature and Nationalism: Anti-Tehri Dam Movement and Sunderlal Bahuguna

Unit 4: (Week 5): Environmentalism and Revivalism: The Vrindavan Forest Revival and Conservation Project

Unit 5: (Week 6): Environment and Ethnicity: The Politics of Sacred Groves in Jharkhand

Unit 6: (Week 7 & 8): Hindu Nationalism and the Environment: Elements and Themes

Unit 7: (Week 9): Environment, Labour and Labour Organisations

Unit 8: (Week 10-11): Environment, Social and Political Movement, Network & Alliances

Environmental Studies [FC-0102] [FC-0102-5]

Overview

Professor Simon Brown

Some of the most pressing issues of our time arise from our impact on the environment. In this course, we will explore questions such as: What obligations, if any, do we have to future generations, other species, or ecosystems, and why?  What does it mean for something to be natural, and does something’s being natural inherently make it worth preserving?  What are the most pressing environmental issues—what exactly are the main threats associated with climate change, and how should we think about them in relation to other environmental issues such as air and water pollution, biodiversity loss, and deforestation? What does justice look like in a world where development may require environmental destruction—or is this a false dichotomy?  What kinds of actions (if any) are ethically required of us as individuals: should ordinary citizens leave action on environmental issues to the state, billionaires, and/or corporations, or ought we to make drastic changes in our own lifestyles?  How can ordinary citizens determine what to think about complex environmental issues when our information environment is polluted by sophisticated campaigns of misinformation, and can we deal with such problems adequately within a liberal democratic society?

Learning Outcomes
  • gain an understanding of some of the most pressing environmental challenges of our time (including their social and political dimensions) and their policy solutions
  • develop a holistic understanding of the environment around us, including its biophysical and social elements
  • learn to articulate the main claims and strengths and weaknesses of major frameworks in contemporary environmental ethics, and how to apply them to a range of issues 
  • enhance your ability to make informed, environmentally friendly decisions in your life as a responsible citizen, using critical reflection and evidence from multiple disciplines
  • refine your ability in using techniques of analysis, construction, expression, and assessment of logical arguments

Microeconomics 1 [ECO-5101] [ECO-5101-1]

Faculty Name
Sanyyam Khurana [sanyyam.khurana@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

This is a graduate level course on microeconomic theory. The course is broadly divided into three parts. In the first part, we will study a consumer's problem of utility maximization under budget constraints. In the second part, we will study a producer's problem of cost minimization given technological constraints. In the third part, we will study general equilibrium where consumers and producers interact. The treatment of the course will be rigorous in nature.

Learning Outcomes
  1.  To understand the core concepts in microeconomics.
  2. To apply the concepts in economic problems.
  3. To build intuitions of results.
  4. To learn proof writing.

Quantitative Techniques [ECO-5011] [ECO-5011-1]

Faculty Name
Mihir Bhattacharya [mihir.bhattacharya@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

This is a compulsory course for MA Economics, which will provide the students the mathematical tools and techniques required for quantitative economic analysis in all sub-fields of economics. A basic knowledge of calculus, vector space and algebra will be required.

Learning Outcomes

Students will learn mathematical tools required for various areas of economics: Microeconomics, Macroeconomics and Econometrics. Some of the topics covered include existence of solutions to systems of linear equations using rank of a matrix, linear independence of vectors, basis of a set of vectors, span of a set of vectors, matrix algebra, determinants, Cramer’s rule, Inverse of a matrix, eigenvalues, properties of eigenvalues, etc. Differentiation and Optimization: derivatives, chain rule, directional derivatives, higher-order derivatives, implicit functions, system of implicit functions, quadratic forms, definiteness of quadratic forms, unconstrained optimization: FOC, SOC, local max/min, global max/min, constrained optimisation:equality constraints, inequality constraints, constraint qualification, homogeneous functions, concave/convex functions, quasi-concave/quasi-convex functions, concave programming, Weierstrass’ theorem, Lagrange's method, Kuhn-Tucker conditions, Slater's condition, etc.

Note that the list of topics is not exhaustive and the full course outline will be shared in class.

1. Simon and Blume's “Mathematics for Economists”, Norton (1994)
2. Sundaram's "First course in Optimization Theory” (Cambridge University Press,
1996)

The Theory of Linear Economic Models, David Gale, University of Chicago Press (1960)

courseTitle: History of India II: From c. 200 BCE to 1000 CE
description:
History of India II: From c. 200 BCE to 1000 CE [HIS-2002] [HIS-2002-1]

Faculty Name
Upinder Singh [upinder.singh@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

What happened after the Maurya empire collapsed? Why do Krishna and Balarama appear along with Zeus and Athena on Indo-Greek coins? How did ancient poets express the emotion of love in Prakrit, Sanskrit and Tamil? What is unique about the Buddha images found at Sarnath? Why did the Panchatantra animal stories become so popular across Europe and Asia? Why did the Cholas launch a naval expedition against Srivijaya? This course answers these and many more questions. It highlights continuities and change in political structures, class, caste, gender, agrarian relations, urban life and trade. It discusses the history of Hinduism, Buddhism, Jainism and Islam along with the primordial worship of serpents and yakshas, the pervasive influence of Tantra, and the extent to which bhakti saints questioned social hierarchies. The emergence of regional profiles in early medieval times, the vitality in intellectual life, the efflorescence of art and architecture, and the many ways in which the Indian subcontinent was connected with the wider world are other major themes. While giving a panoramic view of the Indian subcontinent between the momentous centuries between c. 200 BCE and 1000 CE, the course explains the sources through which histories of this period are written and addresses key issues that are essential to comprehend the complexities of India’s past.

Learning Outcomes

Students will get a grasp of fundamental issues related to early Indian history as well as be exposed to the primary sources on the basis of which history is written.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

courseTitle: Electricity and Magnetism in Light of Relativity
description:
Electricity and Magnetism in Light of Relativity [PHY-2310] [PHY-2310-1]

Faculty Name
Susmita Saha [susmita.saha@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

Welcome to the course named, “Electricity and Magnetism in the light of relativity”. This course serves as a gateway into the captivating realm of electromagnetism, exploring its foundational principles and practical applications. We will start with the basic concept of electrostatics and magnetostatics and at the end we will study the relativistic aspects of electrodynamics. At the end of the course, you will have acquired a robust understanding of electromagnetism and electrodynamics, empowering you to analyze and solve a diverse array of problems.

Course content:  In this course we will cover the following topics:

Electrostatics:  Coulomb’s law, Electric field, Potentials, Gauss’s law, work and energy, Laplace’s equations, method of images, multipole expansions, Electric field in matter: conductors, dielectrics and superconductors

Magnetostatics: Lorentz force low, Biot-savart law, magnetic vector potentials, magnetic field in matter: diamagnets, paramagnets and ferromagnets.

Electrodynamics: Electromotive forces, Ohm law, Faraday’s law, Maxwells equation 

Electrodynamics and relativity:  Einstein postulates, Lorentz transformation, relativistic electrodynamics

Taught at the level of: Introduction to Electrodynamics (D J Griffiths), Electricity & Magnetism (E M Purcell).

Learning Outcomes

Will gain the knowledge  about Electromagnetism and the special theory of relativity.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Pre-requisites: Physics primar

1. Basic idea of Vector analysis: vector Addition, Subtraction, Dot and Cross product

2. Concept of Gradient ,  Divergence, Curl

3. Line, surface and volume  integral in both Spherical Polar and Cartesian coordinate system

description:
Health Economics [ECO-6650] [ECO-6650-1]

Faculty Name
Aparajita Dasgupta [aparajita.dasgupta@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

This course is an introduction to the field of health economics. Health economics is an active field of microeconomics with a large and growing literature and is an important aspect of public policy. The purpose of the course is to understand the microeconomic foundations of health economics and to introduce students to some key research questions and methods in health economics. The course further aims to develop an understanding of a variety of econometric techniques and research designs used by applied microeconomists focusing
on causal inference to critically evaluate key research papers in health economics. The course will cover topics such as measurement and determinants of health, health disparities, relationship between health and economic development, the need for financial risk protection
against health shocks, the determinants of fertility and demographic change, economics of nutrition and human capital formation, behavioural insights in health, health and gender, economic evaluation of health and health programs.

Qualitative Research Methods [PSY-3082] [PSY-3082-1]

Faculty Name
Annie Baxi [annie.baxi@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

The course is designed to introduce students to the prominent qualitative research methods in Psychology. Qualitative research facilitates an in-depth and contextual  understanding of  psychological states and processes through systematic analyses of thick descriptive and experiential data. Questions like - What is the lived experience of a psychiatric diagnosis? How are images and symbols in popular media influencing our everyday language and reality? What are the various stages of coping in the aftermath of a trauma? Why are certain stories and myths important in a community? are most suited for a qualitative inquiry. 

The course will begin with a rationale of the various qualitative approaches and their underlying theoretical assumptions. The lectures will include activities designed to give a hands-on-experience of all the major qualitative methods. Throughout the course, students will be encouraged to engage in thinking about and articulating the role of researcher’s subjectivity and social position in qualitative research. 

Learning Outcomes

After completing the course, the student will be able to:

  • - Understand the relevance of the various paradigms in psychological research.
  • - Identify and differentiate between the different methods in qualitative research.
  • - Develop and enhance skills involved in conducting a qualitative interview.
  • - Appreciate the role of Reflexivity and Positionality in the dynamics of qualitative work.
  • - Analyse and interpret data using Thematic Analysis.
Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

1. Denzin, N. K., & Lincoln, Y. S. (Eds.). (2018). The SAGE Handbook of Qualitative Research (5th ed.). Los Angeles, CA: Sage.

2.  Smith, J. A. (Ed.). (2003). Qualitative psychology: A practical guide to research methods.  Sage Publications, Inc.

3. Grbich, C. (2013). Qualitative Data Analysis: An Introduction (2nd ed.). New York: Sage

4 Yin, R. K. (2016). Qualitative research from start to finish. New York: The Guilford Press

 

Attendance

Introduction to Philosophy [PHI-1000] [PHI-1000-1]

Faculty Name
Aditi Chaturvedi [aditi.chaturvedi@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

Do smartphones make us unhappy? Do they lead to loneliness and corrode friendships? Friendship is an integral part of all our lives – but what makes someone a good friend? Do we have special obligations to our family and to people with whom we closely associate?  Are you certain that you are reading this description? How do you know this isn’t just a dream? How do we come to know anything at all?  We take all kinds of things to be true on a regular basis – but are we really justified in so doing?  Can we be blamed/praised for what we do? Can we say that we have freedom to choose our actions? 

In this course, we'll explore such questions in ethics and politics, epistemology, and metaphysics. Our discussions will be guided by texts drawn from diverse philosophical traditions and time periods, from the 4th century BCE to 2025.  Along the way, you'll develop skills in constructing sustained arguments, considering objections and counter-objections, and making conceptual connections across traditions. The course will demonstrate both the fruitfulness and challenges of philosophical inquiry, and the tools you will acquire here will serve you well beyond the study of philosophy. 

Learning Outcomes

The Political Arts [POL-3024] [POL-3024-1]

Faculty Name
Malvika Maheshwari [malvika.maheshwari@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

In what ways does power translate and transform through art practice? Why and how are democratic states so invested in promoting, but also censoring the arts? How do categories in art appear? What role do states, markets and artists play in producing these categories? What is the role of the market in making art and artists matter? How does an audience develop a relationship with specific artists, and acquire a taste for the arts? With a central question « what can art practice tell us about social and political institutions and relationships? » this course explores the deeply fraught yet critical alliance between political practice and the art world. To address this issue, the course begins with answering why, in the first place, should social scientists be concerned about the arts?

Learning Outcomes

The course will not only entail a study of important theoretical texts, alongside focusing on empirical research and literature emerging in field, but we will also critically engage with the arts and reflect on methodological strategies that are applied to study the relationship between art and politics.

Querying the Early Medieval [HIS-3203] [HIS-3203-1]

Faculty Name
Sanjukta Datta [sanjukta.datta@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

The period between c.600-1200 CE is considered to be a distinct stage in Indian history, connecting the ancient to the medieval, and is labelled as the early medieval. So what are the distinguishing historical markers of the early medieval? How have historians understood the early medieval within the conventional categorization of Indian history into ancient, medieval and modern? Beginning with the question of periodization in Indian history, the course moves on to the exploration of diverse themes relating to the early medieval period such as the unfolding of particular political processes and articulations of kingship; flowering of regional identities through language, literature, and art; emergence of powerful religious movements and encounters between distinct religious traditions; and expanding networks between the subcontinent and the rest of Asia through military campaigns, trade and pilgrimage. 

Learning Outcomes

Quantum Mechanics [PHY-3510] [PHY-3510-1]

Faculty Name
Suratna Das [suratna.das@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

Albert Einstein: “God doesn’t play dice [with the universe]”

Niels Bohr: “Einstein, stop telling God what to do!”

 

We are all familiar with the tussle between Albert Einstein and Niels Bohr when it came to Quantum Mechanics: a completely new way of looking at the world of atomic and subatomic particles which started to unravel in the beginning and middle of the last century. In this course, we will learn the very basics of this vast subject, a subject which still causes bewilderment to the greatest of the minds. There’s no well-known physicist in this world who has not pondered over the mind-boggling Quantum Mechanics deeply at some point of time in their life. 

 

The course has been designed in the following way:

 

1. Some historical motivations: Blackbody spectrum: the problem of ultraviolet catastrophe and Planck’s constant, Bohr’s atomic model and de Broglie wavelength, Wave-particle duality: Young’s double slit experiment, Davisson-Germer Experiment, Photoelectric Effect, Atomic spectroscopy.

2. Basics of Quantum Mechanics: Wavefunction, Schrödinger Equation, Interpretation of Wavefunction, Wavefunction normalisation, Wavefunction as a probability amplitude, Principle of superposition, Wavepackets and Uncertainty,  Time evolution of a free wavepacket 

3. Examples: Particle in a 1D potential (Dirac delta, infinite and finite square-well potentials) - bound states and scattering, Tunnelling and quantum mechanical explanation of radioactive decay.

4. Operator method: Hilbert space of states, bra-ket notation, observables as linear operators, Schrodinger equation and unitary evolution, state vector collapse - Born rule, The energy, position and momentum basis - transforming between different bases: Schrodinger and Heisenberg pictures, The harmonic oscillator, angular momentum and spin in Quantum Mechanics, Stern-Gerlach experiment, The hydrogen atom - derivation of its energy levels.

5. ** Some advanced topics: Symmetries and Conservation laws in Quantum Mechanics, Quantum-to-Classical Transition problem (Copenhagen Interpretation, Many-world Interpretation, Decoherence) [These topics will be covered only if time permits]

Learning Outcomes

Quantum Mechanics is the basis of modern science, be it physics, chemistry, biology or computer science. This course will set the basis of other higher level courses that the Physics Major students will credit in future, like Quantum Mechanics II, Physics of Matter and Electronics. By the end of this course, it is expected that students will have a firm foundation in the fundamental concepts of QM, will be familiar with both the state-vector and wave mechanics based approaches, and would have gained the relevant background to explore and understand the manifold applications of QM to explain diverse physical phenomena, be it in Atomic, Molecular, Nuclear, Particle Physics or Quantum Information  or Condensed Matter physics. 

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Prerequisite: 

Absolute essential prerequisites for this course are the materials covered in MP1, MP2 and Classical Mechanics courses. The students are advised to revise the following parts from these courses before the course begins:

MP1: Linear Vector Spaces and Matrices, Partial Derivatives 

MP2: Partial Differential Equation 

Classical Mechanics: Lagrangian and Hamiltonian formulations 

Apart from the above topics, familiarity with basic concepts of probability is also required. 

 

References: 

The course will closely follow the following two text books:

 

Introduction to Quantum Mechanics: David Griffiths 

Principles of Quantum Mechanics: R. Shankar 

 

Other books useful for reference and supplementary reading include: Feynman Lectures on Physics (Vol. III), Modern Quantum Mechanics, by J.J. Sakurai, Quantum Mechanics by Leonard Schiff 

Attendance

Attending all the classes as well as the discussion sessions are mandatory. 

Excused absence(s) are not applicable in this course lecture.
Additional excused absence(s) are not applicable for sportspersons in this course lecture.
Additional Comments:

Statistical Mechanics [PHY-3610] [PHY-3610-1]

Faculty Name
Garima Mishra [garima.mishra@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

Overview:

Say we have a complete understanding of the fundamental laws of nature for a system containing 1023 (or any large number) particles and aim to examine its properties. One might consider starting with writing and solving equations of motion for 1023 particle. However, this approach is impractical due to the vast number of particles involved. Even if achievable, the challenge lies in bridging microscopic details of individual particles (position, momentum) to macroscopic observables of the system.

Statistical mechanics serves as a tool to elucidate the behaviour of systems with a large number of particles. It bridges the behaviour of individual particles at the microscopic level to the observable properties of macroscopic systems.

Contents:

Review of thermodynamics, kinetic theory of gases, microcanonical, canonical, and grand canonical ensembles in classical statistical mechanics, identical particles and quantum statistics, Bosonic and Fermionic systems, quantum ideal gas, interacting particles, Phase transitions.

Books:

Fundamentals of Statistical and Thermal Physics, F Reif.

 

Learning Outcomes
Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Themal Physics, MP1

Industrial Organisation [ECO-3600] [ECO-3600-1]

Faculty Name
Saish Vijay Nevrekar [saish.nevrekar@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

Think about a simple the cartoon of Mahatma Gandhi: just a few simple strokes---round glasses, a walking stick, a shawl---and yet you immediately recognize who it is. A good cartoon doesn't aim for realism; it captures the essence.

This course teaches you to cartoon markets. Like a skilled cartoonist, you'll learn how to use minimal strokes to highlight the main strategic forces in markets. The focus isn't on solving complex equations but on building clear, insightful models. You'll learn what to include, what to leave out, and how to communicate economic ideas effectively.

A central idea in this course is understanding the trade-off between complexity and explanatory power. While there is no \(R^2\) for a theoretical model, whether it fits something in a meaningful way is often a matter of judgement. However, we can loosely think of better “fitting” models as being more complex. Not only are such models harder to solve, often requiring more advanced game-theoretic tools, but they also tend to have lower explanatory power: you can no longer easily see the economics at work inside the model. Thus, economic modelling relies on judgment rather than precise metrics, making it as much an art as a science.

Learning Outcomes

This course addresses two key questions students often have:

  • Why Learn Game Theory? Students frequently wonder why they are required to learn to solve abstract game-theoretic models. The crucial connection between game-theoretic models and real-world scenarios is often not explicitly covered---this course addresses that gap. You will see why modelling is a valuable skill that deepens your understanding of market dynamics.  
  • How to Build Models? Even if you understand the value of economic models, constructing them from scratch can be challenging. Model-building involves translating real-world situations into structured economic thinking, making informed assumptions, and deciding what complexities to simplify. This course provides a clear framework to confidently build models.
  • Why learn to model? In many of the most important markets today—especially digital and AI-driven ones—reliable data is extremely difficult to obtain. High-quality data is either proprietary, tightly guarded by firms, or prohibitively expensive. In such environments, economic models become powerful tools for reasoning about how these markets function. We use models to explore questions like: How do AI and Big Tech platforms operate? What kinds of business models underlie Amazon, Google, Meta, and OpenAI? And how are governments—from India to Europe to the U.S.—crafting new rules around data sharing, app store pricing, and algorithmic transparency? Contrary to what you may believe, constructing complex models is actually easy. However, solving them is difficult, and disentangling the economic interpretations is even more difficult. Good models are simple, elegant and yet demonstrate novel economic interpretations. Constructing such models is often difficult, but one constructed look simple or even obvious.
