Economics of Gender [ECO-3660] [ECO-3660-1]

Faculty Name
Bipasha Maity [bipasha.maity@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

This course aims at undertaking an economic analysis of the issues affecting women in the economy. The discrimination faced by women in market scenarios, such as those of labour and credit as well as the impact of globalization on women will be studied. Further, the course will explore issues that women face in non-market situations such as bargaining within the household, marriage and fertility and how market and non-market scenarios interact to in uence women's well-being. Lastly the roles of education, healthcare, property rights, birth control, political franchise and representation in mitigating gender-based inequalities will be studied. Students would be able to understand and appreciate both market and non-market factors that result in or promote gender based inequalities. They would also be able to critically understand why some policies succeed while others may fail to mitigate gender-based inequalities.

Learning Outcomes
Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

The main textbook for the course is:

Why Gender Matters in Economics. Author: Mukesh Eswaran. Publisher: Princeton University Press, 2014.

A significant part of the course also relies on materials from published papers in academic economics journals. This will be provided by the first week of classes.

Craft of Writing (Translation) [CW-2011] [CW-2011-1]

Faculty Name
Arunava Sinha [arunava.sinha@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

In this course, students will develop the basic skills of translation by working on a variety of short texts as well as one medium-sized text. The short exercises will be aimed at practising different genres and facets of translation, including prose, poetry, and dialogue. At this stage they will learn about making choices and the elements of the original text that need to be carried over into the translated text. The second half will involve translating a medium-sized text of the student's choice from their mother tongue (or any other language of choice) into English, applying the earlier learnings. The course is aimed at preparing students to translate full-length texts.

Students should have completed the Introduction to Creative Writing Course and Reading For Writers.

Learning Outcomes
Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Ecology and Evolution (Lab) [BIO-3012/ ES-3301] [BIO-3012/ ES-3301-1]

Faculty Name
Imroze Khan [imroze.khan@ashoka.edu.in] ,Shivani [shivani.krishna@ashoka.edu.in ];
Overview

The course offers a hands-on experience to apply concepts from evolutionary biology and ecology theory courses. Students will be introduced to quantitative methods and research processes in ecology and evolution, which include experimental design, data collection, analysis, interpretation, and scientific writing, utilizing both field and laboratory studies. 

Ecological systems are immensely complex due to the diverse and context-dependent interactions among species, shaped by evolutionary processes and resulting in numerous emergent properties. In the course, students learn how real-world ecologists and evolutionary biologists tackle this complexity by beginning with simple assumptions. They will use local plant and animal models to test concepts on population dynamics, competition, resource utilization, foraging behavior, antibiotic resistance, and sexual selection. The course comprises interconnected laboratory modules. Each module aims to revisit some of the concepts introduced in the lectures and also trains students to construct arguments in ecological and evolutionary biology based on the evidence. Thinking analytically and scientific writing are best developed through practice. Thus, actively engaging in writing laboratory reports will serve as a useful tool to improve students’ writing skills. 

Learning Outcomes

Towards the end of this course, students will be able to design experiments, implement appropriate sampling methods for individuals, populations, and communities, and inquire about their diversity and stability. They will be acquainted with potential errors that arise due to observer bias, the significance of blinded methods, and other potential ways to improve the reliability of the data collected.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Reading materials will be provided on a weekly basis for each of the modules.

Attendance
3 excused absence(s) are allowed in this course lecture.
1 additional excused absence(s) are allowed for sportspersons in this course lecture.
Additional Comments: This is a laboratory course that involves live animals and plants; therefore, repeating the modules is not possible. Therefore, the total number of allowed absences cannot exceed 4.

Introduction to Neuroscience/ Biological Psychology [PSY-2011/ BIO-2103/ BIO-6103] [PSY-2011/ BIO-2103/ BIO-6103-1]

Faculty Name
Supriya Ray [supriya.ray@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

“Within this brain of mine, A universe resides, where thoughts like stars align, And reason gently guides.” -Author Unknown.

“I consider that a man's brain originally is like a little empty attic, and you have to stock it with such furniture as you choose. A fool takes in all the lumber of every sort that he comes across, so that the knowledge which might be useful to him gets crowded out..." - Sir Arthur Conan Doyle, A Study in Scarlet

This introductory course provides a broad overview of the fascinating field of neuroscience, exploring the structure, function, development, and disorders of the nervous system. We will delve into the fundamental principles governing neuronal communication, sensory and motor systems, learning and memory, emotion, and higher cognitive functions. This course aims to equip students with a foundational understanding of the brain and its intricate relationship with behavior and cognition. No prior knowledge of neuroscience is required, although a basic understanding of biology and psychology is helpful.

Learning Outcomes

Upon successful completion of this course, students will be able to:

  • Identify the major structures of the nervous system and their functions.
  • Explain the principles of neuronal signalling, including action potentials and synaptic transmission.
  • Describe the organization and function of sensory systems (e.g., vision, audition, somatosensation).
  • Explain the neural mechanisms underlying motor control and movement.
  • Discuss the biological basis of learning, memory, and plasticity.
  • Describe the neural circuits involved in emotion and motivation.
  • Understand the neural correlates of higher cognitive functions such as language and attention.
  • Gain an introductory understanding of common neurological and psychiatric disorders.
  • Critically evaluate basic neuroscience research findings.
  • Develop an appreciation for the interdisciplinary nature of neuroscience.
Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Required Textbook:

  • Fundamental Neuroscience (3rd / 4th Ed) by Larry Squire, Floyd Bloom, et al.

Recommended Readings (Optional):

  • Neuroscience (6th Ed) by Dale Purves
  • Biological Psychology (13th Ed) by James W. Kalat
  • Scientific articles and other materials will be shared through Google Classroom.

Microbiology [BIO-2411/ BIO-6411] [BIO-2411/ BIO-6411-1]

Faculty Name
Laasya Samhita [laasya.samhita@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

This microbiology module is designed as an inquiry-based laboratory course. It will investigate antimicrobial resistance (AMR) from multiple angles, incorporating aspects of molecular microbiology, microbial ecology and evolution. The aim is to expose students to how real research stories are built, while simultaneously teaching laboratory tools and techniques such as microbiological methods, PCR, mutagenesis and experimental evolution. Students are expected to participate in generating and evaluating evidence-based data. As a bonus, in cases that yield interesting results, students could also gain the opportunity to further analyse (beyond the class time) and publish their findings, thus gaining valuable research experience. In order to ensure personal attention and hands-on training, the number will be limited to 15 students (groups of 3 X 5).  At least one trained senior research assistants will participate as a GA to carry out prior preparatory work, organize and help with carrying out the activities. Those enrolling please note that in order to learn effectively we may have to work on occasion outside class hours.

Learning Outcomes

Learning outcomes:

How to isolate DNA from an environmental (mixed) and laboratory (pure) samples

PCR and primer design

Experimental evolution 

Problem based experimental design across different settings

Analysis of mutant genes and genomes

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Reading material will be shared before class introducing the problem of AMR and illustrating principles of experimental evolution, agarose gel electrophoresis and PCR. Everything else will be taught in class. Two primary resources are listed below:

‘Molecular cloning: a laboratory manual’ by Sambrook and Green (4th ed onwards)

https://www.cell.com/trends/ecology-evolution/pdf/S0169-5347%2812%2900142-5.pdf

Attendance
1 excused absence(s) are allowed in this course lecture.
1 additional excused absence(s) are allowed for sportspersons in this course lecture.
Additional Comments: Since this is a hands-on lab module meant to expose students to research, missing more than one class will impact learning outcomes significantly. Any absences beyond one class will need to be accompanied by a valid medical reason and certificate.

Linear Algebra [MAT-1001/ CS-2210/ PHY-1001] [MAT-1001/ CS-2210/ PHY-1001-1]

Faculty Name
Sourav Ghosh [sourav.ghosh@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

 

In this course we will study the following topics: Real and complex vector spaces, subspaces, spanning sets, basis sets, dimension of a vector space.  Solution of a system of linear equations. Row space and column space of a matrix, rank of a matrix, elementary row and column operations of a matrix. Inversion of square matrices, rank factorization of a matrix. Properties of determinant. Linear transformations, range and null space of a linear transformation, rank-nullity theorem. Matrix representation of a linear transformation. Inner product spaces, normed linear spaces, examples of different normed linear spaces, orthonormal basis sets. Eigenvalues, eigenvectors, characteristic polynomials. Spectral theorem for real symmetric matrices. Singular value decompositions.

Learning Outcomes

Analyze and picturize multivariate data.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)
  • Friedberg, Insel and Spence: Linear algebra, Pearson, 2015.
  • K. Hoffman and R. Kunze: Linear algebra, Prentice-Hall, Second edition, 1971.

Gender Matters in Global Politics [IR-2015/ POL-2029] [IR-2015/ POL-2029-1]

Faculty Name
Ananya Sharma [ananya.sharma@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

This course is concerned with gender ‘in’ International Relations. It is a comprehensive introduction to a way of analyzing and researching global politics and international relations that takes gender seriously as a category of analysis. More specifically, it is concerned with how ideas of war, peace, sovereignty, violence, foreign policy, governance and political economy are sustained by specific masculinities and femininities, and how these particular gender constructions impact on the lives of particular groups of men and women. Set against this, the aim of the course is mainly threefold: firstly, to (re)introduce how the discipline has traditionally thought about war and peace; secondly, to reveal the gendered constructions and inequalities that mark the traditional scholarship; and thirdly, to evaluate the
specific contribution that feminist critiques have made as part of the so-called ‘Critical Turn’ in IR. Gender is understood here not as a synonym for ‘woman’ but as a hierarchical coding of masculinity and femininity that pervades social relations and institutional practices, with systemic (though not deterministic) effects on inequalities. Gender meanings and practices permeate our lives, and a closer look at these processes is more illuminating than many anticipate, with relevance and implications for who we are, how we think, and how we act – as individuals, groups, communities and nation-states.
Course Objectives:
• Understand the landscape of feminist international relations thought and challenge gender-blind and gendered approaches to global politics.
• Complicate understandings of global politics by identifying relationship between global crises and global gender(ed) divisions.
• Appreciate that the international is personal and the personal is international and recognize the necessity and complexity of taking gender seriously in global politics.

Learning Outcomes
Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

The pre-requiste is Introduction to International Relations Theory (IR 101).

Seminar Series in Biological Sciences [BIO-6014] [BIO-6014-1]

Faculty Name
Laasya Samhita [laasya.samhita@ashoka.edu.in] ,Rama Sundari Akondy [rama.akondy@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

This seminar series is designed to equip PhD and MSc students in the biological sciences with the essential skills for presenting, critiquing, and discussing scientific literature. This is a mandatory 4-credit course for PhD and MSc students (3 hour classes once a week). Students will present papers selected from a pool of papers suggested by the instructors.

Learning Outcomes

Learning Outcomes:

Critically evaluate the structure and organization of a scientific manuscript, identifying the research question, methodology, results, and conclusions.

Assess the strengths and weaknesses of a scientific manuscript, including the validity of its methodology, interpretation of data, and potential limitations.

Write and improve a concise and informative summary of the research question, and key findings from a manuscript.

Formulate well-structured questions during seminars to critically analyze research presented by peers and invited speakers, demonstrating an understanding of scientific concepts.

Develop and deliver a clear and concise scientific presentation that effectively communicates the key findings, strengths, and weaknesses/limitations from a reviewed manuscript, integrating them with existing knowledge in the field.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Prerequisites:

This course is designed for Masters and PhD students in the department of biology and assumes basic knowledge of English. Students who are not comfortable presenting or discussing scientific literature in English are encouraged to utilize the university's center for writing and communication (CWC).  Please don't hesitate to speak with the instructor to discuss any concerns or accommodations you may need prior to the course start.

Ecology [BIO-3020/ BIO-6020/ ES-2101/ PHY-3020] [BIO-3020/ BIO-6020/ ES-2101/ PHY-3020-1]

Faculty Name
Shivani [shivani.krishna@ashoka.edu.in ];
Overview

The course will cover a range of topics from individuals to ecosystems with an emphasis on theoretical foundations and recent developments in the field. We will begin with how ecological understanding is achieved, how conditions and resources influence individual species and then move to processes at higher levels of organization and end with rethinking some of the big questions in ecology. The topics covered will include physiological ecology, population ecology, species interactions, community ecology, succession and disturbance, ecosystem ecology, and biogeochemistry. Topics introduced in the lectures will be followed by in-class activities (and simulations) and discussions. For discussion sessions, I will suggest classic and recent research papers, and students will lead discussions based on those. The course will allow for reflection on uncertainty and variation in natural processes from individual behavior to ecosystem services. It is strongly recommended to take an evolutionary biology course before this, since this course will build on some of the modules covered in that course.

****Note: This course is being offered in Monsoon for third and fourth-year undergraduate students. The same course will be offered again in Monsoon 2026 with a larger enrollment cap***

 

Learning Outcomes

Towards the end of this course, students will be able to (a) understand how ecologists empirically study processes occurring at various scales and apply evolutionary thinking to these processes (b) integrate proximate and ultimate factors to understand natural processes (c) quantitatively synthesize ecological research (d) explore applications of ecological concepts such as conservation, landscape management.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Begon, M., Harper, J. L., & Townsend, C. R. Ecology. Individuals, populations and communities. Blackwell scientific publications.

Scott, G. (2009). Essential animal behavior. John Wiley & Sons.

Davies, N. B., Krebs, J. R., & West, S. A. (2012). An Introduction to behavioural ecology. John Wiley & Sons.

Immunology [BIO-3443/ BIO-6443] [BIO-3443/ BIO-6443-1]

Faculty Name
Rama Sundari Akondy [rama.akondy@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

Immunology is the study of the immune system - a complex network of organs, cells and proteins that protect the body from disease (except when it doesn’t!). It is an evolving field that is difficult to understand and memorize, making it a challenging subject to learn. This course focuses on introducing fundamental concepts of the vertebrate immune system rather than a comprehensive coverage of the subject. Students who want to grasp key concepts of how the immune system works should consider this course. This course can complement student interest / knowledge of cancer therapy, vaccine biology and infectious diseases.

Please contact the instructor if you have any specific learning needs / challenges.

Learning Outcomes
  • Identify components of the immune system. (Part 1)
  • Describe how diseased / infected cells are identified (Part 1)
  • Describe the key processes in initiation of an immune response. (Part 1)
  • Explain how the immune system is able to respond to so many different pathogens, even those that have not been encountered previously. (Part 2)
  • Describe some general and specialized immune mechanisms used to control pathogens. (Part 2)
  • Explain how immune cells move through the body. (Part 2)
  • Describe the fundamental principle behind some common techniques used in immunology research. (Part 3)
  • Describe how the immune system is able to discriminate non-self from self or harmful from harmless. (Part 3)
Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

- Specified chapters / sections of Kuby’s Immunology. 

- How the immune system works (Lauren Sompayrac)

- Vineeta Bal and Satyajit Rath articles in Resonance journal in the 1990s

- Other resources including figures from a primary paper may be used, videos or research highlights from journals or articles will be provided as needed.

Attendance

Attendance will be recorded, and regular participation is strongly encouraged, as peer learning and interaction are integral to this course.

  • Unannounced in-class assessments will not be repeated for students who are absent.
  • Students arriving more than five minutes late will be marked absent.
  • Students with three or fewer absences during the semester will receive one additional mark added to their final grade.
  • Up to three absences without documentation are allowed and cover mental health days, unexpected illness, sporting events, or other personal or academic contingencies.
  • Six or more undocumented absences will result in a 6% deduction from your final grade.

courseTitle: Studies in Film: Bollywood and Gender
description:
Studies in Film: Bollywood and Gender [ENG-3411] [ENG-3411-1]

Faculty Name
Geetanjali Chanda [geetanjali.chanda@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

Bombay cinema, affectionately called “Bollywood” has become the background music to our lives, whether as innocent entertainment or ‘time pass’. However, we often overlook Bollywood’s serious intent and strong ideological underpinnings. Right from its inception, with Dadasaheb Phalke’s Raja Harishchandra (1913), it has shaped the public narrative in India.
 

While the themes of Hindi films have changed over the years --from the patriotic ‘Mother India’ to the sports-feminist ‘Dangal’, the presentation of nationalism, sports and sexualities may just be old wine in new bottles. We will examine these ideologies primarily through the lens of gender.
 

We will also explore how the language, fashion, music, dance, and social values embedded in Bollywood films are disseminated. International theoretical readings from ideas of nationalism, film, gender, class, and cultural studies, and literature from various parts of the world will underpin our discussions of Bombay’s film industry and our exploration of the values and ideologies embedded in apparently innocent entertainment.
 

One of the course’s goals is to recognize these themes and develop the analytical tools to effectively “read” a text/film, empowering us to identify and challenge mainstream norms.

[Please note –Supplementary readings and films may be assigned during the course of the semester. Film viewing is mandatory. Even if you have seen the film before it is important to see it again for this class and with a view to the topics and ideas being discussed. Please find a way to view the films on your own. Ashoka may not be able to arrange screenings.]

Learning Outcomes

Understanding the hidden messages of Bollywood films.

How do Bollywood films expose issues of nationalism and gender. 

Learning the language of Bollywood films.

Tracing the chronology of Bollywood films.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Participation In-class discussion is an essential requirement. This means listening as well as responding and reacting to the ongoing discussions about the readings. Your ability to raise issues and questions that occurred to you while you read the texts demonstrates your attention to the readings.

Written Assignments
A total of 3 short and 1 long paper. Please note that bibliographies and filmographies are essential. Please follow the correct format for including these. You could look up any site such as Purdue Owl, etc. You will be required to frame your own questions for each of the papers.

Broad Themes & List of Films [all films will be viewed outside of class time]

Nationalism

Mother India (1957)

Purab aur Paschim (1970)

Rang De Basanti (2006)

Aarakshan (2011)

Sexualities

Dilwale Dulhania Le Jayenge (1995)

Aligarh (2016)

Ek Ladki Ko Dekha Toh Aisa Laga (2019)

Sports

Chak De! India (2001)

Dangal (2017)

Saand ki Ankh (2019)

Mary Kom (2014)

Masculinities and Femininities

Father, Son and Holy War (1995)

Lipstick under my Burkha (2016)

description:
Chemical Basis of Life [BIO-2300/ BIO-6300] [BIO-2300/ BIO-6300-1]

Faculty Name
Sandeep Ameta [sandeep.ameta@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

Fundamental chemical principles govern the highly regulated biological systems and their environment. Therefore, to appreciate the complexity of biological systems, we must also examine them from a chemical perspective. This course aims to introduce basic chemistry concepts necessary for studying biological systems. The course is designed to provide students with a framework for understanding the fundamentals of chemistry, biomolecules, their interactions, and the underlying mechanisms. In addition, the course will also offer a glimpse of how various chemical entities and their interactions led to the transition from chemistry to biology. The first half of the course will cover the basics of chemical bonds, structures, chemical thermodynamics, reactions, equilibrium, and kinetics. The second half will teach about the basic building blocks constituting life (nucleic acids, lipids, carbohydrates, sugar, protein, and a few concepts of metabolism).

Learning Outcomes

During the course, students will be taught two broad aspects:

  • What are biological molecules made of?
  • How do these biomolecules interact, assemble, and get processed in the biological systems?

Within this broad theme, by the end of the course, we aim to have students become familiar with basic chemical concepts that are useful in biology. This includes an understanding of the basics of chemical bonds, solutions, chemical interactions, thermodynamics, chemical reactions, chemical kinetics, enzyme kinetics, binding kinetics, biomolecules, and their function in biology. Students will also be familiarized with how these biomolecules are synthesized and maintained in the body. Additionally, through this course, students should be able to evaluate and make connections between the key chemical components of life and how these components can interact within the biological systems.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

The course content will be prepared from multiple sources, which will be sufficient to understand. However, the following books can be referred to for additional knowledge:

  • Introductory Chemistry, A Foundation by Zumdahl & Decoste
  • Lehninger Principles of Biochemistry by David L. Nelson, Michael M. Cox. Publisher: W. H. Freeman (6th Ed).
  • Biochemistry Voet, D., Voet, J.G. Publisher: Wiley; 3 Ed.

In addition, lectures as reading material and some notes will also be circulated.

Chemical Basis of Life [BIO-2300/ BIO-6300] [BIO-2300/ BIO-6300-2]

Faculty Name
Kavita Agarwal [kavita.agarwal@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

This course introduces the fundamental concepts of chemistry that are essential for understanding how molecules drive and regulate biological processes. Students will start with the basics of atomic structure and chemical bonding, then explore the key classes of biological molecules—nucleic acids, lipids, carbohydrates, and proteins. The course emphasizes how these molecules come together to form the complex structures and systems found in living organisms. Core principles such as thermodynamics, chemical reactions, equilibrium, pH, and reaction kinetics will be discussed in the context of biological examples, helping students connect chemistry to life science.

Learning Outcomes

By the end of the course, students will develop a foundational understanding of biomolecules, their chemical properties, interactions, and the role of chemistry in governing biological processes.

Students should be able to:

1. Describe the chemical composition and structure of key biological molecules.

2. Explain how biomolecules store, transmit, and process biological information.

3. Analyze how the structure of biomolecules relates to their specific functions within living systems.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

1. Lehninger Principles of Biochemistry David L. Nelson, Michael M. Cox. Publisher: W. H. Freeman

2. Biochemistry Voet, D., Voet, J.G. Publisher: Wiley; 3 Ed.

Soft- Matter Physics [PHY-4720/ PHY-6720 ] [PHY-4720/ PHY-6720 -1]

Faculty Name
Gautam Iqbal Menon [gautam.menon@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

This  course will provide an introduction to soft condensed matter physics, the phenomena, the physics underlying such materials, the experiments that inform us about them and the insightful theoretical ideas that enable us to make sense of them.

Although standard condensed matter physics/solid state physics courses might leave you with the impression that most, if not all, materials are (a) solids and (b) crystalline,  this is plainly untrue.  Milk (a colloid), plastic (a polymer melt), the stuff that covers your cells (a membrane), Sonepat air in November (an aerosol), plasticine (a viscoelastic solid),  oil extraction (fluid in a porous medium), LC displays (nematic liquid crystals), sand piles (granular media), ketchup (a yield stress material) as well as many other examples, are ubiquitous in our daily lives. But these are neither solid nor crystalline. Instead they flow,  respond in non-linear ways to perturbations and organize in fascinating and unexpected ways.

What ideas might unite such disparate phenomena? I will concentrate on the importance of thermal fluctuations and Brownian motion, the relevance of entropy, ideas of scaling behaviour, coarse-grained models, emergence, phase transitions, ideas of renormalization and the importance of topological defects.

I plan to cover (most of) the following:

1) Introduction to soft condensed matter: Length, time and energy scales, diffusion and related properties, examples, stress tensor, basics of statistical mechanics

2) Fluids and their description, viscosity

3)  Colloids and their interactions

4) What is measured, scattering experiments, response and correlation functions

5) Polymer physics, random and self-avoiding walks, polymer solutions, phase separation, biological examples

6) Liquid crystals: nematics, smectics, cholesterols and discotics

7) Membranes, curvature elasticity, osmotic pressure, measurements

8) Dynamical properties: fluctuation dissipation relation, response functions, viscoelasticity

9) Special topics: Granular media, active systems, glasses

Learning Outcomes

At the end of this course, you will have a overall broad view of this field and the ability to understand what's interesting and current, in addition to being able to carry out  basic and intermediate-level calculations.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Recommended background reading, but I will teach most of what I require in class.

1) Soft Matter Physics: Masao Doi

2) Principles of Condensed Matter Physics by P. M. Chaikin, T. C. Lubensky

3) Scaling Concepts in Polymer Physics by Pierre Gilles de Gennes

4) Structured fluids by Thomas Witten

5) Fluid Mechanics: Course of Theoretical Physics - Vol. 6 by Lev Landau

 

Attendance

I expect 100% attendance. If you need to be absent, please email me and the TF before the class. It would help if you provided a reason, even if brief.

Excused absence(s) are not applicable in this course lecture.
Additional excused absence(s) are not applicable for sportspersons in this course lecture.
Additional Comments:

I expect 100% attendance. If you need to be absent, please email me and the TF before the class. It would help if you provided a reason, even if brief.

Concepts in Organic Chemistry [CHM-1101] [CHM-1101-1]

Faculty Name
Deepak Asthana [deepak.asthana@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

About the course:

Chemistry teaches the art of creating new molecules, new materials, compounds that never existed. A small modification in chemical structure results in entirely new sets of properties. Bonded atoms form molecule and molecules undergos chemical reaction to form a new molecule. This course offers an introductory level understanding of various processes that take place in organic chemical reactions. Course structure is designed to refresh your chemistry knowledge from your school and to prepare you for your journey towards becoming an expert. It will provide better understanding of all the key concepts that you may require to solve the puzzles of chemical bonding and reactions.

The world of chemistry, and especially organic chemistry, might look scary. However, if fundamental rules and some basic principles are understood, most things start becoming obvious events. Concept of electronegativity, resonance, conjugation, hybridisation, steric effects, and aromaticity are key in explaining the number of complexities found organic chemistry.  

The first question that one might ask is why atoms form molecules, and once they have come close to each other, what keeps them intact. What are the factors that decide the path and the fate of any chemical reaction? The purpose of this course is to make sure that your journey into the realm of organic reactions and all those rule exceptions is more enjoyable!

Course Contents/Topics:

Stereochemistry of simple straight chain and cyclic alkanes

  • Conformational nomenclature: eclipsed, staggered, gauche, syn and anti; dihedral angle, torsion angle
  • Energy barrier of rotation and relative stability of conformers
  • Conformational analysis of ethane, propane, n-butane, and 2-methylbutane; cyclohexane and cyclopentane
  • Geometrical isomerism: cis–trans, syn-anti, and E/Z notations with C.I.P rules.

Organic Acids and Bases

  • Hybridisation, Inductive effects, Hyperconjugation, Mesomeric effects, and Steric effect and their effect on acidity/basicity
  • Concept of pKa and pKaH, effect of structure, substituent and solvent on acidity and basicity; proton sponge

Addition and Elimination Reactions

  • Elimination reactions: formation of alkenes and alkynes; mechanisms, reactivity, regioselectivity and stereoselectivity
  • Addition Reactions of alkenes and alkynes: Mechanism, reactivity, regioselectivity (Markownikoff and anti-Markownikoff addition) and stereoselectivity

Interconversion of functional groups

  • Oxidation of alcohols to form aldehyde/ketone & carboxylic acids
  • Oxidation and reduction of aldehydes to form carboxylic acids & alcohols
  • Conversion of carboxylic acid into acid chlorides, esters, amides and reduction to alcohols

 

Learning Outcomes
  • Students will develop understanding about the factors that make an organic compound acidic or basic. Strength of organic acids and bases will be studied in details.    
  • Electronic and steric factors basically control the behavior of a molecule in any chemical reaction. A clear understanding of electronic and steric effects enables us to predict several chemical properties. 
  • Will study the fact that why some system exists in a particular conformation. What makes a specific geometric arrangement more stable than the other. 
  • Addition and elimination reactions will be studied.
  • Will learn the various oxidation & reduction reactions that lead to inter-conversion of various functional groups such as alcohol to aldehyde or acid etc.
Requirements (Reading List and other materials)
  • Organic Chemistry by Jonathan Clayden, Nick Greeves and Stuart Warren.
  • Advanced Organic Chemistry: Part A: Structure and Mechanisms by Francis A. Carey and Richard J. Sundberg.
  • Interested in studying more about atomic orbitals: Principles of Atomic Orbitals by N. N. Greenwood
  • Organic Chemistry by Morrison & Boyd.
  • Organic Chemistry, Vol-1, by I L Finar.

100%

Additional excused absence(s) are not applicable for sportspersons in this course lecture.
Additional Comments:

100%

Introduction to Critical Thinking [CT-0001] [CT-0001-3]

Faculty Name
Arpita Das [arpita.das@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

In this course, you will develop and rehearse the habits that are essential to the development of a critical mind: reading, writing, speaking, listening and - of course - thinking. You will engage with a variety of source materials and understand how to ask questions that extend and enrich your understanding -- of situations, texts, institutions and people. You will explore the distinctness of academic research and writing, and participate in an active knowledge community constituted by your peers. By the close of the course, you will have a clearer understanding of what it means to be a scholar in an academic setting, and a keener sense of your own processes of learning, thinking and writing.

The theme this semester is Environmentalism Desi-Style where we read writings by Vandana Shiva, Amita Baviskar, Mahesh Rangarajan, Nagaraj Adve, Arpitha Kodiveri,  examine miscellaneous news reports, social media posts, and opinion pieces, and watch short films, videos and reels together to explore how environmentalism might mean different things for different people in South Asia, and how it has different ramifications in our part of the world than it does in the West. All reading, viewing material will be provided via Google Classroom.

Most importantly, our classroom will be a safe space for discussion, debate and constructive disagreements. 

I like my classes to be as interactive and discussive as possible. All the same, if you feel unsure or diffident about speaking up in class, please do not worry; there will be many ways in which I can continue to get a sense of how you feel about various things under discussion, via the weekly blog, other written submissions, and our chats during office hours.

Learning Outcomes

Reading:

1. Breaking down texts into identifiable parts.

2. Making patterns and connections across texts

3. Building reading stamina and the ability to select texts

4. Understanding textual context, genre and source material and documenting these via strategic note-making.

Writing 

1. Developing the craft of outlining, revising, editing

2. Applying form, voice, style, tone to affect writing

3. Developing logical, coherent, structured writing

4. Using explanatory, narrative and justificatory writing

Thinking

1. Practising converting thoughts into words

2. Narrowing down a curiosity or thought into a question

3. Constructing and developing a reasoned argument

4. Engaging meaningfully with multiple perspectives

Speaking-Listening

1. Aiming for confidence, clarity, coherence 

2. Practising and harnessing audience engagement 

3. Developing active and respectful listening to others 

4. Engaging meaningfully with ongoing discussions

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

You can expect to do regular reading (of academic texts and wider materials) in this course. These will be specified on a weekly basis on the schedule at the end of this outline. In addition, you can expect to write consistently, participate in giving and taking feedback, and work on medium-term projects both individually and in collaboration with your course mates. All reading material will be provided via Google Classroom.

3 additional excused absence(s) are allowed for sportspersons in this course lecture.

Introduction to Critical Thinking [CT-0001] [CT-0001-22]

Faculty Name
Varun Andhare [varun.andhare@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

'Introduction to Critical Thinking', or ICT courses, are meant to offer various pathways towards fostering habits of thinking and communication for first-year undergraduate students at Ashoka. In this ICT course, we shall do so by developing said habits through intensive, iterative processes of reading and writing over the course of twelve weeks. In so doing, we will both adapt to the demands of university-level argumentative writing and learn to use it in expressive ways — formulating original arguments and nurturing an appreciation for writing as both a functional and aesthetic extension of the self.

This semester, we will largely spend our time studying literary, academic and pop-culture texts relating to the theme of 'Content'. As consumers and participants within the economy of content online, an increasingly significant chunk of work and leisure in the 21st century appears to be mediated by the presence of this ephemeral, shapeless, yet instantly recognisable facet of modern life. This begs some fundamental questions we shall explore in class: What are the social forces which shape our relationship to the content we consume? How do we read a social media like a text? What kind of presence does and should content exert in our lives? And how do we make sense of the increasing proliferation of AI-generated content in everyday life?

We will tether these efforts to another set of more urgent questions: How does content inform your sense of self as newly enrolled students at Ashoka University? What do we make of life within and outside its walls? And how do we learn to read questions of power into these fundamental elements of daily life?

It is important to note, however, that the emphasis of this course will be not on providing students with expertise on any particular theme but rather the processes and practice of academic argumentation itself — it is through the theme that we will achieve these aims. To that end, students can expect the latter half of the semester in particular to be heavily oriented towards the research of their term paper, which will be discussed and assessed over multiple stages and rounds of feedback, and will be based on a series of prompts that will borrow from ideas brought up in our course readings.

Learning Outcomes

Reading

1. Breaking down texts into identifiable parts.

2. Making patterns and connections across texts

3. Building reading stamina and the ability to select texts

4. Understanding context, genre and source material

Writing 

1. Developing the craft of outlining, revising, editing

2. Applying form, voice, style, tone to affect writing

3. Developing logical, coherent, structured writing

4. Producing different kinds of writing (narrative, argumentative etc)

Research

1. Narrowing down a curiosity into a question

2. Identifying credible sources for study

3. Reflecting on  method and organising the research process

4. Handling multiple sources or an archive

Communication

1. Aiming for confidence, clarity, coherence in speaking

2. Practising and harnessing audience engagement 

3. Developing active and respectful listening to others 

4. Engaging meaningfully with ongoing discussions

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

An extensive reading list of class readings and other recommended readings will be made available to you in the first week of the semester. 

You do not need to have any specic kind of training in order to do an ICT course. Nor is any ICT course geared towards preparing you specically for a career in a particular subject or eld. Rather, you can expect it to guide you in transition out of how you approached academic work in school to how you might approach it in a university setting, and to sharpen your understanding of what it means to be critical, questioning and deliberate in your approach to the world.

ICT is writing-intensive. You can expect to work on longer assignments (the Mid-Term and the End-Term essays) over multiple rounds of feedback, as well as shorter assignments through the semester. You will also need to rehearse regular habits of reading (of academic texts and wider materials) and responding (to prompts, or given materials).

The course is also purposely designed to facilitate peer and faculty interaction; a lot of what you take away from it will come from your peers and the degree to which we are able to come together as a community of writers and thinkers. Expect to be doing a fair amount of group-led field work (we did photo walks around Lodhi Garden and Khan Market last semester) as well as other tasks specifically premised on breaking you out of the comfort zone of the classroom. This will involve spending some money to get around the city. If you are a Financial Aid student and require prior intimation or support, please do get in touch so we can facilitate the process for you as smoothly as possible.

Attendance
Excused absence(s) are not applicable in this course lecture.
Additional excused absence(s) are not applicable for sportspersons in this course lecture.
Additional Comments:

This course does not have a minimum attendance requirement but operates on an honour-code with regards to absences. Students will need to communicate the reasons for their absences to the Peer Tutor and Instructor, and will be expected to keep up with the material discussed in class through the Peer Tutor or your peer buddies.

Mastering the Interview [MS-2111] [MS-2111-1]

Faculty Name
Tisha Srivastav [tisha.srivastav@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

MS 2111 MASTERING THE INTERVIEW
Course Description:
Whether you look at PR, Communication or journalism as media industries, knowing how to
interview well is a transferable media industry asset. Maybe you are a vlogger, making short Insta or
video chats or are just interested in building an informed conversation - this course is a practice-
based introduction to the art of interviewing as a specific media form. It collapses several worlds to
first explain the changing world of the interview – legacy news media, You Tube, audio interview-
based storytelling, community-building and exploring Generative AI. This course prepares you with
practical learnings to cut through the clutter, by mastering this media form.
 

Learning Outcomes

Developing curiosity towards your questions/interested subject area concretely.
Develop the skill in using your phone for media production and understanding how interviews aid
storytelling.
Understanding that asking questions matter as much as how you ask them.
In month two of the course, students in a group setting learn relevant tools and techniques to do an
audio interview.
In the final month of the course, students individually attempt to think through an audio-based show
using original interviews.
Alongside, the course offers critical scope in examining current industry practices in interviewing.
You also get to practice how to use and consider the possibilities (& limits) of several AI tools &
open-source apps in situations as varied as image creation & marginalized media access.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Classes 3 - 4:30 pm Monday Wednesday

Week on week break up
Week 1-4 The changing world of the interview as a media form
Week 5 – 9 Interview Practice in groups of two (audio) + With guest lectures by audio & in class workshop by voice specialists

Week 10-13 Production of an audio interview-based show (Individual)

Econometrics 2 [ECO-6402] [ECO-6402-1]

Faculty Name
Kanika Mahajan [kanika.mahajan@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

The course is designed to equip students with theoretical and practical tools for causal identification in empirical research. It builds on Econometrics I to cover advanced econometric methods, such as experiments, matching techniques, instrumental variables, panel data, differences-in-differences, and regression discontinuity designs, with the explicit aim of measuring causal relationships using real-world data. The problem sets will be data driven and students are expected to present and critically engage with academic papers and replicate published empirical studies.

Learning Outcomes

Homework problems will generally be based on data. Homework assessments will be submitted individually. Group discussions are allowed but plagiarism will be dealt with a fail grade on the assessment and on the course for repeated violation. STATA based assessments should be accompanied with proper outputs and explanations. Assignments must be submitted in time on google classroom. Late submission will not be graded. Cheating will be dealt with by a fail grade on the course.

Class Presentation: Students (individually or groups of 2 depending on enrollment in the course) will present and lead the class-discussion of an assigned paper. In addition to summarizing the paper, a key portion of the presentation will focus on “critiquing” the paper and considering possible extensions.

Class Participation: while there is no attendance requirement, class participation comprises a key part of the course. Students are expected to contribute to discussions on the assigned papers.

Replication:  Students will be required to work in teams of 2 or individually (depending on enrolment). You need to select a paper from any of these journals: American Economic Review (AER), the American Economic Journals (AEJ: Applied Economics, Economic Policy), Quarterly Journal of Economics (QJE), Journal of Development Economics (JDE), American Journal of Political Science. You can choose papers from other journals too if the datasets are available online. Their websites host data files for recent years and also the computer programs for the results obtained in the papers. Each team will need to select a paper and download the associated files to replicate the main regression models. The “do” and the “log” files will be required to be submitted by each team. Two teams cannot work on the same topic (so first come, first served will be the criteria). The teams will under replication analysis/results and present it in a 15-minute presentation about the paper and how the results were replicated will be answered by the team members.

Principles of Science [FC-0801] [FC-0801-1]

Faculty Name
Dipyaman Ganguly [dipyaman.ganguly@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

This foundation course will engage in discussions synthesizing three relevant dimensions of the Science-Visual art symbiosis, viz. a) how artistic endeavours for recording observations have enriched the scientific pursuit and shaped the epistemic landscape (for example, how sketches by anatomists, astronomers and naturalists enriched contemporaneous understanding about the natural world), b) how artistic imaginations have contributed to scientific contemplations and vice versa (from Leonardo to Heath Robinson’s caricatures), c) how aesthetics, in terms of morphogenesis and organismal behaviour as well as cognitive inclinations to art, emerged in the course of evolution (mate selection in the animal world and the neuroscience of visual aesthetics in humans).

Principles of Science [FC-0801] [FC-0801-2]

Faculty Name
Gautam Basu [gautam.basu@ashoka.edu.in] ,Kasturi Mitra [Kasturi.mitra@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

Almost all High School graduates have studied science in school.      However, invariably the science they studied mostly were about the products of science and not the process behind the product (discoveries or inventions), disconnected with the person(s) responsible for the discovery or the invention or the role of the society and funding. The aim of this course is to make students aware about how science is done. This will include how discoveries or inventions are made,  how society, including the media or the state, responds, how prizes are awarded (or not awarded) for discoveries, how the nature of science has changed from being the pursuit of isolated individuals to Big Science, where a large number of people collaborate worldwide, and how science can be used to understand global issues like  epidemics, climate change or the large scale environmental pollution, all immediate concerns for humanity at large.

This will be accomplished through lectures, readings, discussions, student   seminars on self-assigned topics and/or assigned by the instructors, interviewing scientists at Ashoka University after reading some of their select publications in primary journals, and by enacting a play (Oxygen by Carl Djerassi and Roald Hoffmann).

Learning Outcomes

At the end of the course, it is expected that students will be more aware of the process of science as a human pursuit, albeit special, that operates with tacit support from the society, and with far reaching implications of the inventions and discoveries, often beyond what the discoverer ever imagined. It will also inculcate scientific temperament and make the younger generation aware of global catastrophes that the planet currently faces like epidemics, climate change and environmental pollution.

Reading materials will be provided in class.

Principles of Science [FC-0801] [FC-0801-3]

Faculty Name
Shraddha Karve [shraddha.karve@ashoka.edu.in] ,Somak Raychaudhury [somak.raychaudhury@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

This course concerns the nature of Time and the important role it plays in our lives. It introduces the concept of age and time in the context of Physics and Astronomy- how Time is measured, its connection with Space, and why it moves in one direction, as well as the way Time is perceived in biological systems. Through this course we would be like to bring to the students our current understanding about the scale and age of the Universe, and how this knowledge has evolved; how biological systems including human body maintain temporal patterns; the impact of climate change and ecological damage on biological time and the evolution of survival strategies that require the understanding of past, present and future.

The course will start with a general introduction and historical perspective to the concept of time in our day-to-day life and in physics and in biology. We shall discuss the history of measurement of time and invention of clocks. Without involving much mathematics, the course will help students derive relationship between speed of light and time, space-time continuum, age of the universe, stars, earth etc. We would then follow concept of time in biology in the context of birth-growth-ageing-death. Seasonal variations in morphological and life-history traits as measurement of time, mechanism of timekeeping - biological clocks, circadian rhythms. We will also discuss the evolutionary time and the important concepts pertaining to our understanding of this such as generation time of different living beings. The course ends with discussions on human cognition and the concept of time: conceptual understanding of past, present and future.

The course is taught through lectures, discussions, flip-the-classroom mode (students making presentations on various related topics), reading books/watching movies and writing assignments.

Learning Outcomes

1.     Our current understanding about the scale and age of the Universe, and how this knowledge has evolved.

2.     Understanding how Astronomers and Geologists measure time and age, and how reliable these measurements are.

3.     Appreciation for different scales of time in biology: from timescales of biomolecules to the evolutionary timescale.

4.    Understanding of interdependencies in biological timescales.

Principles of Science [FC-0801] [FC-0801-4]

Faculty Name
Sourav Pal [sourav.pal@ashoka.edu.in] ,Vidya Dnyaneshwar Avasare [vidya.avasare@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

Course description:

This course throws a light on the principles of science and central role of chemistry in science. Historically, chemistry has been focusing on the variation of matter, their properties and how these matters can undergo interesting chemical transformations. The intriguing chemical and physical properties of these matters attract the attention of scientific community. Chemistry has been the building block of matters, small to large. Materials at different length scales will be addressed and how different pedagogies can explain matter at varying length scales

Therefore, in this course, we will discuss about principles of science involved in the deeper understanding of matters (from quantum dots to supramolecular arrangements) at different length scales.

Focus will be on concepts and units of lengths, change of paradigm and pedagogy as small molecules become larger molecules, polymers, biomolecules, transition from quantum mechanics to classical mechanics at a pedagogical level. General principles of thermodynamics and kinetics will be highlighted as basic principles of science.

At a chemical length scale, periodic table of elements, their electronic structure and properties, introduction to organic chemistry as a great utility in science from building blocks of life to renewable energy, healthcare, medicines, and materials with value-addition in society will be discussed to understand logic of chemical reactivity.

Syllabus:

Principles of Science: Falsifiability, Persimony, Accuracy, Precision, Ethics, Communication

Length scales in science: Pedagogic view of Classical to Quantum transition as sizes of the systems become smaller; Galaxy to subatomic length scales; Length scale of chemistry

Chemistry as a central science; how chemical transformations describe molecules to materials

Behaviour of materials at different length scales: Bird’s eye view

States of Matter

Chemical Thermodynamics- Drive of a chemical reaction

Chemical kinetics- How fast the drive takes place

Electronic structure of atoms- Concept of orbitals

Mole concept in chemistry

Periodic Table- An introduction

Organic chemistry as a utility science

Role of chemistry in Renewable Energy, Healthcare, Climate change

Chemical Bond; hybridisation

Reactivity; electrophilic and nucleophilic

IUPAC nomenclature and simple organic reactions

Chemical structures through model building

Learning Outcomes

Foundations of science and chemistry

Principles of Science [FC-0801] [FC-0801-5]

Faculty Name
Sujan Kumar Sengupta [sujan.sengupta@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

The Planet Earth: Its status in the Universe, potential threats and the ultimate fate

A formidable combination of astronomical and geological conditions has made it possible for the Earth to harbour life on it. But there are many catastrophic events in the space that may destroy life, even the planet which in the vast cosmic arena appears as a mote of dust suspended in a beam of sunlight and floating in the vast emptiness of space. Search for extra-terrestrial life has taught us an important lesson that our world, mother Earth is an extremely rare place in our galaxy and possibly the only planet that has the required astrophysical and geological conditions for harbouring life. Even if there are other planets similar to the Earth wherein life may exist, the number of such planets in the vast galaxy is extremely small and so we are alone at least within a radius of few hundreds of light years. This course will unfold the fact that our home, the planet Earth is so special yet so vulnerable, so crowded yet so lonely, so common yet so unique, so insignificant yet so great! 

        The following topics will be covered in the whole course: 

(i)    Our address in the Universe, the hierarchy in the structure of the visible Universe – super clusters of galaxies, clusters of galaxies, galaxies, the Milky Way Galaxy, stars: the building blocks of galaxies, The Sun and the Solar System. 

(ii)   Birth of the Sun and its planets including the Earth. A brief history of the solar planets

(iii)  We are made of star dust – the origin of heavy elements including carbon the building block of organic molecules. 

(iv)   Life is a puzzle: Definition of life- its main functions: Metabolism, replication and evolution by natural selection.  Origin of life on the Earth.  

(v)   Evolution of life in a changing Earth – the first, second and the third atmosphere of the Earth, formation of the Oceans, Continents and forest. The ecological system. 

(vi)  The potential threats to the Earth – Astronomical, Geological and Man-made threats. Extinction of life in the past. 

(vii) The natural protection for life – The extremely rare combination of astronomical and geological coincidences that has enabled life on the Earth to survive and evolve.  

(viii)  Are we alone? Search for extra-terrestrial biosignature and techno-signature. 

(ix)    The evolution of the Sun – from a faint young star to a red giant and a changing environment of the Earth – from habitable to uninhabitable planet. 

(x)     The death of the Sun and the fate of its planets.         

       

Learning Outcomes

Basic knowledge on the formation of the Sun and the Solar system alongwith the planet Earth; Earth's evolution and ecology; Origin, evolution and extinction of life; Future of planet Earth and life on it.  

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

(1) Physics of the Earth by Frank D Stacey and Paul M Davis, Cambridge University Press

(2) Handbook of Astrobiology edited by Vera M. Kolb, CRC Press

(3) Pale Blue Dot : A Vision of the Human Future in Space by Carl Sagan , Ballantine Books Inc, NY

(4) Worlds Beyond Our Own : The Search for Habitable Planets by Sujan Sengupta, Springer International

Literature and the World [FC-0701] [FC-0701-2]

Faculty Name
Rita Kothari [rita.kothari@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

Families shape us, form us, for better or worse. How does literature talk
about this institution? Does the world of imagination tell us deeper truths about the family—its
potential to define, destroy, and heal? This course takes texts from across the world and focuses
on this relation between the individual and the family; the joy and burden of kinship; the
networks of relations that bind and set us free. In the process, we also hope to gain an
understanding of literature as an institution, and its role in telling stories that are both real and
imaginary.

Primary Texts:
1. Jane Austen, Pride and Prejudice
2. Amitabha Bagchi, Half the Night is Gone
3. Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie, Purple Hibiscus
4. Attia Hosain, Sunlight on a Broken Column
5. Daya Pawar, Baluta
6. Dharamvir Bharati, Andha Yug: The Age of Darkness
7. Mahesh Dattani, Dance Like a Man
8. Sophocles, Oedipus Rex
9. Alison Bechdel, Fun Home

Secondary Texts (excerpts):

1. Menon, Nivedita. Seeing like a feminist. Penguin UK, 2012.
2. Sarkar, Tanika, and Urvashi Butalia, eds. Women and the Hindu right: A collection of essays.
Kali for Women, 1995.
3. Uberoi, Patricia. Freedom and destiny: Gender, family, and popular culture in India. Oxford
University Press, USA, 2006.
4. Kakar, Sudhir. "The Inner World: A Psycho-Analytic Study of Childhood and Society in
India." (1978).
5. Sattar, Arshia. Maryada: Searching for Dharma in the Ramayana. Harper Collins, India, 2020.
Course Philosophy:
A key to a robust and fulfilling class experience is that the instructor and students have a
common understanding on what the course is about, i.e., not only what it will do, but also what it
will not include or focus upon. The instructor will make sure that this understanding of the
course, as a whole and in parts, is communicated. However, feel free to approach us in case of
any questions and discussions that may arise in your mind. Do note that the course will proceed
sequentially so that you have time to read all the texts; however, the duration spent on each text
may sometimes vary depending upon the nature of interest and involvement we feel.
Students are expected to procure and read all the primary texts. Secondary text excerpts and
articles will be made available to the class. They will inform our reading of the primary texts, but
we may not have the time to discuss each and every piece in class.
The instructor likes to be interrupted; so please do not wait for cues to participate in
class—instead, view the classroom experience as an adda (without food, of course!). Allow room
for both focused and meaningful digressions.

Literature and the World [FC-0701] [FC-0701-3]

Faculty Name
Saikat Majumdar [saikat.majumdar@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

What is liberal arts education? Is it identified with particular subjects, or a certain style of teaching and learning? This course will offer an introduction to liberal arts education as it might be practiced in a literature classroom for non-specialists, including students who may major in any subject at Ashoka – a be it literature, economics, or biology. Our focus will be on English as a world language, and particularly one of global literature. How did the British Empire shape a global terrain of colonial modernity? How did that modernity merge with Anglo-American globalization of the twentieth and twenty-first centuries? How did this create the English-speaking and English-reading worlds, and how did it turn English into a

language of world literature? We will examine the transnational trajectory of this diverse and diffuse body of writing, including work from spaces with vastly different histories – the colonies in sub-Saharan Africa, the Caribbean and South Asia, and the hard-to-classify context of South Africa.

Evaluation: Attendance: 10%; Group presentation: 20%; Midterm: 30%; Final Exam: 40%; DS Attendance: 10%

Literature and the World [FC-0701] [FC-0701-5]

Faculty Name
Vivek Venkitaraman Narayan [v.v.narayan@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

Literature lives in a strange place where the word meets the world: here, the fantastical can seem familiar and the mundane may seem bizarre. The act of reading allows us to imagine the strange worlds of others as if we lived in them, and, equally, to reimagine our everyday worlds as if we viewed them through unfamiliar eyes. This imaginative encounter with otherness—other people, other perspectives, other places, and other worlds—lies at the heart of the literary experience. 

In South Asia, the literary encounter with otherness is inextricable from the worldly encounters of caste. The aesthetics of caste inform our literary sensibilities, the social experiences of caste frame the world we inhabit, and the everyday performances of caste shape our bodies. In short, the encounters that create our aesthetic, social, and embodied experiences—between the word and the world, between the self and the other, and between the real and the imagined—are all entangled with caste.   

This course will examine the relationship between literature and the world by focussing on the aesthetic, social, and embodied experiences of caste. We will ask: What can caste and literature tell us about each other? What do the intersections of caste and literature tell us about the world? How does our experience of the world inform and inflect our responses to literary representations of caste? And, perhaps most important, how will this kind of literary experience help us inhabit the world? We will read fiction, nonfiction, poems, and plays to explore what literature can reveal about others, ourselves, and a world organized by caste.

Learning Outcomes

Upon successfully completing this course, students will be able to:

  • Articulate a critical response to literary texts representing caste.
  • Examine the relationship of literary texts to their worldly contexts. 
  • Analyze the affordances of form and genre in literary texts.  
  • Demonstrate the significance of form and genre for literary representations of caste.  
  • Develop a critical approach to caste informed by literary theories and, equally, to literature informed by theories of caste.  
Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

We will likely read fiction by M. M. Vinodini, A. K. Ramanujan, C. Ayyappan, Ajay Navaria, U. R. Ananthamurthy, Bama, Devanooru Mahadeva, Baburao Bagul, R. K. Narayan, and T. K. C. Vaduthala; nonfiction by B. R. Ambedkar, M. N. Srinivas, Louis Dumont, M. S. S. Pandian, Laura Brueck, Aniket Jaaware, Gopal Guru and Sundar Sarukkai, Urmila Pawar, Yashica Dutt, Sharmila Rege, Lovely Stephen, Challappalli Swaroopa Rani, Siddhalingaiah, and Arvind Malagatti; poems by Meena Kandasamy, A. K. Ramanujan, S. Joseph, Vijila Chirappad, Prakash Jadhav, and Sukirtharani; as well as plays by Girish Karnad and K. A. Gunasekaran. This is a tentative list subject to change. All texts will be uploaded to the course folder as soft copies.

Great Books [FC-0601] [FC-0601-1]

Faculty Name
Arpita Das [arpita.das@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

Texts that act as political beacons are the focus of this course. Each one is a stellar example of the genre we know as narrative non-fiction, and each one has been cited and referred to by generations of scholars, practitioners, activists, and students for whom equity and social justice are of importance. Over time, these texts have taken on a talismanic importance and yet, they age well with the times and remain supremely relevant. Is that something to celebrate in terms of the prescience of the texts themselves, or to lament in terms of how the world does not seem to become a more equitable place even over the decades since these texts were read for the first time. 

The texts we will be reading: Jotirao Phyle, Slavery; B. R. Ambedkar, Annihilation of Caste; Frantz Fanon, Wretched of the Earth, James Baldwin, 'Here Be Dragons'; Jeanette Winterson, Why Be Happy When You Can Be Normal; Susan Abulhawa, 'Memories of an un-Palestinian story, in a can of tuna''.

Learning Outcomes

Studying textss from different cultures, chronologies, disciplines, and languages, the Great Books course introduces students to multiple ways of thinking and being in the world. As the semester progresses, students are encouraged to ask questions of the books or fragments of books they are reading. The intent is to familiarise students with how to engage with texts and not be intimidated by them, and in so doing, opening a door for students, inviting them into new landscapes of ideas, narratives, arguments, and experiences.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

The texts we will be reading: Jotirao Phyle, Slavery; B. R. Ambedkar, Annihilation of Caste; Frantz Fanon, Wretched of the Earth, James Baldwin, 'Here Be Dragons'; Jeanette Winterson, Why Be Happy When You Can Be Normal; Susan Abulhawa, 'Memories of an un-Palestinian story, in a can of tuna''.

All texts will be provided on Google Classroom.

We will read select works by Nobel Laureates from around the world, works that have originated in various languages, cultures, histories, geographies, and systems of thoughts and beliefs, mediated by individual talent. Great Books [FC-0601] [FC-0601-5]

Faculty Name
S Satish Kumar [s.kumar@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

This course seeks to reflect on care and love both conceptually and experientially. What does it mean to love and care for oneself and for others? What allows us to love and care? What prevents us from caring and loving ourselves and others? What forces—personal, interpersonal, or collective and communal—regulate, prescribe and even prohibit experiences and expressions of love.

Our primary goal in the course is to work towards developing a critical and comprehensive language around understanding care and love as the basis for any and all configurations of relationalities that both make and unmake our senses of being in the world. Beginning our journey with selections from The Symposium by Plato, verses from the Gatha Sattasai, and poetry from the Akam repertoire of Sangam literature, we will make our way through more contemporary iterations and meditations on caring and loving such as, Roland Barthes’ A Lover’s Discourse and Ocean Vuong’s On Earth We Are Briefly Gorgeous. All along the way we will be reflecting on and attempting to problematize “traditional” and “normative” structures within which care and love are usually understood and experienced.

Learning Outcomes

To understand representations of caring and loving in literature and culture.

To contemplate and reflect on caring and loving experientially and critically.

To develop a critical lexicon for addressing the ethics of caring and loving.

Great Books [FC-0601] [FC-0601-6]

Faculty Name
Alexander Robert Phillips [alexander.phillips@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

In this course we will critique the notion of "greatness" as such relative to what it suggests both about The Human and about processes of canon formation, i.e. what makes a "Great Book." We will do so by looking at the figure of Prometheus. In Greek mythology, Prometheus stole fire from the gods and gave it to humans, for which he was tied to a mountain while an eagle ate at his liver. As an adjective, "Promethean" connotes forward-thinking, activeness, striving, defiance of whatever inexorable forces lie beyond our control, and domination. Prometheus is thus an archetype who appears again and again in literary history. But in this class we will also read texts that think about the non- or un-Promethean, texts that are decidedly not "great" insofar as they thematize the small or present us with characters who relate to the world in ways very different from all we associate with Prometheus.

Performing Arts Practices [PA-1009] [PA-1009-1]

Overview

Taught by Justin McCarthy

This course guides students through a multiplicity of performance practices existing on the subcontinent. These practices include the locally specific, the socially specific, the traditional, the hereditary, the rural, the nomadic, the urban, the pan-Indian, as well as those practices with discernible connections to performance conventions beyond the specifically Indian context. An important premise of this course is that music, dance and theatre are three strands of an intertwined whole. Their closely related cultural, social and aesthetic histories will constitute the core material to be studied. While acknowledging a cultural corpus often possessing obvious mutual affinities, this course will give pride of place to the wide varieties of performance practices found in India and the divergent histories accompanying them.  Though mainly academic, the course can contain performance elements depending on the students’ inclinations and their performative relationship to the material being studied.

There is no prerequisite for this course.

This course is mandatory for all students wanting to pursue  a minor in performing arts.

Poetics in Indian Dance [PA-2011/ ENG-2601/ PHI-2871] [PA-2011/ ENG-2601/ PHI-2871-1]

Overview

Taught by Navtej Johar

This course, focused on poetics in Indian dance, will include both practice and theory. In the practice session we will create scene work with text, mostly the amorous poetry that is used in Indian dance. The underlying intent of the practice sessions will be to make the body sensorially available to the ambiance of the character’s world, so that performance becomes a pleasurably embodied experience for both the performer and the viewer.  The theoretical component of the course will be structured around the bhava-rasa theory of the Natya Shastra. It will discuss the emotional palate constituting interiority as per the bhava model, the importance of the pleasurable “taste” of aesthetic experience or rasa  in offering resolve to and repose in the viewer, and the critical role of the audience in co-orchestrating the aesthetic experience.

courseTitle: Introduction to Biology 3: Molecular Genetics and Molecular Biology
description:
Introduction to Biology 3: Molecular Genetics and Molecular Biology [BIO-2201] [BIO-2201-1]

Faculty Name
Kasturi Mitra [Kasturi.mitra@ashoka.edu.in] ,Sougata Roy [sougata.roy@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

How is an organism’s structure and function regulated? The answer to this question lies within the inherited DNA. Genetics have evolved phenomenally since Mendel first introduced the concept of genes during the mid-1800s. Today genetics is used in all phases of life from food to medicines, new discoveries tend to manipulate genetics not only to diagnose and find better cure for deadly diseases like cancer but also to design smart plants and microbes to enhance the quality and quantity of food and secondary metabolites such as biofuel. Hence a thorough knowledge of genetics is an absolute requirement for biologists to comprehend the complexity of living organisms.

Specifically, you will learn in detail about the structure, function and regulation of chromosomes and genes Variation in phenotype is important for evolution. This is usually accompanied by underlying genetic variation. We will therefore study how genetic variation comes about, and focus on some model organisms used for genetic studies. Subsequently we will learn about the inheritance of complex traits and population genetics. This course will provide basic as well as advanced understanding of the concepts and tools that are used in molecular genetics and molecular biology. Then we will discuss how to evaluate and design key cutting-edge research in the field of molecular biology.

Learning Outcomes

This course will provide a basic understanding of the concepts of molecular biology and build the platform to learn advanced molecular biology approaches and their application. You will learn in detail about the following:

Central dogma of molecular biology and its variations in life.

Structure, function and regulation of chromosomes and genes at the molecular level.

Actions of the core molecular players in DNA replication, gene transcription and mRNA translation, DNA repair and recombination.

Basic principles of gene regulation.

Fundamental of genetic engineering.

description:
Understanding Structure and Function [BIO-3006/ BIO-6006] [BIO-3006/ BIO-6006-1]

Faculty Name
Dilip Kumar [dilip.kumar@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

Have you ever visited a key maker? You must have seen lots of premade keys with unique shapes and sizes. However, only certain keys might work for a particular lock. But what makes a particular key functional for one lock but not for the others? It entirely depends on the structural complementarity of lock and key. Similarly, in Biology, thousands of such keys for specific locks mediate numerous biological functions based on their shapes, features, and their interactions with the surroundings. This course will discuss how these biological keys or biomolecules are structured for their specific functions. Through this course, we will be asking some of these questions. We will also be visiting various biophysical techniques that are used to measure and visualize biomolecular interactions.

Learning Outcomes

Learning Outcomes: At the end of the course, the students will have clarity and understanding of the role of structure in the functions of biological macromolecules. The precise learning outcomes

of this course will be:

1. Students will be able to understand the basic chemistry behind the biological functioning of macromolecules.

2. We will also be discussing published research articles on related topics. This course will enable students to interpret the research articles and frame relevant questions related to the topic.

3. Through active participation, students will also enhance their communication and presentation skills.

 

Weekly learning outcomes:

W1: Basics of biomolecular interactions and how structure leads to function.

W2-W3: Details of building blocks of proteins

W4-W6: Structure and chemistry of lipids, carbohydrates, and Nucleic acids, and Mid-term presentation by PhD students

W7-W11: Methods for macromolecular structure determination and interaction analysis

W12: Macromolecular interactions and Paper presentations by PhD students in the last class of the semester

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

This module will be mostly based on research papers and reviews. The following books can be referred. In addition, reading material in the form of papers and notes will be circulated.

• Lehninger Principles of Biochemistry- 6th Ed. David L Nelson, Michael M Cox

• Biochemistry - Donald Voet, Judith G. Voet

• Molecular Biology of the Cell- Bruce Alberts, Alexander Johnson, Julian Lewis, Martin Raff, Keith Roberts, Peter Walter

Online resources: Atlas of the Bacterial and Archaeal Cell Structure (Catherine M. Oikonomou & Grant J. Jensen)
