courseTitle: Introduction to Biology II: Cell Biology
description:
Introduction to Biology II: Cell Biology [BIO-2214] [BIO-2214-1]

Faculty Name
Anup Padmanabhan [anup.padmanabhan@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

Cells are the fundamental unit of life. It carries out most of the physiological processes that are essential for its survival and propagation. Within the cell, each of these processes is accomplished by molecular machines. What are these processes, and how do these mini-machines carry out cellular functions? How are they assembled? How do these cellular machines know the right place and the right time to carry out appropriate functions? This course will emphasize the dynamics of these components in building cellular architecture.

Learning Outcomes

In this introductory Cell Biology course, essential cellular processes will be explored to understand how molecular machines carry out these functions.

The primary focus of this course will be on eukaryotic cells.  There are 3 lectures on prokaryotic cell biology to draw comparisons between prokaryotic and eukaryotic cellular processes to appreciate their similarities and differences.

By the end of this course, participants are expected to have a solid conceptual understanding of basic cellular mechanisms, the molecular machinery involved, and their functional regulation within a cell.

Through detailed discussions on cell biology methods and classical cell biology experiments, the participants should be able to read and interpret experimental data and appreciate the role of controls, and able to design cell biology experiments to test hypotheses.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

No prerequisites. 
Reading materials and references will be shared once the course begins. 

Attendance

Attendance will be taken, but it is not mandatory.  

Excused absence(s) are not applicable in this course lecture.

courseTitle: Introduction to General Relativity with Application to Cosmology
description:
Introduction to General Relativity with Application to Cosmology [PHY-4810/ PHY-6810] [PHY-4810/ PHY-6810-1]

Faculty Name
Kandaswamy Subramanian [kandaswamy.subramanian@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

Gravity is different from other fundamental forces. It can be incorporated as the property of spacetime geometry itself, instead of being described by  “charges” and “fields.” The best description of gravity is provided by the General Theory of Relativity which is a theory of spacetime geometry. The main aim of this course is to introduce the fundamental concepts of General Theory of Relativity and its applicationsa with special emphasis on modern cosmology.

Outline of the course:

Special Relativity Review, Principle of Equivalence and Gravity as Spacetime Geometry, Maths of Curved spacetime: Tensor algebra, Particle dynamics in curved spacetime, Connection and Covariant Derivative, Physics in curved spacetime, Space-time Curvature, Action for Gravity and Einstein equation, Energy momentum Tensors, Newtonian limit, Schwarchild Metric- Orbits-Black hole, Gravitational Waves.

Basic Cosmology: The Hubble Law, Geometry of the Universe, Friedmann Equations, Dark matter and Dark energy,  Primordial Nucleosynthesis, Cosmic microwave bacground,  Inflation, Structure formation int the universe.

Learning Outcomes

By the end of the course the student will have some appreciation of hravitation as space time gelometry and also its modern applications to astrophysics and cosmology

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Apart from my lecture notes some useful books are:

An Introduction to Relativity, Jayant V. Narlikar, Cambridge University Press

The Classical Theory of Fields, Volume 2, L. D. Landau and E. M. Lifschitz, Pergamon

Gravitation: Foundations and Frontiers, T. Padmanabhan, Cambridge University Press

An introduction to Einstein’s General Relativity by James B. Hartlle.

3 additional excused absence(s) are allowed for sportspersons in this course lecture.

description:
Probability and Statistics [MAT-2020/ CS-1209/ PHY-1208] [MAT-2020/ CS-1209/ PHY-1208-1]

Faculty Name
Debapratim Banerjee [debapratim.banerjee@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

This is a first course in probability theory where the students are expected to learn the foundations, basic concepts of probability theory and be able to solve problems. We shall also discuss some preliminary concepts and foundations of statistics. This course is the first step to take future advanced courses in probability and statistics.

Learning Outcomes

Frequency and axiomatic definition of probability, random experiments with equally likely finite outcomes, Inclusion exclusion principle. General finite sample spaces, infinite sample spaces.  Concept of probability spaces and construction of probability measures. Conditional probability, Bayes theorem, Independence of events. Random variable (discrete), probability mass function and distribution function. Examples: Bernoulli, Binomial, Poisson, Geometric distributions. Expectation and variance of a random variable, sum law and product law of expectation, moment generating functions. Random vector (discrete), joint distribution, Marginal distributions, joint moment generating functions, covariance, Multinomial distributions. Continuous random variables, density functions, distribution functions, expectation, variance, moment generating function, example: uniform, normal, and exponential. Continuous random vector, joint density function, joint distribution function, conditional density, example: multivariate normal. 

Inequalities: Markov, Chebyshev. Weak variant of law of large numbers, Central Limit Theorem (without proof). 

Descriptive statistics, Distribution of sampling statistics, Parameter Estimation and Hypothesis testing basics.

Simple linear regression with one regressor (only if time permits).

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

 Students are expected to have a strong background in permutation and combination and calculus. Hence, they should be comfortable with the course materials of Mathematics in 10+2 standard and MAT 1000: Calculus.

courseTitle: Hegemony, the United States, and the World
description:
Hegemony, the United States, and the World [IR-3020] [IR-3020-1]

Faculty Name
Quintijn Benjamin Kat [quintijn.kat@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

What do we mean when we use the term ‘hegemony’ in International Relations? How is it different from terms like ‘primacy’, ‘domination’, or ‘empire’? On what foundations did US hegemony rest during the ‘American century’, and what is left of it today? How, over the course of two hundred years, did the United States transition from being a middle power with modest military and economic means to a great power and then to the world’s sole superpower? And what lies ahead? Are we currently witnessing the end of the ‘US-led Liberal International Order’ and the ‘Pax Americana’, or will the United States retain or regain its predominance as it has done in earlier times of supposed US decline?

This course addresses such questions by combining an historical overview of US foreign policy with a survey of existing theories of hegemony in IR. First, it traces the rise to superpower status of the United States from the 19th century to the World Wars and the Cold War, ending with the ‘unipolar moment’ of the 1990s and the first two decades of the 21st century. We will discuss the foreign policies of different US leaders and analyse how these, in conjunction with changes to the global power balance, enabled US hegemony, and we will ask when and why this primacy came under threat and how the United States responded to such threats. Second, the course will acquaint students with various theoretical perspectives within IR concerning the concept of hegemony. We will discuss the presumed foundations of hegemony that have been identified by major hegemony theories and look into what each perceives may constitute sources of change in hegemonic order. An important objective of the course is to enable students to analytically assess the power, dominance and leadership of the United States in the past and present and to articulate theoretically informed opinions about US hegemony and the challenges it faces today.

Learning Outcomes
Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Any 1000-level IR course, preferably IR-1009.

Monetary Theory [ECO-3200] [ECO-3200-1]

Faculty Name
Arghya Bhattacharya [arghya.bhattacharya@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

What exactly is "money"? Is it simply something that we needed for trading? If so, then money would be a constraint - a thing without which trades can't happen. What about alternative trading arrangements like barter or credit? Why is barter, credit, or a system that keeps track of transfers, inferior to money? Why is fiat money Pareto superior to commodity money (gold, silver, etc.)? What causes inflation? What about banking - why do we need it? Are banks always welfare-improving? Why do banks fail? This course starts with a micro-founded approach to money using an overlapping generations model and discusses why money is not a constraint but an instrument that arises endogenously leading to welfare gains for the economy. Then we build on this model and go on to study the relationship between money and other institutions that issue/ use money - financial intermediation & banks, a model of bank risk and bank panic (Diamond-Dybvig model).

Time permitting and based on your collective interest & my expertise, we might cover other interesting topics in monetary economics such as national debt, fiscal theories of price level & inflation, pension systems, and/ or one or two MA/ Ph.D. level papers on money-related topics.

Learning Outcomes
Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Children’s Literature [ENG-4330] [ENG-4330-1]

Faculty Name
Geetanjali Chanda [geetanjali.chanda@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

What we read as children forms who we become and provides our first world view. This course provides an opportunity to critically assess the stories that shaped our understanding of morals, culture, and values, as well as those we will impart to future generations. In this discussion-oriented interactive course, we will read and review children’s books, examine the purposes of visual literacy, and write reviews on specific authors and illustrators. We will write our own children’s book to gauge all that we have learnt.

This course aims to examine how the books children read shape their outlook and emotional development. We will study the historical, creative, nurturing, emotional, and educational aspects of these forms of literature and their impact on us later in life. We will also consider why a study of children’s literature is important, and how it impacts pedagogies for children across borders.

            We will examine the views of multiple theoretical thinkers and texts in conjunction with actual children's literature. We will ask the important but often overlooked questions about this particular genre, mainly focusing on Indian and Western children’s literature. The purpose is not so much to compare these two cultural offerings, but to give us a taste of both. 

            We shall consider popular stories for children up to 12 years old, including Harry Potter & The Philosopher’s Stone, Amar Chitra Katha, Matilda, The Little Prince, Feluda and Mulan. At the same time, we will also study theoretical thinkers such as Jack Zipes, Seth Lerer, Paulo Freire, and Bruno Bettelheim to help us navigate the complex field of children’s literature in relation to issues of culture, religion, difference, gender, and sexuality.

We will unpack the didactic intent as well as the pleasure principle that might have prompted the writers. Authorial intent is, however, only one part of our study; the other part is to see how children and parents receive these stories. Children’s literature creates moral as well as national frameworks that help acculturate young people. In examining the genre of children’s literature, we will consider various sub-genres such as picture books, fairy tales, fables, and chapter books. 

Learning Outcomes

To understand the purpose and pleasures of childrens literature. 

To see the choronological development of childrens literature.

To explore the theories about  children's literature.

To write our own illustrated childrens book and then critique it to see what goes into the process of developing a children's book.

To explore the idea of visual litercy. 

To learn about and practice peer reviewing. 

 

 

 

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Below are the primary readings which you must have ordered before hand. Additional  readings may be added to this list . Other readings, especially picture books, can be seen in the library or online. 

Rushdie, Salman. Haroun and the Sea of Stories. London: Penguin (1990). 

de Saint Exupery, Antoine. The Little Prince [Translated by Richard Howard] (2000).

  Dahl, Roald. Matilda (1988). 

Chandra, Nandini. The Classic Popular: Amar Chitra Katha (1967-2007), Yoda Press (2008).

Lal, Ranjit. The Battle for No.19, Penguin India (2007).

Ray, Satyajit. The Mystery of the Elephant God.

Ruskin Bond: The Room on the Roof (1987)

Antoine de Saint Exupery. The Little Prince

Chosky, Stephen. Wonder. 2017. (film)

courseTitle: Visual and Material Cultures of the Himalayas
description:
Visual and Material Cultures of the Himalayas [VA-2006/ SOA-2215/ MS-3098] [VA-2006/ SOA-2215/ MS-3098-1]

Faculty Name
Latika Gupta [latika.gupta@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

Level: 1000/ 2000/ 3000

Prerequisites: None

This course focuses on the Western Himalayas to understand how visual and material cultures are intrinsically connected with the idea of ‘place’. We will look at how places, cultures and people are constructed through representations — visual and written — both by ‘outsiders’ as well as local communities from the 19th century until today. Utilising interdisciplinary methodologies borrowing from visual anthropology, material culture studies, museology and history, students will engage with critical questions about the ethics of representation in imaging places and people; the socio-political processes that inform the making of tradition, and the entanglements of politics and culture in the formation of regional and national identities.

We will read a contemporary novel, early travel accounts, do a deep dive into colonial and contemporary photography, watch films and look at representations in popular culture. Through field visits to a Tibetan exile settlement and a museum in Delhi, we will study material culture in relationship to its uses and the recontextualization of sacred objects within museum spaces.

Some of the questions we will explore include: How are cultures constructed through acts of museumisation and what is the impact this has on communities and people? How did the field of Himalayan Art emerge? Where do we ‘locate’ this field; which geographical areas and religions are made emblematic of this discipline; which cultures are excluded and why? How were museum collections of Himalayan objects built and in what historical circumstances? What curatorial strategies are used to reconstruct the auras of objects? How are sacred objects of use segregated into categories of art and ethnography? At the heart of our enquiries will be our affective relationships to things and the many complex lives that objects traverse through time and geographies.

We will also examine the recent museum-making impulse in the Himalayas through case studies of a range of museums situated in these borderlands — war memorial museums; community museums of conflict and of trade route artefacts; and museums in Buddhist monasteries to understand the relationship between heritage and religion, the impact of the movement of things from sacred sites to ‘secular’ museums, and to ask how a politics of remembrance may manifest in cultural production. The course will conclude with an introduction to Tibetan culture-in-exile through contemporary art, poetry, writing and films.

Learning Outcomes

By the end of the course, students:


• will be familiar with the broad field of the visual and material cultures in the Western Himalayas in Tibet, Ladakh and Himachal Pradesh.
• will learn about major international museums and collections of Himalayan Art and be able to critically analyze the framing of objects as art or ethnography, and questions of provenance research and label writing in object displays.
• will be conversant with critical questions around heritage, the politics of museums and the role of tradition in the construction of contemporary cultural identities.
• will acquire the critical tools interrogate the nature and impact of representation of regions, cultures and communities through images and written texts.
• will be able to analyse and read images and texts, with a focus on meaning making through vocabularies and terminologies, and apply this critical thinking in a curatorial project.

Elementary Sanskrit - II [SAN-1002/ HIS-1102] [SAN-1002/ HIS-1102-1]

Faculty Name
Nirajan Kafle [nirajan.kafle@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

Elementary Sanskrit II is the second part of a three-course series focusing on Sanskrit Grammar. By completing this course, students will grasp essential principles, enabling them to interpret and understand Classical Sanskrit texts more effectively. The emphasis on foundational skills ensures a solid understanding of the language's intricacies and better engagement with classical Sanskrit literature.

Learning Outcomes

1. Demonstrate a clear command of intermediate Sanskrit grammar, including the formation and usage of noun stems ending in consonants and a range of verbal forms.

2. Accurately recognize and construct key grammatical forms, such as present active participles, past imperfect participles, gerundives, and the conditional mood.

3. Understand and apply syntactic structures, including compound formations (samāsa), locative and genitive absolutes, and the use of demonstrative pronouns (इदम् and अदस्).

4. Conjugate and employ secondary verbal roots and desiderative verbs within accurate grammatical contexts.

5. Parse and translate Sanskrit sentences by identifying grammatical elements and applying rules of agreement, case usage, and verb conjugation.

6. Build the grammatical foundation necessary for reading Classical Sanskrit texts, with increasing independence and accuracy.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

We will follow the ‘‘Samskrta-Subodhini: A Sanskrit Primer" by Madhav Deshpande.

Economy, Politics and Society [FC-0412] [FC-0412-3]

Faculty Name
Malvika Maheshwari [malvika.maheshwari@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

The course introduces students to some of the most important concepts that frame the study of social sciences and modernity like economy, politics and society and related ideas of state, market, democracy, liberty among others. In doing so, we also delve into broader disciplinary questions like what does it mean to be political? What is the difference between thinking politically and doing politics? What is the meaning of these concepts? How are these concepts related? Have they remained static across time and space? If not, then what explains their variation? What are some of the ways in which these concepts have been studied historically? Importantly, in what ways are these diverse and dense set of ideas relevant for us today? 

Learning Outcomes

Reading primary texts, the course aims to initiate learning of some of the fundamental themes that outline our political, economic and social worlds. 

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

All the mandatory readings would be made available to the students electronically after the end of the first lecture on 25th August.

Economy, Politics and Society [FC-0412] [FC-0412-4]

Faculty Name
Nitish Kashyap [nitish.kashyap@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

This course introduces Capitalism as an economic system, critically examining its key features and inherent contradictions. We begin by investigating the relationship between the Economy and Society with theoretical frameworks and moving toward real-world observations, to understand how the structure and logic of capitalism have evolved over time.Themes such as consumerism, technological progress, surplus accumulation, among others are explored both as features of capitalism and for their impact on business, labour processes, and society at large. Engaging with both classical and contemporary thinkers, the course helps students uncover the economic value chain, question dominant narratives, and connect abstract economic ideas to everyday realities. 

By the end of the course, students will be equipped not only to think historically and critically, but also to engage with the world around them with awareness, and pragmatism.

Learning Outcomes

The course materials and evaluation design of the course is suggestive of the following learning outcomes;

One, students shall be able to understand and deconstruct the economic and business environment in which we live.

Secondly, students shall develop some strength in developing a framework for uncertain outcomes (e,g; what would the future of work look like?)

Lastly, it is expected that course shall augment independent thinking aided by holisitc reasoning.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

We shall have both papers and chapters from books as reference materials. Some of the materials in the course are taken from E K Hunt's History of Economic Thought (1968), Robert Heilbroner's The Nature and Logic of Capitalism (1985), Boltanski & Chiapello's The New Spirit of Capitalism(2018), Shoshana Zuboff's The Age of Survelliance Capitalism (2019), Grace Blakeley's Vulture capitalism (2025) among others.

The unit wise reading list shall be made available closer to the semester.

Economy, Politics and Society [FC-0412] [FC-0412-7]

Overview

What do tennis racquets and Artificial Intelligence have on common? How can the government reduce traffic jams and vehicular pollution in Delhi? What is money and what does the Reserve Bank of India do? Why does President Trump want to raise tariffs? What is a tariff and what does it do to the prices that you and I pay? What is a budget and why do economists spend so much time worrying about government budgets? What is a “ nudge” and how can you use it in getting people to scale back their electricity consumption? Is the Sensex a correct gauge of how the Indian economy is doing? Why are countries afraid of “Japanification”?

This course addresses a diverse range of issues in economics and public policy in a non-technical way. It emphasizes the intuition behind complex economic ideas and also explores the connections of economics with other disciplines – psychology, philosophy, finance, sociology and political science—for example. Finally, it  explores India specific problems such as premature such as the risk of a middle-income trap. The aim is to blend an understanding of current issues with the history of ideas to leave students with a quick but comprehensive idea of the science and art of economics.

 The course will use a diverse set of resources – short videos, excerpts from Yale and MIT open learning course, blogs and a simple textbook written by Nobel Laureate Paul Krugman.

Learning Outcomes

Evaluation

4 quizzes: 40 per cent of total marks

Class participation: 15 per cent

Group project and presentation: 45 per cent

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Essentials of Economics: Paul Krugman, Robin Wells and Martha Olney, Worth Publishers

Calculus [MAT-1000] [MAT-1000-2]

Faculty Name
Debapratim Banerjee [debapratim.banerjee@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

This course is a basic course in calculus. You will learn the foundation of calculus in this course, like number system, sequences, limits, function, differentiation, integration etc. This course is a mandatory course for all students considering mathematics as a major or minor. Students with mathematics at the level of 10 + 2 might find some overlap with this course. However, mathematical rigor and emphasis on problem solving are the keys in this course. So it will most possibly be quite different from the school-level calculus.

Learning Outcomes

Number systems.ref Sequences and series. Functions of a real variable. Graphs of functions. Limits and continuity. Differentiation. Mean value theorem. L’Hospital rule. Maclaurin and Taylor series. Curve tracing. Riemann integral. Definite and indefinite integrals. Fundamental theorem of calculus. Applications of differential and integral calculus in areas such as optimization and mechanics.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Knowledge about high school mathematics is required. We shall follow the following textbooks:

1. R. G. Bertle and D. R. Sherbert: Introduction to real analysis, Wiley, fourth edition. (Main reference)
2. J. Stewart: Calculus, Cengage Publishers, 2012. (Main reference)

description:
Evolutionary Genetics [BIO-3456/ BIO-6456] [BIO-3456/ BIO-6456-1]

Faculty Name
Sudipta Tung [sudipta.tung@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

Evolutionary thinking is rather pervasive. Its applications are not only limited to all subdisciplines of biology, but also across a range of fields outside biology, from cosmology to town building. Evolutionary computation is a distinguished field now enabling solutions to inherently complex systems.

In this course I plan to lay a firm foundation of evolutionary theory with the help of basic principles of genetics along with the tools of mathematics and computation. This will be followed by connecting those concepts to the essence of modern omics techniques, human health and evolutionary medicine.

This course does not need any pre-requisite, except for 10th standard mathematics. All other necessary concepts will be taught during the course itself. However, an introduction to genetics, 12th-grade Mathematics, a basic knowledge of coding in any programming language and will be helpful (but not essential) for this course.

Learning Outcomes

Strong foundational knowledge of the principles behind evolutionary thinking and experimentation.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

There is no prescribed textbook for this course. Suitable reading materials will be shared after the lectures. Interested students may go through the following books for additional reading.

  • Rice, S., 2004. Evolutionary theory: mathematical and conceptual foundations.
  • Freeman, S. and Herron, J.C., 2007. Evolutionary analysis.
  • Hartl, D.L., Clark, A.G. and Clark, A.G., 1997. Principles of population genetics (Vol. 116).

courseTitle: Negotiating Nature in the Early Modern World
description:
Negotiating Nature in the Early Modern World [HIS-3518/ ES-3221] [HIS-3518/ ES-3221-1]

Faculty Name
Pratyay Nath [pratyay.nath@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

How did early modern (1500-1800) Europeans experience the night? What role did animals play in shaping the Ottoman Empire in Egypt? How were whales understood and studied in Tokugawa Japan? Why did the French found the nature in Canada weird? These are some of the questions the present course unravels. This is a course in global environmental history. On the one hand, we will explore how empires, societies, and the environment shaped each other during the early modern period. On the other hand, we will investigate the evolution of the field of environmental history through its various twists and turns over the last half a century. Every week, we will explore readings around a specific theme relating to environmental history. These include nonhumans, gardens, resources, time, colonialism, wilderness, hunting, and marine life. We will cover regions from all over the world,  including Brazil, Russia, West Asia, Japan, Canada, South Asia, Europe, Egypt, China, Mexico, and South Africa. By the end of the course, students will have a sound understanding of how societies, empires, and environment moulded each other to produce the early modern world.

NB: This History elective is cross-listed with Environmental Studies. There are no prerequisites for taking this course.

Learning Outcomes

Alok Bhattacharya [alok.bhattacharya@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

This course prepares you to start your life as a researcher. A researcher needs to learn how to initiate a research project, plan the research project, execute the plan and finally write up the findings to disseminate the results. In the process, researchers must follow specific rules and guidelines, including statutory requirements. There are due processes that also guide how the research results are written up and who gets credit for the work. The course will be a participatory one involving discussions and case studies.

Structure elucidation of organic molecules [CHM-4402] [CHM-4402-1]

Faculty Name
Vidya Dnyaneshwar Avasare [vidya.avasare@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

The structure establishment is crucial for any synthesized/ naturally occurring chemical compounds The students working in any synthetic field should have the skills to analyze and interpret the spectral data and confirm the structural features of the synthesized or isolated natural products. There are various methods to establish the structure or composition of any chemical entity. However, NMR, IR, UV-visible spectroscopic methods, and mass spectrometry are commonly used in the interpretation of organic, inorganic, organometallic, and biomolecules.

In this course, the applications of NMR spectroscopy (basic and advanced) in the structure determination of the molecules consisting of primarily  C, H,  (N, F, and P  in a few cases) will be discussed along with basic mass spectrometry, IR, and UV-visible spectroscopy.

Who can attend?

This course will be useful for students who would like to do research in

Synthetic chemistry

Chemical biology

Synthetic biology

Drug discovery

Material chemistry

Computational chemistry ( to predict NMR, IR of complex molecules)

Learning Outcomes

By the end of this course, students will be able to:

Explain the fundamental principles and applications of UV-visible and IR spectroscopy in the context of molecular structure analysis.

Understand and apply basic concepts of 1D NMR spectroscopy (¹H and ¹³C) to interpret and solve spectral data for simple and chiral organic molecules.

Analyze and interpret advanced 1D NMR spectral features, including spin systems, splitting patterns, NOE effects, and polarization transfer techniques (INEPT, APT, DEPT) for complex molecules.

Utilize 2D NMR techniques, including homonuclear (COSY, TOCSY) and heteronuclear (HSQC) correlation spectroscopy, to elucidate the detailed structure of organic, organometallic, and biomolecules.

Describe the principles of mass spectrometry and apply mass spectral data for the identification and structural characterization of organic, organometallic, and biological compounds.

Integrate information from multiple spectroscopic techniques (UV-Vis, IR, NMR, MS) to comprehensively establish the structure and stereochemistry of unknown compounds.

Develop problem-solving skills through the interpretation of spectral data sets and critical evaluation of structural hypotheses.

Prepare to apply spectroscopic methods in research areas such as synthetic chemistry, chemical biology, drug discovery, material chemistry, and computational chemistry

Reading for Writing [CW-1005] [CW-1005-1]

Faculty Name
Adam Klein [adam.klein@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

 Communication is wider and more varied now than at any time in history and our expanded field of expressive modalities are both indiscriminate and proliferating. Immersed in a world of texts, a torrent of rediscovered and newly translated writings, we are more permeated by language and images than ever. Formerly marginal writings are at the center of our considerations, and the distinctions between visual and linguistic signs have been torn away. So, what and how should a writer read? With openness, anticipation, awe? Or with reserve, a quarrel with sensibility, technique, execution? We’ll read broadly for starters.

Over this course, we’ll encounter novellas, short stories, creative nonfiction, as well as works that combine text and image. We’ll consider the use of photographs in W.G. Sebald’s stories and follow Sophie Calle’s photo-text wanderings in Suite Vénitienne. We’ll revisit this same idiosyncratic artist in Grégoire Bouillier’s strange, comic memoir The Mystery Guest. We’ll read three vivid experiments in form: Vladimir Nabokov’s Pale Fire and Ann Carson’s Autobiography of Red, and Justin Torres’s Blackouts.

In an age of deep-fakes, consciousness machines, and social networks fully entwined with our social lives, considerations of formal strategies for writers abound. We’ll enter the mind-bending stories of Jorge Luis Borges and Alain Robbe-Grillet and Clarice Lispector. Finally, we’ll explore two pioneers in feminist sci-fi (James Tiptree Jr. AKA Alice Sheldon and Joanna Russ) and the philosophical horror of Brian Evenson.

Marcel Duchamp wrote, Water writes always in plural, and in this course, we’ll dip our toes into multiple streams. We’ll consider how, by allowing ourselves to read new forms of writing, we can open our practice and ourselves up to new ways of thinking and writing.

Readings are subject to change.

Visual Storytelling [VA-2010/ MS-1081] [VA-2010/ MS-1081-1]

Faculty Name
Vishwajyoti Ghosh [vishwajyoti.ghosh@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

VISUAL STORYTELLING: Through Graphic and Sequential Narratives

Course Description

This course seeks to engage with this fast-moving genre of visual storytelling through comics and graphic narratives with a research led and inter-disciplinary approach, in sync with the student’s core area of interest or discipline.

In sync with the time’s media or information dissemination, it is important to learn and practice visual storytelling as both a language and a medium that can be incorporated in one’s individual academic discipline. This approach can help the students in articulating their learnings, research and storytelling in multi-disciplinary formats that is much required in today’s realm of information & content, where visual storytelling is an alternate and a popular form of information, opinion and communication.

As the world’s reading engagement is rapidly shrinking into a palm sized mobile, the engagement with the visual is rapidly becoming the new language, with the binaries between the texts and visuals fading away. In these times visual storytelling is making a strong space for itself in every form of information or content. Be it journalism, health information, economics or plain fiction, the visual approach is now here to stay, in an age where the best of storytelling, poetry, journalism or reportage are now visually led.

Visual Storytelling is an ever-evolving medium. From the cave drawings documenting the hunter’s life or the Egyptian clay tablets that documented the Pharaoh’s philosophy or the Persian miniatures that visually documented the Ruler’s court or the wars, the Pahadi miniatures that visually articulated the leelas of Radha Krishna to the visual documentation in the modern era, from the peasant sketches of Van Gogh, the daily life depicted by Seurat, Degas and more or the nightlife by Lautrec, the Mexican muralists like Deigo Rivera, Orzoco, Chittoprasad, Indian artists like Ram Kinkar Baij, Somenath Hore to the best graphic narratives of our times by Chris Ware, Satrapi, Joe Sacco and now to the world of You Tube and Tik Tok animations the form has only grown both in terms of practice but also viewership and acceptance. In the visual world we live now, it is a form with a moving language now blending with technology. This course will blend these influences into ones’ own practice to create comics and graphic narratives in sync with the practitioner’s area of interest and discipline.

This is not to say that all human centric works of art can be categorized as narrative artworks but graphic narratives have grown and imbibed many of these experiences in the making of graphic stories including films and popular culture. For a medium as absorbent as graphic storytelling, the form has drawn inspiration and acknowledged the same from multiple disciplines like painting, prose and poetry, filmmaking and even gaming. It’s this multi-disciplinary influence and framework this course seeks to work with.

Graphic narratives can never be limited to a category but more than a form it has evolved to a medium that has embraced every subject which makes it a complete storytelling tool than an only entertainment or an informational one. 

Learning Outcomes

The preliminary module of this course of 2 weeks will be a curated overview of the published, popular and the prevalent and emerging forms of visual storytelling in the world of graphic narratives and visuals. The idea would be exploring the diversity of practice across the globe and the processes involved in the making. The core idea here will be to discuss the forms and works to bring new practice-based influences and ideas, their working process and explore the architecture of visual storytelling in these works.

Weeks 1-2: Discuss works of art, graphic novels, cartoons, comic strips and create short narratives.

This will be a presentation and discussion-based approach discussing the presented works in detail and the stories behind making many of these works. The idea will be to discuss the journey of the works from the intent to execution and the struggles and transformations that make the narrative in the final output. For example, Van Gogh’s study of the peasantry, the sketch book notes leading to the potato eaters or Somenath Hore’s diaries documenting the Tebhaga movement or Marjane Satrapi’s background story behind the making of Persepolis or Chris Ware’s documentation of the American Midwest are some of the well-articulated stories in the making of these works.

Weeks 3-5: Ideate, research, explore graphic storytelling ideas and create micro books, zines etc.

This will be followed by 3 weeks to ideate, research, explore ideas of student’s interest in their areas of discipline followed by field work, data collection and research on the ground. This will include visual data collection, interviews, recording, documentation and conceptualizing the idea based on the research.

This will lead to create micro books, zines etc.

Documentation of the research will be followed to process and distill the findings to create the core conceptual idea and be presented in the studio sessions for the benefit of collective brainstorming and discussions. These discussions with fellow classmates will led to an inter-disciplinary ideation and conceptualization, moving closer to shape and sharpen the core project ideas of the students. The students will also be expected to share the processing of their research findings along with their influences and inspirations.

Weeks 6-7: Exploring possibilities of form, conceptualization, layout, architecture etc. and presentation of a final project idea followed by discussion on similar ideas & influences

Moving on from research the course will discuss the working process of creating a visual narrative using multiple influences of form and genres. This will include detailed discussions on the various possibilities of the form i.e. different forms that can be explored -doodle narratives, popular comics, mobile based narratives, photo comics, design, layouts, page architecture, typography, sequential storytelling and the work process involved in each, enabling the students to make informed choices in sync with their ideas.

Week 8: Presentation of a final project idea followed by discussion on similar ideas & influences

The following week the students will be expected to present their ideas and preliminary drafts as scribbles/ sketches with fellow batchmates, followed by open discussions, suggestions and ideation to evolve a clear understanding to flesh out the final narrative.

Each student/ project will be further exposed to similar works through display and in-depth discussions on influences and ideas related to the project to lend a visual and storytelling perspective, enabling the practitioner to take one’s work further.

Besides creating multiple micro narratives through the semester, finally, the semester will move to its last weeks to create a bigger multi-page graphic narrative.

Weeks 9-14: Final completion with a mid-level presentation in week 11.

A mid-level draft presentation will be shared in the studio to display the work in progress after 2 weeks then followed by the final 4 weeks or the end of the semester, ready for display, presentation and production. Studio presence in these weeks will be a must.

Output Participation:

Though the output will be individual, the process of production will be based on field research, short studio collaborations and conversations and work-in-progress presentations at regular intervals as discussed above.

Course Deliverables: Every student will be expected to develop, produce multiple research-based short visual stories and graphic narratives/ comics or picture books, scrolls, posters, animation etc.

Course Prerequisites: Narrative based research, writing, basic drawing/ doodling, basic research photography, basic mobile photography.

Fictive Modernities [ENG-4341] [ENG-4341-1]

Faculty Name
Rita Kothari [rita.kothari@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

The phrase ‘fictive modernities’ speaks to two kinds of fictions. Firstly, to the modernities that
the early bhasha novels, as an incipient form, attempted to construct through a fiction
germinated from the seeds of change in the late 19th century. But also to a modernity that was
itself ‘fictitious’—and in its fiction(s) extremely fertile. These early novels are both important
archives of and indispensable drivers of a period of great ferment. Accordingly, this course finds
its impulse in both kinds of fictions; literary and social/political. We will look at four primary
texts, beginning with ‘Indulekha’(O. Chandu Menon) and ‘Indira Bai’(G. V. Rao) both of which
deal with social-political changes in the 19th century—with reform, the role of English, with new
kinds of love, and quite a good measure of didacticism. Fakir Mohan Senapati’s ‘Chha Mana
Atha Guntha’ is an agrarian novel. It is deeply satirical in its narrative voice and is a sharp
critique of both lasting and changing modes of power. Finally, we will read K. M. Munshi’s ‘The
Glory of Patan’ which is an exciting and dramatic historical fiction. While with this novel we will
step back into ‘history’, we will also see how significantly it comes to bear upon our present.

Learning Outcomes

This course is best suited for fourth year undergraduates, MA, and Ph.D students.

courseTitle: The Asian Buddhist World: Past and Present
description:
The Asian Buddhist World: Past and Present [HIS-3520] [HIS-3520-1]

Faculty Name
Sanjukta Datta [sanjukta.datta@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

Buddhism, the fourth largest religion in the world today, had its origins as a powerful, anti-Vedic renunicatory movement in the middle Ganga plains of north India in the 6th-5th centuries BCE. From the 3rd century BCE onwards, it began to be disseminated beyond the Buddhist heartland, and over the centuries came to establish deep roots across Asia. Consequently, in the course of this unusually rich but complex history of 2,500 years, both Buddhist thought and practice have undergone remarkable transformations. This course engages with multiple facets of this fascinating history, and in the process, critically examines some of the widespread, popular stereotypes about Buddhism. Some of the specific questions that it explores are as follows: How has the memorialization of the Buddha been truly dynamic? Has Buddhism really been an instrument of empowerment for the marginalized? Is environmental conservation a core tenet of Buddhism? Is it surprising to witness the involvement of Buddhist monks in political violence?

Monks, Monastery, Modernity [SOA-2213] [SOA-2213-1]

Faculty Name
Swargajyoti Gohain [swargajyoti.gohain@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

SOA 2213: Monks, Monastery, Modernity

Course Description

This is a course on the anthropology of Buddhism, and specifically Tibetan or Vajrayana Buddhism. Many people are aware that India is home to the Dalai Lama and the exile Tibetan communities, but few know that many communities who practice Tibetan Buddhism reside in the Indian Himalayan borderlands and have historical connections with Tibet. This course explores how religion, custom, politics and development confront and negotiate with one another in these Tibetan Buddhist areas.

This course begins by exploring some basic questions such as - Is Buddhism one monolithic religion or several plural traditions? What are the main doctrines and institutions of Buddhism? How do the lived practices, and institutions in contemporary Buddhist societies adhere or depart from doctrine? How is Tibetan Buddhism different from Theravada Buddhism.

The second part of this course explores the relation of Buddhism to questions of violence, nationalism, gender, and environment. Is Buddhism non-violent? Then how do we interpret the role of monks in violent identity politics and aggressive nationalisms? Was the Buddha a vegetarian?  If not, how does vegetarianism enter into Buddhist environmentalist discourse? Do Buddhist ethics prescribe egalitarianism and inclusion? Then how do gender inequalities persist in Buddhist institutions and practices? Are monasteries spaces for meditation and prayers? Then how are they co-opted into electoral battles? Is not Buddhism about renunciation? Then what do we make of the relations between Buddhism and business, and increasingly Buddhist tourism? How do Buddhists negotiate their position as minorities in India, and how does this manifest in their politics and approaches to the Indian state while negotiating citizenship benefits? While maintaining a holistic focus on Buddhism, this course will focus more on the Himalayan Buddhist areas.

Learning Outcomes

This course will give students an understanding of the anthropological approach to Buddhism.

This course offers an introduction to modern Indian political thought. We shall read the political writings of five key figures of the Indian freedom struggle--Gandhi, Tagore, Nehru, Ambedkar, and Savarkar, and explore the issues that emerge in the debates between them. The course is divided into two parts. The first, shorter, part focuses on Gandhi, while the second, longer, part looks at the debates between Gandhi and his principal interlocutors and critics.

Political Philosophy and Public Policy [POL-3084/ PHI-3810] [POL-3084/ PHI-3810-1]

Faculty Name
Bastian Steuwer [bastian.steuwer@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

Public policy requires value judgments. Cases in which we only need to know “what works” are rare. The choice between different policies requires us to trade off different values or trade off benefits to some against burdens to others. Some social scientists therefore seek to describe their task more modestly. The task of social policy as a discipline is to measure, at least estimate, the outcomes or effectiveness of a policy proposal. But even this modest task involves value judgments. How should we measure welfare? Or health? Or poverty? Or inequality? In this course we will connect political philosophy with public policy. Political philosophy is concerned with reasoning about value judgments.

Each week we will connect one debate in political philosophy with a debate in public policy. The public policy debates are often examples. Philosophical debates on inequality, for instance, bear on many policy questions. However, for this course it helps to focus our discussion by looking at one policy case in particular. There will be student presentations on the policy cases and we will work together to draw the connections between the political philosophy material and the social policy debate in India.

The course is intended for two groups of students. First, it is intended for students interested in entering public policy. This means students interested in working for policy-oriented NGOs, think tanks, IAS, public interested spirited litigation, political parties, and so on. The course shall help students sensitize about value questions as they arise in public policy. At the end of the course, students shall be able to identify implicit value questions and reason about them critically. The second group of students are students interested in political philosophy and political theory. Many courses in political theory are, well, theoretical. This course seeks to apply and make relevant debates in political philosophy for real-world concerns. Students interested in political theory can benefit from this applied focus.

Learning Outcomes
Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

In the course well will draw on political philosophy/theory as well as economics and law. Basic knowledge of political theory, political or moral philosophy is highly recommended as evidenced by completion of Western Political Thought I, Introduction to Political Theory, or an equivalent course in political theory and/or philosophy. Students without such prior courses should approach me with a short description of their background before registration. Prior knowledge of economics and/or law is helpful but not required.

courseTitle: Introduction to the Study of China
description:
Introduction to the Study of China [CHI-2001/ HIS-2804/ IR-2038] [CHI-2001/ HIS-2804/ IR-2038-1]

Faculty Name
Eloise Wright [eloise.wright@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

What is China? Who counts as Chinese? What is China’s place in the modern world? These contentious questions have been continually debated both inside and outside China, with more and more urgency. This course will introduce students to a variety of approaches to the interdisciplinary study of the societies and peoples that have been called ‘Chinese,’ both past and present. We will read works by historians, anthropologists, political scientists, sociologists, and other commentators to explore when and by whom these questions have been asked, and how they have been answered. We will examine what the study of China has meant for different kinds of audiences, and how those perspectives have evolved across time and disciplines. Therefore, we will also pay special attention to how ‘China’ has been explained to academic and popular audiences by non-Chinese commentators. As a deeply heterogenous cultural formation that has transformed and been transformed by other cultures and systems, we will consider what is distinctive, or not, about the study of “China” in our time and our region.

This semester, the topical focus for the class is ‘food’, structured around four themes: movement, labour, identity, and ritual.

This course is the core course for the China Studies minor. It is offered in Monsoon semester only.

Learning Outcomes

Think critically about the concept of ‘China’ in long-term historical perspective.

Be able to identify multiple alternative sources through which to learn about China, and analyse their strengths and weaknesses.

Identify common tropes in written and visual primary source material related to China.

Analyse the arguments and sources used by scholars in different disciplines writing about China.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Introduction to Mandarin Level - 1 [CHI-1101] [CHI-1101-1]

Faculty Name
Shao Chin [shao.chin@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

Introduction to Mandarin is a beginner’s language course, specifically designed for students with no exposure to Modern Standard Chinese (putonghua 普通話). The course will introduce students to the Chinese language and culture and focus on basic speaking, listening, reading, and writing skills. This includes an introduction to phonetics, basic vocabulary, and expressions of daily use. The course will prepare the students to attain a certain level of understanding and proficiency in Chinese language through interpretive, interpersonal, and presentational modes. It will integrate Chinese culture into language learning through both written and audio-visual means to familiarize students with the culture and language. At the end of the class, students will be able to read and comprehend Chinese texts on various topics moderately without the aid of pinyin and tone marks. They will be able to give presentations in Chinese on a prepared topic and write short paragraphs and compositions on a limited range of topics and situations.

This course is part of a two-semester sequence building towards a TOCFL Novice certification at the end of the Spring semester.

There will be one section of Introduction to Mandarin Level 1 offered in Monsoon 2025:

CHI 1101-1 M/W/F 11:50–13:20 (taught by Shao Jhe Chin Laoshi)

Learning Outcomes

Student will have  a TOCFL novice level.

Student will understand at least  150  Mandarin vocabularies.

Students will be able to  recognize everyday, high-frequency words which are immediately relevant to oneself, with backtracking allowed, and meaning supported by context.

Physics of the Universe [PHY-2850/ AST-2850] [PHY-2850/ AST-2850-1]

Faculty Name
Kandaswamy Subramanian [kandaswamy.subramanian@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

This course will introduce the students to the contents of the universe and the physical processes that occur in them.  It will describe how, starting from the big bang, the universe expanded to its present size, what forces it experienced, the nature of dark matter and dark energy, how galaxies, stars and planets formed, the origin and properties of compact objects such as neutron stars and black holes and the predicted future course of evolution of the universe.  The prime role of General Theory of Relativity in many of these processes will be highlighted.

Syllabus:

(1) Contents of the Universe from Stars/Galaxies to largest scales
(2) The smooth expanding Universe: Hubble law-redshift-Newtonian cosmology-Dark matter, Dark energy
(3) The Hot Universe: Big bang-Thermal history-Nucleosynthesis-Atom formation-Cosmic Microwave Background Radiation-Puzzles in cosmology-inflation-seed fluctuations-sound waves
(4) Structuring the universe: gravitational instability-spherical collapse-galaxy formation-dark ages-21 cm line-reionization-lyman alpha clouds-galaxies
(5) Gas in galaxies-atomic and molecular probes-formation of stars and planets-stellar structure and evolution-end state of stars.
 

Learning Outcomes

The student will develop appreciation of the many exciting phenomena that go on in the universe and learn how to understand them using only the basic laws of Physics.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Pre-requisite (desirable): Physical science at the std XI-XII level, FCs on QRMT and PoS

Recommended reading:

1. The Physical Universe, Frank H. Shu, University Science Books
2. Foundations of Astrophysics, Barbara M. Ryden and Bradley M. Peterson, Cambridge University Press
3. An Introduction to Modern Astrophysics, B.W. Carroll and D.A. Ostlie, Cambridge University Press
4. Astrophysical Concepts, M. Harwit, Springer
5. IGNOU PHE-15 Study Material

courseTitle: Odissi and the art of movement
description:
Odissi and the art of movement [CPA-0077] [CPA-0077-1]

Overview

Supriya Nayak

This course will facilitate a familiarity with and basic literacy in Odissi- a culturally and historically specific vocabulary of dance movement-  along with tools to better engage with the performing arts more broadly. Focussing on some fundamental elements,  students will work with Odissi rhythms and learn basic stances and movements to understand the interplay of symmetry and asymmetry that is characteristic of this style of dance. By the end of the semester, we will build short phrases of dance from the material learnt.

courseTitle: At the Margins of Care and Love
description:
At the Margins of Care and Love [ENG-3341/ SOA-3109] [ENG-3341/ SOA-3109-1]

Faculty Name
S Satish Kumar [s.kumar@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

This course seeks to reflect on the margins beyond which imaginations and experiences of care and love begin to appear fraught and even impossible. What does it mean to love and care for oneself and for individual and collectivities of others? What allows us to love and care? What prevents us from caring and loving for ourselves and others? To paraphrase the narrator of The God of Small Things, this course attempts reflections on the “Love Laws” that determine who can be loved, how and how much.

The texts chosen for our study deal with such themes through representations of experiences of care and love from subject positions that lie outside of “traditional” and “normative” structures within which they are usually understood and experienced. The primary objective of the course then is to reflect on not just representations of care and love in literary and cultural texts, but how such representations are shaped by collective imaginaries and in turn shape the same.

Learning Outcomes

description:
The Earth and Other Planets [AST-2840/ AST-3840/ PHY-3840] [AST-2840/ AST-3840/ PHY-3840-1]

Faculty Name
Sujan Kumar Sengupta [sujan.sengupta@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

    THE EARTH AND OTHER PLANETS

The following topics will be covered in the whole course: 

  1.  Introduction: Progress in Astronomy
  2.   (i)  Brief history of the discovery of  Solar Planets    (ii)  Hierarchy in the Universe and our position
  3.  The Sun and its properties
  4.  The Earth and its properties
  5.   Geological evolution of the Earth
  6.   Formation of the Solar system
  7.   Mercury
  8.   Venus
  9.   Mars
  10.   Asteroid Belt
  11.   Jupiter
  12.   Saturn
  13.   Uranus and Neptune
  14.   Pluto and other dwarf planets
  15.   Moons of the Solar System- Natural satellites
  16.   Discovery and Detection methods of Exoplanets
  17.   Radial Velocity or Doppler Method
  18.   Transit Method and Gravitational Microlensing Method
  19.   Zoo of Planets
  20.   Definition of Life  
  21.    Earth’s Ecological system
  22.   Habitable Zone and Bio-signatur
  23.   Possibility of life anywhere else  in Solar system
  24.   Search for intelligent life
  25.   Fate of the Sun and the Solar system
Learning Outcomes

Konwledge on Earth and other Solar planets, detection methods and properties of Extrasolar planets, basic of Astrobiology, present status of the search for intelligent and unintelligent extraterrestrial life. 

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Recommended reading:

(1) Worlds Beyond Our Own- The Search for Habitable Planets by Sujan Sengupta (Springer,  
      2015).
(2) ExtraSolar planets and Astrobiology by Celeb A Scharf (University Science Books, 2008).
(3) The Exoplanet Handbook by Michael Perryman (Cambridge University Press, 2018).
(4) Fundamental Planetary Science: Physics, Chemistry and Habitability by Jack J. Lissauer  
     (Cambridge University Press, 2019).
(5) Handbook of Astrobiology by Vera M. Kolb, (CRC Press, 2021).

Cosmic Messengers -2 (Laboratory) [AST-3880/ AST-4880/ PHY-3880/ PHY-4880/ PHY-6880] [AST-3880/ AST-4880/ PHY-3880/ PHY-4880/ PHY-6880-1]

Faculty Name
Dipankar Bhattacharya [dipankar.bhattacharya@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

This course will introduce general techniques of data analysis and of drawing inference from multi-attribute, multi-mesenger data.  Specific examples from Astronomy will be used, but the underlying methods will have applicability in a wide variety of domains.

Syllabus:

Brief overview of different electromagnetic bands and the instruments employed for astronomical data collection.  Ground vs Space based astronomy. Inference from data, role and techniqes of model fitting.  Temporal, spectral and direct/indirect imaging data will be treated in an unified framework.

Types of data - Image data, Spectral data, Temporal data, Interferometry data, Event data.
Principles of reduction of different data types. Calibration requirements.  Background estimation and removal. Error estimates.  Elements of Fourier analysis.

Astronomical data and metadata formats:  The FITS standard.  Viewing, writing and manipulating FITS files.  The AstroPy package.

Hands-on analysis of data including introduction to packages:

Optical: IRAF
Measuring the optical magnitude of a star. Estimating the surface brightness profile of a galaxy. Reduction of a one-dimensional spectrum - wavelength calibration, line identification, continuum subtraction, line profile fitting and radial velocity measurement.

X-ray/Gamma-ray: HEASOFT
Binning of event data to create image, spectrum and light curve.  Response Matrix and Auxiliary Response Files.  Orbital motion of a space-based observatory and charged particle background.
Temporal analysis of Crab pulsar data - barycentric correction, power spectral estimation, epoch folding, phase tracking.  Estimation of spin and spin-down rate.  Transient detection: GRB

Radio interferometry: friendlyVRI, CASA
Creation of an image from visibility data, snapshot vs earth rotation synthesis.  Spectral channels and data cubes.  Local Standard of Rest correction.

Gravitational Waves
Matched filtering through a burst segment and parameter estimation.

Learning Outcomes

This course is intended to familiarise the students with the analysis of multi-messenger astronomical data at different wavebands, including optical, X-ray, radio and gravitational waves.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Recommended Reading:
1. Observational Astronomy (2nd ed): D. Scott Bimey, Guillermo Gonzalez and David Oesper, Cambridge University Press
3. Essential Radio Astronomy: James A. Condon and Scott A. Ransom, Princeton University Press
5. Handbook of X-ray astronomy, ed. K. Arnaud, R. Smith and A. Siemiginowska, Cambridge University Press
7. General Relativity and Gravitational Waves: Essentials of Theory and Practice: Sanjeev Dhurandhar and Sanjit Mitra, Springer
8. Basics of Fourier Analysis for High Energy Astronomy: T. Belloni and D. Bhattacharya, Handbook of X-ray and Gamma-Ray Astronomy, Springer [arXiv: 2203.04106]

Pre-requisites:  This course is intended to familiarise the students with the analysis of multi-messenger astronomical data at different wavebands, including optical, X-ray, radio and gravitational waves.  General knowledge about astronomical sources and various types of radiation is essential.   Working knowledge of linux operating system, python programming and conda environment will be required.

Environment Justice [ES-3443] [ES-3443-1]

Faculty Name
Mukul Sharma [mukul.sharma@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

ENVIRONMENT JUSTICE: HISTORICAL, GLOBAL, INDIAN

This elective course explores the dynamic and evolving field of environmental justice, tracing its roots and growth across historical, global, and Indian contexts. It begins by examining how the concept emerged powerfully in the 1980s, especially through the struggles of Black communities in the United States. These movements arose in response to stark racial inequalities embedded in urban planning, housing, industrial zoning, and the toxic burden placed disproportionately on marginalized communities. One landmark in this journey was the 1991 People of Color Environmental Leadership Summit in Washington D.C.—a moment that redefined the relationship between environment and social justice.

But environmental justice has never stayed confined to one place. As it travelled across borders, it took on different forms—shaped by diverse cultural histories, political struggles, and the universal rejection of racism, oppression, and exclusion. From the global South to the global North, its frameworks have expanded to engage with trade, climate change, waste dumping, and the Rights of Nature, evolving into a truly global and pluralistic movement.

In India, the story of environmental justice is deeply interwoven with struggles over access to and control of natural resources—by peasants, workers, Dalits, women, and Adivasi communities. Here, the course will draw from a rich body of Indian environmental thought and activism, looking at how social conflicts—over forests, water, land, and energy—are inseparable from issues of justice, dignity, and survival.

The course will critically engage with case studies, theoretical perspectives, and comparative insights, while giving special attention to caste, gender, climate, and energy justice. It will encourage students to think historically and globally, while staying grounded in local and national realities.

Learning Outcomes

The course is organized around weekly lectures and discussions based on the readings. Students will be asked to write an essay on one of the topics of the course, with footnotes and bibliography, and further readings will be given to them on their chosen topic, so that they can go in much more depth on a particular topic

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Unit 1: An Introduction to History

Origins of environmental justice movements; connections to civil rights and anti-racist struggles.

Unit 2: Theories and Perspectives

Conceptual frameworks and key debates; understanding justice through multiple lenses—legal, cultural, ecological.

Unit 3: Global Trajectories: Africa, South America and Asia

Comparative case studies and global linkages; transnational environmental activism and resistance.

Unit 4: Indian Perspectives and Case Studies

Local movements and national dynamics; forest rights, displacement, mining, urban pollution, and grassroots resistance.

Unit 5: Climate and Energy Justice

Equity in climate policy; energy access and transitions; justice debates in mitigation and adaptation.

Unit 6: Caste, Dalits and Environmental Justice

Intersections of caste and ecology; exclusions in environmental policy and activism; the fight for recognition and redistribution.

Essential and Secondary Readings:

Bryant, Bunyan, ed. 1995. Environmental Justice: Issues, Policies, and Solutions. Washington, DC: Island Press.

Bullard, Robert D. 2000. Dumping in Dixie: Race, Class, and Environmental Quality. Boulder, CO: Westview Press.

Byrne, John, Leigh Glover, and Cecilia Martinez. 2002. Environmental Justice: Discourses in International Political Economy. New Brunswick, NJ: Transaction.

Cole, Luke W., and Sheila R. Foster. 2001. From the Ground Up: Environmental Racism and the Rise of the Environmental Justice Movement. New York: New York University Press.

Dobson, Andrew. 1998. Justice and the Environment: Conceptions of Environmental Sustainability and Theories of Distributive Justice. Oxford: Oxford University Press.

Guha, Ramachandra, and Juan Martinez-Alier. 1998. Varieties of Environmentalism: Essays North and South. Delhi: Oxford University Press.

Guru, Gopal. 2012. “Experience, Space, and Justice.” In The Cracked Mirror: An Indian Debate on Experience and Theory, ed. Gopal Guru and Sundar Sarukkai, 71–106. New Delhi: Oxford University Press.

Harvey, David. 1996. Justice, Nature and the Geography of Difference. Cambridge: Blackwell.

Martinez-Alier Joan, Leah Temper, Daniela Del Bene, and Arnim Scheidel. 2016. “Is There a Global Environmental Justice Movement?” Journal of Peasant Studies 43: 731–755.

Rajan, S. Ravi. 2014. “Environmental Justice in India.” Environmental Justice 7 (5): 117–121.

Sandler, Ronald, and Phaedra C. Pezzullo, eds. 2007. Environmental Justice and Environmentalism: The Social Justice Challenge to the Environmental Movement. Cambridge, MA: MIT Press.

Sharma, Mukul. 2017. Caste & Nature: Dalits and Indian Environmental Politics. New Delhi: Oxford University Press.

Steady, Filomina Chioma, ed. 2009. Environmental Justice in the New Millennium. New York: Palgrave Macmillan.

Taylor, Dorceta E. 2014. Toxic Communities: Environmental Racism, Industrial Pollution, and Residential Mobility. New York: New York University Press.

Wells, Christopher W., ed. 2018. Environmental Justice in Postwar America: A Documentary Reader. Seattle, WA: University of Washington Press.

Foreign Policy Analysis [IR-2050] [IR-2050-1]

Faculty Name
Quintijn Benjamin Kat [quintijn.kat@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

As a discipline, IR is initially taught in terms of grand theories—realism, liberalism, constructivism, Marxism—which try to explain in one fell swoop the entirety of international politics. Foreign Policy Analysis is much more granular because it examines how policymakers decide. As you will learn, actual decision-making is always messier than what grand theories imply. So, from the grand and the ‘macro’, we look on the domestic, state, organizational, and personal levels to understand the multitude of factors that affect a country’s foreign policy. To do this, we make use of various conceptual lenses: theories of rational choice and alternatives to rational choice, individual/group psychology, emotions, culture/identity, and more.

So, what are the kind of questions that this class will help you think about? Perhaps questions such as ‘Why did the United States respond to the discovery of Soviet missiles in Cuba with a blockade rather than any other possible response?’, ‘Why do state leaders sometimes choose policy options with a high risk of failure while less risky options are available?’, ‘How did domestic politics impact US-Iranian relations in the early twenty-first century?’, ‘How did Nehru’s experience of colonial subjugation shape his ideas of non-alignment?’, ‘What are the effects of social media on foreign policy?’, and ‘Can small states be successful in their foreign policy and, if yes, under what conditions?’. These are just some examples. The main objective of the course is to introduce you to the many approaches one can take when trying to understand, explain, and analyse foreign policy processes and decision-making.

Learning Outcomes

A basic understanding of Foreign Policy Analysis and how it converges with and diverges from systemic IR theory.

Familiarity with several theories and core concepts of Foreign Policy Analysis.

Ability to distinguish between different levels of analysis and how each of these entails varying approaches to research.

Ability to question rhetorical justifications for prominent foreign policy decisions that may not explain them adequately.

Ability to apply a Foreign Policy Analysis theoretical framework to a case of choice or to write a critique of such a theoretical framework.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Having completed IR-1009, IR Theory

Computational Astrophysics and Geophysics [PHY-4830/ PHY-6830/ AST-4830] [PHY-4830/ PHY-6830/ AST-4830-1]

Faculty Name
Dipankar Bhattacharya [dipankar.bhattacharya@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

Computational modelling is an essential tool in Astrophysics and Geophysics.  Comprehension of diverse physical effects including fluid and gas flow under gravity, heat and radiation transport, oscillations and seismology, formation of structures in the universe etc is being developed through computations.  This course will introduce the students to some of the basic techniques to perform such computational modelling.    At the heart of the mathematical description of these problems are partial differential equations (PDEs).  Several common methods used to solve PDEs will be discussed, with application examples drawn from Astrophysical and Geophysical settings.   Statistical moelling through Mone-Carlo methods and methods of inference from data will also be discussed.

The following is an outline of the syllabus:

1. Ordinary and Partial differential equations; Different discretization schemes - Finite difference, Finite Volume and Finite element methods; Euler, Crank-Nicholson and Runge-Kutta integration schemes. Fourier Transforms and Spectral Methods.
2. Applications to the structure and oscillations of stellar and planetary bodies, dynamic, thermal and radiative processes in diffuse material, Geophysical heat and material transport.
3. N-body simulations and formation of structure in the universe 
4. Bayesian inference from observed data. Basic Monte Carlo and MCMC techniques.
Learning Outcomes

1. Learn to formulate physical problems in a computational setting
2. Learn various algorithms for solving problems described by differential equations, their pros and cons and domain of applicability.
3. Experience hands-on the application of numerical techniques to astrophysical and geophysical problems
4. Learn methods to draw statistical inference from data

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Prerequisites:

Coding ability in any one programming language such as Python, C, C++ or FORTRAN.   Familiarity with differential and integral calculus. Basic knowledge of classical mechanics and thermodynamics.  Basic plotting and visualisation techniques.  Working knowledge of Linear Algebra and Root finding methods.

Recommended Reading:

1. Numerical Recipes: The Art of Scientific Computing -  by W.H. Press, S.A. Teukolsky, W.T. Vetterling and B.P. Flannery, Cambridge University Press, http://numerical.recipes
2. Finite Volume Methods for Hyperbolic Problems - by Randall J. Leveque, Cambridge University Press
3. Numerical Solutions of Partial Differential Equations - by K.W. Morton and D.F. Mayers, Cambridge University Press
4. Partial Differential Equations for Scientists and Engineers - by Stanley F. Farlow, Dover Publications
5. Lecture Notes on Computational Geophysics by A.P. van den Berg: http:// www.geo.uu.nl/~berg/compgeoph/lecturenotes.pdf
6. Data Analysis: A Bayesian Tutorial by D.S. Sivia and J. Skilling, Oxford University Press

India in Asian Geopolitics [IR-3014/ CHI-3302/ POL-3098] [IR-3014/ CHI-3302/ POL-3098-1]

Faculty Name
Shivshankar Menon [shivshankar.menon@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

This twenty lecture course examines changes and constants in the geopolitics affecting India’s foreign and security policies since independence in 1947. It first considers chronologically the factors that affected Indian policy, its international context, and the role of personalities, structures and strategic culture in the making of that policy as it evolved over seven decades. It then focuses on the present, on the new geopolitics of Asia and India’s interests and policy choices today. The course concentrates on India in Asia, and considers the dynamic between India’s interests, the changing environment, and India’s growing capabilities as expressed in the practice of Indian policy.

Learning Outcomes

The course seeks to give students a sense of Asian geopolitics, non-Western IR, and of the domestic and other drivers of foreign and security policy choices in India and Asia.

Instrumentation Laboratory [CHM-3206/ CHM-4206/ CHM-6206] [CHM-3206/ CHM-4206/ CHM-6206-1]

Faculty Name
Santu Bera [santu.bera@ashoka.edu.in] ,Vidya Dnyaneshwar Avasare [vidya.avasare@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

This laboratory course provides hands-on experience and a theoretical understanding of key modern instrumental techniques commonly used in chemical analysis. Students will explore the principles, operation, and applications of spectroscopic and chromatographic methods, including Fourier Transform Infrared Spectroscopy (FTIR), UV-Visible Spectrophotometry, Fluorescence Spectroscopy, Gas Chromatography-Mass Spectrometry (GC-MS), High-Performance Liquid Chromatography (HPLC), and Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) Spectroscopy. The course emphasizes practical skills in sample preparation, data acquisition, and interpretation of experimental results relevant to organic, inorganic, and pharmaceutical chemistry.

Learning Outcomes

By the end of this course, students will be able to:

  • Explain the fundamental principles and instrumentation of FTIR, UV-Vis, fluorescence spectroscopy, GC-MS, HPLC, and NMR.
  • Perform qualitative and quantitative analysis of chemical samples using instrumental techniques, including functional group identification and concentration determination.
  • Interpret spectroscopic data (FTIR, UV-Vis, fluorescence, NMR) to elucidate molecular structure, identify functional groups, and analyze reaction progress.
  • Analyze chromatographic data from GC-MS and HPLC to identify and purify components and determine enantiomeric excess % .
  • Apply instrumental methods to study chemical and physical properties.
  • Use current scientific literature to support experimental outcomes, data interpretation, and validation of instrumental analysis techniques.
  • Develop skills in experimental planning, laboratory safety, handling of instrumentation, and scientific reporting.

Introduction to Computer Science [CS-1102] [CS-1102-1]

Faculty Name
Aalok Dhaval Thakkar [thakkar@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

This introductory course provides a foundational understanding of computational thinking as a problem-solving strategy, explores the core principles of computation, and introduces students to various subdisciplines within the field. Students will learn how to approach and solve problems both with and without code, with a strong emphasis on correctness, design, and style. The course is structured around two key computational models: the functional model, which views computation as the evaluation of mathematical functions, and the imperative model, which focuses on sequences of instructions that manipulate program state. By exploring these two perspectives, students will develop a deeper understanding of how different programming paradigms influence problem-solving and algorithm design. The course concludes with a series of lectures that offer disciplinary breadth through topics such as information theory, cryptography, compiler design, databases, numerical algorithms, quantitative modeling, and machine learning. The course webpage will be available in early August.

Learning Outcomes

1. Algorithmic Thinking: Develop the ability to analyze and design algorithms as systematic problem-solving approaches, with an emphasis on precision and efficiency.  

2. Program Correctness and Design: Understand the theoretical principles of program correctness, as well as design principles that emphasize clarity, structure, and style in solutions.  

3. Computational Models: Explore computation through two core paradigms—the functional model (evaluation of mathematical functions) and the imperative model (state manipulation via sequences of instructions).  

4. Practical Coding Skills: Gain hands-on experience coding in OCaml and Python, with opportunities to explore other languages such as C++, Rust, Java, Datalog, and SQL.  

5. Foundational Disciplinary Topics: Acquire an introductory understanding of subfields such as information theory, cryptography, compiler design, databases, numerical algorithms, quantitative modeling, and machine learning.
