courseTitle: Empire, education, and practices of reading
description:
Empire, education, and practices of reading [ENG-4308] [ENG-4308-1]

Faculty Name
Saikat Majumdar [saikat.majumdar@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

The act of reading is central to literary studies. Debates around different kinds of reading have marked defining concerns of the discipline in the last few decades: deep and surface reading, close and distant reading, professional and amateur reading. This course will extend these debates to the domain of world English. Examining patterns of reading and literary education in different parts of the historical British Empire, it will consider unifying patterns of such education in the colonies along with their postcolonial legacies: structures of universities, curricula, and an often-overlapping body of English texts. It will also examine how this pushed a body of imaginative readers to read against the variously limiting and exclusionary structures of colonial and postcolonial education, creating figures of disruptive autodidactism. Our focus will be on South Africa, West Indies, and India.

Empires, Nomads and Barbarians [HIS-3538] [HIS-3538-1]

Faculty Name
Upinder Singh [upinder.singh@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

How did the Achaemenid empire of Iran change world history? Why did Alexander’s army retreat at the Beas? How did the Chandragupta and Ashoka interface with the Hellenistic world? What impact did the Bactrian Greeks, Scythians, Parthians and Kushanas have on Indian history? How did Gupta kings deal with the threat posed by the Hunas and Sasanids? What does the Begram treasure tell us about the importance of Central Asia and Afghanistan in the ancient world? Why is it that in spite of a long history of varied, vibrant interactions with the world, Indian texts display a disdain for foreigners, designating them as mlechhas or barbarians? This course answers these and many other questions by viewing the history of the Indian subcontinent within wider global and comparative frames. It uses primary sources -- textual, archaeological, epigraphic, numismatic and visual – to explore networks of political, economic, religious, intellectual and artistic interaction across the Afro-Eurasian world. Touching on anthropological and historical debates related to states, empires, nomads, frontiers and borderlands, the course explores themes such as migration and nomadism, how cultural others become ‘barbarians,’ what happens when ‘barbarians’ become rulers, and the cultural synthesis that can occur in times of political conflict.

Learning Outcomes

Students will understand the interconnections between different parts of the ancient world, and the value of a comparative historical perspective.

courseTitle: Law and Lawyerly Thinking: An Introduction for Entrepreneurs and Beyond
description:
Law and Lawyerly Thinking: An Introduction for Entrepreneurs and Beyond [ENT-2039] [ENT-2039-1]

Faculty Name
Ekanto Ghosh [ekanto.ghosh@ashoka.edu.in] ,Nikhil Sud [nikhil.sud@ashoka.edu.in] ,Sagar Singhal [sagar.singhal@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

So you don’t want to be a lawyer. Or maybe you do. Who knows, and who cares, because either way, a general understanding of key legal concepts – and the ability to think like a lawyer – will add invaluably to your arsenal as you step out into the real world. This knowledge and skillset will make you a distinctly sharper leader in the business world, because legal issues routinely – and increasingly – strike at the heart of business risks and opportunities, and are integral to overall corporate strategy. And so not just lawyers but a wide range of business executives (including C-suite executives) and their advisors routinely work on legal issues alongside lawyers. Legal roles are increasingly business roles, and vice versa. Therefore, the knowledge and skills this course provides will make you a sharper entrepreneur, or a sharper business executive, or a sharper consultant to businesses across sectors. But that’s not all. The benefits extend to countless roles even beyond the business world: you’ll be a sharper problem-solver regardless of field. To this end, the course will explore key concepts across several fundamental areas of law including contracts, torts, constitutional, criminal, administrative, competition, and procedural – each of which is applicable across a wide range of professional fields. The course will explore these concepts in two jurisdictions: India and the U.S. The course will also introduce students to thinking (and related) skills fundamental to not just the legal profession but also to the many professional roles (discussed above) that require frequent engagement with the law or with lawyers. These skills include: contract construction and interpretation; analyzing and applying a case; textual interpretation more broadly; analytical writing; persuasive writing; persuasive verbal argument; and highly analytical thinking with unrelenting precision, agility, and creativity.

Introduction to Phonetics [CLA-0048] [CLA-0048-1]

Overview

Taught by Peggy Mohan

This is a course about phonetics, aiming to explore the sounds used in human language, how they are pronounced and how they are written. We will study the structure of the human vocal tract, the places of articulation, the different types of sounds and the airstreams involved in producing them. This will give us a picture of the variety of sounds in all the languages of South Asia, and will also explore those sounds in relationship to the languages outside of South Asia. Besides vowels and consonants, we will also learn about syllable stress and the tones found in tone languages of the Northeast. At the end of the course the student will be able to produce the sounds of words in all the languages of South Asia.

War and Strategy [IR-2048] [IR-2048-1]

Faculty Name
Ananya Sharma [ananya.sharma@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

Why do countries go to war? In this course, we seek to offer a global perspective on the evolution of modern warfare and strategy within a critical context. We will also follow its manifestations in international politics today. While delving into different case studies from Afghanistan, Israel-Palestine and Ukraine, we will evaluate the potential and limitations of causal explanations of warfare, and their embeddedness within different traditions of strategic thought, including from within Asia, as well as Western Europe. Through these discussions, we will explore the extent to which explanations about war have to be contextualized within global developments of the nineteenth and twentieth century, and how its present day conduct is also shaped by colonial and post-colonial influences. Finally, we will evaluate the role of access to technology, and how decision making structures on military affairs serve as the means to contain or to further proliferate war.

courseTitle: Technology Law and Policy: A New Frontier for Business and Society
description:
Technology Law and Policy: A New Frontier for Business and Society [ENT-2032/ POL-2120] [ENT-2032/ POL-2120-1]

Faculty Name
Ekanto Ghosh [ekanto.ghosh@ashoka.edu.in] ,Nikhil Sud [nikhil.sud@ashoka.edu.in] ,Sagar Singhal [sagar.singhal@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

Myth: “This course is heavy on tech.  Expertise/interest in tech is necessary.”

Reality: Not at all.  Tech is just the context.  The course is about policy issues on the internet platforms we all use constantly – issues that affect us all, such as privacy; censorship; competition and choice; and others.

This course (cross-listed with Political Science) will draw from the first-hand experience of a seasoned global tech lawyer and policy practitioner to explore the following questions: around the world, how are businesses, governments, and others thinking about new “rules” for the internet – and how should they be thinking, and how can one help shape this thinking? The course will explore emerging law and policy issues in the context of the internet and technology – in India and key foreign contexts including the U.S. and Europe. Given the increasingly pervasive nature of the internet and technology, these issues bring new and critical implications for a wide variety of professionals and businesses including but not only startups and other entrepreneurial initiatives; for society at large; and for the roles that businesses can play in society. These issues also transcend national boundaries, and routinely reflect and influence complex interactions between different nations. The course will address issues including data privacy; free speech and content moderation; competition; Artificial Intelligence; and others – and also distill practical skills and insights that cut across the various substantive issues discussed in the course. In doing so, the course will help prepare students to navigate, critically evaluate, and shape tech law and policy as part of the business world and more broadly – in India and globally – drawing from the instructor’s first-hand leadership experience in crafting and executing innovative, high-impact strategies in the field.

Introductory inorganic chemistry [CHM-1159] [CHM-1159-1]

Faculty Name
Munmun Ghosh [munmun.ghosh@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

1. Atomic Structure

Recapitulation of Bohr’s theory, atomic spectrum of hydrogen atom. its limitations Wave mechanics: de Broglie equation, Heisenberg’s Uncertainty Principle and its significance.

Quantum numbers and their significance, Radial and angular wave functions for hydrogen atom. Radial and angular distribution curves. Shapes of s, p, d orbitals.

Pauli’s Exclusion Principle, Hund’s rule of maximum multiplicity, aufbau principle and its limitations. Electronic configuration

2 class (3 hrs)

2. Chemical Bonding:

Ionic bond: General characteristics, types of ions, size effects, radius ratio rule and its limitations.

Covalent bond: Lewis structure, Valence Bond theory, Valence shell electron pair repulsion theory (VSEPR)

Energetics of hybridization, Bent’s rule,

Molecular orbital theory. Molecular orbital diagrams of diatomic and simple polyatomic molecules N2, O2, C2, B2, F2, CO, NO, and their ions; HCl (idea of s-p mixing and orbital interaction to be given).

Covalent character in ionic compounds, polarizing power and polarizability. Fajan’s rules and consequences of polarization.

Ionic characters in covalent compounds: Bond moment and dipole moment.

6 class (9 hrs)

3 Chemical Periodicity:

Brief discussion of the following properties of the elements, with reference to s & p-block and the trends shown:

Effective nuclear charge, shielding or screening effect, Slater rules, variation of effective nuclear charge in periodic table.

Atomic and ionic radii

Ionization enthalpy, Successive ionization enthalpies and factors affecting ionization enthalpy and trends in groups and periods.

Electron gain enthalpy and trends in groups and periods.

Electronegativity, Pauling’s/ Allred Rochow’s scales. Variation of electronegativity with bond order, partial charge, hybridization, group electronegativity.

2 class (3 hrs)

4. Acids & Bases

Arrhenius & Protonic Theory of Acid & Bases,

Strength of acids & bases, General trends in periodic table, superacids, pH scale, Buffer solution, Acid-Base titration, Choice of Indicators

2 class (3 hrs)

5. Coordination Chemistry:

IUPAC nomenclature of coordination compounds, isomerism in coordination compounds.

Stereochemistry of complexes with 4 and 6 coordination numbers.

Bonding in Coordination Complex

Reaction Mechanism

CFT (Crystal Field theory)

10 class (15 hrs)

6. Magnetism

Magnetic properties of complexes

Zeeman interaction

2 class (3 hrs)

Learning Outcomes

basic understanding of metals.

atomic structure, electronic configuration

Acidity & basicity

periodic table, periodic trends

Inorganic complexes/ Coordination of complexes

reaction of coordination complexes

Colour and magnetism in complexes

Oxford, 1970

Heinemann,1997.

A Physics Primer [PHY-1220] [PHY-1220-1]

Faculty Name
Bikram Phookun [bikram.phookun@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

This course will be a panorama of physics, both classical and modern. We will use illustrative examples to explore the four major domains of physics — classical mechanics, electricity & magnetism, quantum mechanics, and statistical mechanics —, and examine the space-time in which physical phenomena unfold. We will also learn how physicists use dimensional analysis and order-of-magnitude estimates to build intuition, make informed guesses, and think physically.

Course Content

Space and time: Symmetries of and principle of relativity. Galilean and Lorentz transformations. Special theory of relativity. 

Classical mechanics: Newton’s Laws. Simple pendulum. Coupled pendulums. Waves. Kepler’s laws and planetary motion. Action principle. Symmetry and conservation laws.

Electricity and magnetism: Charges and fields. Transformation of electric and magnetic fields. Maxwell’s equations. Infinite L-C circuits. Electromagnetic waves in waveguides, from current sheet, and from accelerating charge. Power radiated. 

Quantum mechanics: Observational introduction. Double slit experiment. Waves and particles. Uncertainty principle. The wave function. Tunnelling. Bohr model of the hydrogen atom. Concepts of spin and qubits. Black body radiation.

Statistical mechanics: Einstein diffusion and thermal physics. Entropy. Ideal and van Der Waals gases. Fermi and Bose gases, applications

Black holes.

The universe.

 

Prerequisites: Familiarity with calculus, graphing, algebra, and trigonometry at an elementary level.
 

Learning Outcomes

By the end of the course the student will be exposed to a wide spectrum of physics, and is expected to develop a working knowledge of the way physicists think and work. 

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

References

Fundamentals of Physics I and II, by R Shankar (lectures available on Youtube) 

Fly-by-night Physics, by A Zee

Back–of–the–Envelope Physics, by C Swartz

The Art of Insight in Science and Engineering: Mastering Complexity, by S Majahan

courseTitle: Unclaimed Histories: Psychoanalysis as a Historical Method
description:
Unclaimed Histories: Psychoanalysis as a Historical Method [HIS-5600] [HIS-5600-1]

Faculty Name
Aparna Vaidik [aparna.vaidik@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

This is a historical methods course that is woven around historical works that engage with the ‘unruly unconscious’ that expresses itself in the form of flawed testimonies, unprocessed grief, and the silence of trauma. That is, the unclaimed histories of human experiences that tend to fall by the wayside. Given the representational limitations of the evidence-based historical discipline, working with the unconscious disrupts some well-established disciplinary protocols of historiographical practice. It requires a redefinition of the words history, truth, evidence and archive. It also raises some uncomfortable questions such as: How do we attend to the affective dimension of experience - ours and that of historical subjects? How can we subject experiential claims to rigorous investigation and disputation? How does our relationship to a remembered past, or to the past which we imagine is inaccessible to us, serve desires in the present? How do we rethink the complex relationship of narrative structures to truth claims? This course engages with these questions as it takes the students through the writings of historians who successfully adapted psychoanalytic concepts to historical analysis. The course begins with familiarizing the students with a few psychoanalytic concepts that historians tend to draw on followed by weekly segments devoted to a psychoanalytical historical work. 

Learning Outcomes

courseTitle: Archive Fever: Representation, Affect, and Historian's Craft
description:
Archive Fever: Representation, Affect, and Historian's Craft [HIS-6500] [HIS-6500-1]

Faculty Name
Aparna Vaidik [aparna.vaidik@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

History as an academic discipline traces back its genealogy to European Enlightenment, a philosophical movement in 17th and 18th century Europe identified with the Age of Reason. The institutionalization and professionalization of History followed in the 19th century. History as a discipline came to be conceived of as a rigorous science based on evidence. Since that time, notwithstanding the intellectual and ideological orientation of a historian, historical inquiry has been premised on gathering and interpretation of evidence. However, the postmodernist critique shook the foundational ideas of the discipline. It questioned the objectivity and stability of historical facts, the historians’ narratives and their epistemic truth. The consequent disciplinary churn led to a  rethinking of the idea of archive and the referential paradigm of the historian’s craft.  This course explores the questions that came to fore in what has come to be known as the ‘archival turn’ in History. These include: Is archive simply a physical repository of historical materials or an idea or a storehouse of memories and dreams? What role does power and privilege play in the creation and one’s access to an archive?  What distortions or accretions does time create in the archival objects? What are the layers of narratives that an archive embodies? What does it visibilize or silence? In what way does the historian's subjectivity and desires mediate their work in the archives? How does one work with archival artifacts - against the grain or along the grain? What is the difference between an extractive and ethnographic approach to the archives? Can the archives be queered? What are the ethics of working with an archive? This course engages with the conceptual writings on archives and seeks to train students in working with different kinds of archival material. The class format will be a combination of discussions on a set of thematic readings followed by a workshop with archival materials.

Learning Outcomes

1.     Learning historian’s craft: What is a historian’s relationship with their archive? How does a historian go about piecing together the past? What is the relationship between evidence and narration?

2.     Historical thinking trains us to question what we know: That is, it forces us to ask how we know what we know. By doing this it helps establish the connection between evidence and conclusion and differentiate between an assertion and an argument. 

3.     Learning about limitations of the discipline: History is a way of studying the past but not all past is history. The historian needs a variety of tools to construct the past. Knowing about the strengths and limitations of those tools is part of historical practice.

Art and Craft of Sound [MS-3041] [MS-3041-1]

Faculty Name
Gaurav Chintamani [gaurav.chintamani@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

Of all the senses that we possess, hearing cannot be turned off voluntarily. One of the strongest tools in the arsenal of media professional, sound has the ability to construct, amplify and create more engaging narratives. Whether it is in the form of music or sound design, sound art or spoken word - Sound has the ability to attract and engage subliminally.

In this course we will deconstruct sound and explore the building blocks of audio from the lenses of its Nature, Behaviour and Interaction. We will engage with sound by breaking it down to its key components of physics, its interaction with space and different mediums, its translation and the how the selective processing and manipulation can direct the listeners interpretation of this engagement.

This will guide us through the levels of intervention that can be done in pre and post production through Digital Audio Workstations (DAW) to construct and curate the steps in the processing of sound. These techniques of bending sound can be applied to all forms of sound in various media; be it podcasting, audiobooks, music production, sound design and sound art.

Learning Outcomes
  • This course aims to provide a strong foundation in understanding the key components of sound, including the ability to visualise and interpret how sound interacts with different acoustic environments.
  • Students will learn to identify the skills necessary to record and manipulate audio, using post-production techniques to process and tweak audio for coherence and continuity in program material.
  • Throughout the course, students will develop the ability to make informed choices on recording equipment and techniques, navigate DAWs, and work with multitrack audio. They will also learn to engage with sound using processing tools, with a focus on the sound's emotional contour and context.
  • By the end of the course, students will be able to compile an audio story or podcast, including stock music and SFX, and render it for release with industry-standard audio specifications. This will ensure that the program material translates and sounds as intended across different playback systems.

Applied Econometrics [ECO-3515] [ECO-3515-1]

Faculty Name
Kanika Mahajan [kanika.mahajan@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

The course builds on the course work in introductory econometrics and its main objective is to equip students with econometric methods to undertake causal inference in economics. Both theory and its application will be the thrust of this course. It involves how to handle violation of OLS assumptions like homoscedasticity and no serial correlation, binary dependent variables, and causal methods for impact evaluation like instrumental variables, panel data, difference-in-differences, and regression discontinuity designs. Instruction combines lectures, class discussions, STATA demonstrations, and data-driven assignments. 

Prerequisites:Statistics; Introductory Econometrics

Learning Outcomes

Homework problems will be based on real datasets and are required to be submitted individually. Group discussions are allowed but plagiarism will be dealt with a fail grade on the assessment. For STATA based assessments, printouts of output should be accompanied with proper explanations and codes. Assignments must be submitted in time. Late submission will not be graded. Class discussion will be based on circulated articles and papers. 

Replication Exercise: Students will be required to work in teams of 2 (choose your team and inform me by 24th October, 2024. You need to select a paper from any of these journals: American Economic Review (AER), the American Economic Journals (AEJ: Applied Economics, Economic Policy), Quarterly Journal of Economics (QJE), Journal of Development Economics (JDE), American Journal of Political Science. You can choose papers from other journals too if the datasets are available online. Their websites host data files for recent years and also the computer programs for the results obtained in the papers. Each team will need to select a paper and download the associated files to replicate the main regression models. The “do” and the “log” files will be required to be submitted by each team. Two teams cannot work on the same topic (so first come, first served will be the criteria). The teams will under replication analysis/results and present it in a 15-minute presentation at the end of the course in which questions about the paper and how the results were replicated will be answered by the team members.

Attendance: Marks will not be based on attendance, but experience shows that it is highly correlated with final grade.

description:
From Amir Khusrau to Delhi Today: A Rhythmic History of the Urdu Verse [CLA-0051] [CLA-0051-1]

Overview

Taught by Shah Faisal Mushtaq

From Amir Khusrau to Mirza Ghalib, Delhi has, time and again, hosted many significant Urdu Ghazal poets. This course will take you through the vibrant soundscapes of Delhi's poetic history. From the courts of the Mughal emperors to the modern-day mushairas, we will explore the history of rhythm, rhyme, and language in the Urdu Ghazal. Beyond its traditional form, the course will explore the Ghazal's modern reinvention through diverse musical adaptations by prominent singers such as Mehdi Hasan and Nusrat Fateh Ali Khan.

Forms of Indian Music [CPA-0094] [CPA-0094-1]

Overview

Taught by Vighnesh Hampapura

A plethora of languages and cultures, alongside fraught but unbidden migrations and exchanges, has meant an abundance of musical forms in the subcontinent. We will explore as many different genres of music as possible and learn a composition in each. We will listen to and sing a gee gee pada, a bhavageeta, an abhang, rabindrasangeet, qawwali, ghazal, gaana, borgeet, tappa, thumri, nottuswara, etc.  We will also note a range of outliers, a Sufi tatvapada in Kannada, a Karnatik Christian hymn, and the "orchestra" film song. While also attending to their aesthetic histories and the socio-cultural ideas with which they work, our most intense focus, in trying out these musical genres, will be on their formal qualities. Our working assumption is that each form is complex. Along the way, we will also wonder about the categories of 'classical,' 'folk,' 'light,' 'regional,' and 'filmy' that are used to explain these forms, and consider what associations their usage creates.

Microbiome and Health [BIO-3457/ BIO-6457] [BIO-3457/ BIO-6457-1]

Faculty Name
Kavita Agarwal [kavita.agarwal@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

This course offers an engaging introduction to the world of the human microbiome and its growing significance in health and disease. We move beyond popular terms like probiotics and good bacteria to explore the microbiome as a dynamic and context-dependent system. Beginning with core concepts in microbiology, students will gain the essential background to understand microbial life, diversity, and interactions within the human body. You'll examine how microbial communities interact with each other and with the host, ranging from beneficial to pathogenic relationships, and how these shifts influence disease outcomes.

Throughout the course, we will:

  • Explore distinct microbial ecosystems across the human body—oral, gut, and vaginal microbiomes—and their roles in maintaining or disrupting health
  • Investigate the concept of microbiome dysbiosis and its contribution to site-specific and systemic diseases
  • Analyze how therapies such as antibiotics and probiotics affect microbial communities, and how microbiome-informed treatments are emerging
  • Study polymicrobial interactions, microbial cross-talk, and mechanisms like colonization resistance

The course will also introduce students to key experimental and clinical methodologies used in microbiome research—such as sequencing technologies, in vitro models, and study designs (cross-sectional vs. longitudinal)—and how these approaches influence findings and interpretations. An important emphasis of this course is on developing critical reading and analytical skills. Through guided discussions of primary research papers and reviews, students will learn how microbiome studies are designed and interpreted, how to evaluate the strength of scientific evidence, and how to thoughtfully engage with emerging ideas and controversies in the field. Assignments and projects will connect scientific concepts with real-world applications, including evaluating the claims and evidence behind consumer products like probiotics and hygiene products targeting microbiota.
By the end of the course, students will be equipped to critically assess microbiome research and appreciate its relevance in clinical practice, public health, and everyday life—all while gaining insight into one of the most rapidly evolving areas of biomedical science.

Learning Outcomes

After completing this course students should:
1. Understand the biology, diversity, and utility of microorganisms.
2. Explain what the microbiome is.
3. Describe how microbiota benefits the human body.
4. Explain how changes in microbiome are associated with adverse health outcomes.
5. Describe how microbiota targeting therapies work and what are the current challenges related to microbiome research.

In addition, by reading and evaluating relevant articles, students will become familiar with approaches used to solve research problems concerning microorganisms.

Books:
1. Human Microbiome [Clinical Implications and Therapeutic Interventions], Editors: Sabu Thomas
2. Microbiology: An Evolving Science by Slonczewski and Foster
Additional reading material, including latest research, will be shared in the class.

description:
Synthetic Biology [BIO-3455/ BIO-6455] [BIO-3455/ BIO-6455-1]

Faculty Name
Sandeep Ameta [sandeep.ameta@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

The biological systems are complex but work as a well-controlled machine that can be engineered for societal benefit. This course aims to introduce students to the exciting field of synthetic biology to teach them how biological systems can be reprogrammed using a synthetic and systems approach. The course is divided into three modules (M). M1: Tools of Synthetic Biology, which will cover from understanding synthetic availabilities (DNA, RNA, peptides) to manipulation tools (regulators, expression systems). M2: Implementation in the Regulation of Biological Systems. It will cover the basics of gene network organization, regulation, artificial/synthetic networks, and gene circuits. M3: Synthetic Cells and Evolving Systems. This module will cover the work around Minimal Cell Research (Minimal cell/Craig Ventor) and bottom-up approaches (Origins of Life Perspective).

This course is designed to be interdisciplinarily, and all the concepts required for understanding will be taught in the class. However, a basic understanding of Molecular Biology, Cell Biology, and Biochemistry will be really helpful.

Learning Outcomes

At the end of this course, the students should be familiarized with the following ideas and concepts:

  • Basic principles and tools of synthetic biology.
  • Designing and analyzing gene networks and gene circuits.
  • State of the field and achievements of synthetic biology
Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

This course will be mostly based on research papers and reviews. The following books can be referred to:

  • Synthetic Biology-A Primer (by Geoff Baldwin, Imperial College Press)
  • Synthetic Biology Vol I (Robert Meyers, Wiley Publications).

Additionally, reading material in the form of lecture slides, papers and notes will be circulated.

Chemical Biology [CHM-6604/ CHM-4001] [CHM-6604/ CHM-4001-1]

Faculty Name
Sourav Chatterjee [sourav.chatterjee@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

Course Description (Course details is attached)

This course is an undergraduate elective and a course for PhD program. This course is suitable to students who have a particular interest in understanding how modern chemistry tools and techniques are being utilized to correlate detailed molecular structure with biological function and address biological questions to give a broad overview in the field of chemical biology. This course offers the branch of chemistry concepts, techniques and methods used to drive the future advancement of chemical biology subject area.

Special Features

Chemical biology is the application of chemistry toward solving biological problems. This course helps students who wish to go for higher studies to understand molecular level of diseases using chemistry tools. The assignments to be given during this course would help students to read current journal articles more focused on problem-based learning approaches. Graduate students are expected to cultivate their intellectual curiosity and develop problem-solving approaches in chemical biology, enhancing their professional growth and potential to make a significant impact.

Learning Outcomes

Upon completion of this course, students will have the opportunity to develop a comprehensive subject-specific knowledge and understanding of the subject area of chemical biology.

Upon completion of the course, the student should be able to:

- understand the principles of chemistry techniques to integrate the nature of chemical reactions in biological systems at the molecular level.

- acquire relevant scientific information using textbook reading, literature database searches or other public domain tools in their assignments and presentations.

- have deeper knowledge necessary for continued studies within the subject area of chemical biology.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Books/Reading Materaials

1. Essentials of Chemical Biology - Structure and Dynamics of Biological Macromolecules: Julian A. Tanner, and Andrew D. Miller.

2. Introduction to Bioorganic Chemistry and Chemical Biology: David Van Vranken, and Gregory A. Weiss.

3. Lehninger’s Principles of Biochemistry: Cox and Nelson.

4. Chemical Biology: Techniques and Applications B. Larijani, C. A. Rosser, R. Woscholski.

5. Lippincott's Illustrated Q&A Review of Biochemistry: Michael A. Lieberman, and Rick Ricer.

6. Advanced Chemical Biology: Howard C. Hang, Matthew R. Pratt, and Jennifer A. Prescher.

7. Biochemistry: Voet and Voet

8. The molecules of life: Physical and chemical principles. Kuriyan, Konforti & Wemmer.

courseTitle: History of Biomedicine: Germ Theory to Digital Health
description:
History of Biomedicine: Germ Theory to Digital Health [HIS-2511/ BIO-2333] [HIS-2511/ BIO-2333-1]

Faculty Name
Projit Bihari Mukharji [projit.mukharji@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

This course explores the history of modern biomedicine over the last 150 years. It's intention however, is not simply to provide a chronology of technological advances. Rather, it will show how historical analysis can open up new ways of thinking about the relationship between medicine and society. We saw during the recent pandemic that medical matters are seldom, if ever, only about developments in the laboratory. The clinician, the nurse, the pharmacist, the vaccine-manufacturer, the politician, the policeman and even the odd religious figure, not to mention the patient and her family, are all crucial to the way medical events play out in society. Each of these characters and their mutual relationships are structured by history. It is these historically evolving relationships that this course will explore. Additionally, a sub-theme of the course would also be to look at the role of technology in mediating the relationship between health and society. It will do this using a small set of case studies around key moments in modern medical history such as the development of Germ Theory, Randomized Clinical Trials, Transplants, Genetic Screening, MRIs, Telemedicine and Digital Health. 

Learning Outcomes
Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

There is no single text book for the course. But students would be expected to read a maximum of two academic articles a week and watch a short film.

Programming Languages and Translation [CS-3340] [CS-3340-1]

Faculty Name
Partha Pratim Das [partha.das@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

Programming languages are the expressive medium of computation. From early pioneers like FORTRAN and LISP to today’s multi-paradigm giants such as Python, C++, and Haskell, languages have evolved to capture the growing diversity of human and machine needs. This course offers a deep dive into the semantics and translation of programming languages: how programs mean what they mean, and how they are transformed for execution on real machines.

We explore core semantic models – operational, denotational, and axiomatic – to formally reason about program behaviour across paradigms including imperative, object-oriented, functional, and logic programming. Alongside theory, the course emphasizes practice: students will design and implement components of a full language translator. Using tools like Flex and Bison, they will develop a working compiler for a small C-like language, generating and optimizing code down to machine level.

By linking high-level abstraction with low-level execution, the course prepares students to critically evaluate language design, contribute to compiler development, or even create new languages tailored to emerging domains.

Learning Outcomes

This course deals with the issues of semantics and translation of programming languages. Explore how we can express the semantics or meaning of programming languages across multiple paradigms such as functional, procedural, object-oriented, generic / meta-programming, and logic, through various models of operational, denotational, and axiomatic semantics. And once we have a clear semantics, how we efficiently translate programs in different languages to machine models for execution.

By the end of this course, students will be able to:

  1. Understand and formally reason about programming language semantics using foundational models like λ-calculus, type systems, and operational / denotational semantics, enabling precise specification and analysis of program behaviour across paradigms.
  2. Apply semantic principles to evaluate language constructs and paradigms, equipping students to critically compare languages (imperative, object-oriented, functional, logical) and understand design choices in modern programming languages.
  3. Design and implement core components of language translators, such as lexical analysers, parsers, intermediate representations, and symbol tables, using tools like Flex and Bison to transform high-level code into executable form.
  4. Build and optimize runtime structures and code generation pipelines, including control flow analysis and local optimizations, to understand how high-level language constructs are supported and executed efficiently on modern machines.
  5. Develop the ability to connect high-level programming concepts with low-level execution mechanisms, fostering skills to create domain-specific languages, enhance compilers, or contribute to language design and implementation projects.
Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

It is necessary to have completed the following course before attending this one. It is a pre-requisite on AMS:

  • Data Structure and algorithms

In addition, it is expected that the students attending this course have

  1. Taken Theory of Computation (ToC) earlier. While students will be permitted to attend this course without ToC too, they will need to go through additional reading and discussion sessions to catch up on the concepts of Finite and Pushdown Automata.
  2. Prior experience in programming in C. Familiarity with C++, Python and OCAML would be useful. Students not having these, would need to work additionally to catch up on these.

Advanced Algorithms [CS-5211] [CS-5211-1]

Faculty Name
Sandeep Sen [sandeep.sen@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

This course is designed to apprise students who have acquired knowledge of basic design techniques and analysis of recent advances in the field related to approximation algorithms, randomized techniques, dynamic data structures as well as alternate models like parallel, streaming etc.

Topics covered will include randomized algorithm basics and concentration bounds, approximation algorithm techniques like primal-dual and local search,  algorithms for geometric problems like Convex hulls, Voronoi diagrams, planar point location and range-searching, dynamic graph algorithms like connectivity, shortest paths, basic parallel algorithms  for sorting searching and prefix computation, streaming algorithms for large data like frequency moments and min-count sketch

Learning Outcomes
  • Evaluate the performance of heuristics in a rigorous framework
  • Design and analyse algorithms in other (beyond RAM) models of computation
  • A deeper understanding of the basic design techniques and advanced data structures
  • Applications to fundamental combinatorial problems in graphs and geometry
Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Reference text books  : (Additional material will be given out as required)

  1. Randomized Algorithms, R. Motwani and P. Raghavan
  2. The Design of Approximation algorithms,  Williamson and Shmoys
  3. Design and Analysis of Algorithms – a contemporary perspective, S.Sen and A. Kumar

Information Security [CS-3610] [CS-3610-1]

Faculty Name
Subhashis Banerjee [suban@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

Introduction to security. Trust vs verifiability. Adversarial threat models. Notions of secrecy, privacy, and security. Basics of cryptography - symmetric and public key encryption, authentication,
hash functions, digital signatures, certificates, cryptographic protocols, and applications. Cryptographic security definitions. Models of authentication and authorisation; biometrics; identity. Issues with verification of hardware and software integrity; the frameworks of formal verification and model checking. Trust assumptions, distributing trust with secure multiparty computations, hardware trust models, trusted
computing environments and remote attestation. Elements of OS and Network security.

Learning Outcomes

This course will help students understand and model information security in the modern world. It covers various definitional basics of cryptography, models of trust, adversaries, etc. helping students reason concretely about real-world problems.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Data Structures and Algorithms, Probability and Statistics

- Solve recurrences and structure proofs

As part of the course outcome, students will:

- Learn about the wide variety of data structures available and how they can completely change how we approach problems, with the aim of being able to recognize when and how to apply this knowledge

Understanding audio visual production [MS-1567] [MS-1567-1]

Faculty Name
Natasha Badhwar [natasha.badhwar@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

This course will introduce students to audio and video production at an introductory level. Through a series of viewings of historical and contemporary documentary films and readings, students will understand the formats, power and tools of audio visual communication, grasp basic concepts and terminology around production and be introduced to media ethics.

The course will explore the increasing predominance of visual media in contemporary life and the various ways in which traditional narrative forms of storytelling are being replaced by visual forms of storytelling in journalism, photojournalism, film, television, the internet, video games, anime, graphic novels, and advertising. Students will view and analyse films on the basis of  documentary modes as proposed by documentary theorist Bill Nichols - poetic, expository, observational, participatory, reflexive, and performative.

Students will receive basic training in professional video production and use of equipment, as well as post-production practices and software, with an emphasis on establishing effective communication and collaborative skills. Special emphasis will be paid on composition, light and texture in photography and its affective impact on the viewer. The use of movement, sound and transition techniques in editing will be observed and put into practice.

Through a series of practical exercises, they will learn low-budget production methodologies including basic studio production - and the many open-source software tools and platforms that can facilitate video production.

Learning Outcomes

Students will become familiar with the long arc of the history and development of audio-visual expression and the technologies that have enabled them.

They will learn about the power and resonance of audio-visual expression through guided exercises in components of photography, videography and video editing.

courseTitle: Subjective Well-Being: The Science of Happiness
description:
Subjective Well-Being: The Science of Happiness [PSY-4062] [PSY-4062-1]

Faculty Name
Tithi Bhatnagar [tithi.bhatnagar@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

Subjective well-being (SWB, often referred to as happiness) pertains to people's evaluations of their lives, encompassing both cognitive judgments, such as life satisfaction, and affective evaluations, including positive and negative feelings. People are said to have high SWB if satisfied with their lives and experience frequent positive and infrequent negative emotions. Understanding this concept can be very beneficial for leading a rewarding life in every sphere of an individual's life, both internal and external. It helps individuals identify what is important in leading a good and meaningful life. It helps them realize their inner potential and the strength of their psychological treasure to mitigate life circumstances, and how to develop the right approach to face and deal with adverse conditions. This is a reflection and evidence-based course that aims to equip students with strategies to optimize their SWB by reflecting on the learning from the science and applying it to their experiences.

Learning Outcomes

To understand the basic concepts, theories, frameworks, correlates, and measurement issues in Subjective Well-Being

To facilitate the understanding and definition of students’ sense of well-being.

To learn concepts that help develop a positive approach toward life and life events.

To develop a knowledge of well-being interventions and critically engage with them to find one’s best fit.

To appreciate, assess, and apply the various strategies that can be used to optimize SWB.

To create a personalized well-being framework.

Organisational Psychology [PSY-3065/ ENT-3017] [PSY-3065/ ENT-3017-1]

Faculty Name
Mary Jane Arneaud [mary.arneaud@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

The course examines concepts, theory, and research from psychology, but also related disciplines, to understand human behavior in organizational settings. Topics such as motivation, feelings, attitudes, and group dynamics are examined from both the perspective of the organizational members (e.g., employees) and the organization. The course has an applied emphasis and aims to prepare a student for entry and participation in any type of organization.

Learning Outcomes

The course Learning Outcomes are for you to:

  • Gain insight into how to be more productive and successful as an individual worker, and how to manage the work of other people in ways that they find motivating and satisfying.
  • Apply concepts, theory, and research to understand and address concrete organizational problems.
  • Comfortably discuss information about Organizational Psychology with your peers.
  • Develop writing skills through the process of completing two structured assignments.
  • Learn what careers in Organizational Psychology involve and how Organizational Psychology fits into the broader spectrum of specialization areas within psychology.
  • For those students interested in a career in this area: prepare for higher level courses in Organizational Psychology or Human Resource Management by learning important foundational material to draw on in future classes.
Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Pre-requisites: Introduction to Psychology and Social Psychology

Audit requirements: You will earn AU (versus AUF - audit failed) by way of a passing mark on the second course assignment.

For the first week of class, please read the following two articles:

Cable, D. A. J. (2013). The career experiences of industrial and organisational psychology graduates. New Zealand Journal of Psychology, 42(1), 5–12. https://www.psychology.org.nz/journal-archive/Cable3.pdf

Javidan, M., Dorfman, P. W., De Luque, M. S., & House, R. J. (2006). In the eye of the beholder: Cross cultural lessons in leadership from project GLOBE. Academy of Management Perspectives, 20(1), 67–90. https://journals.aom.org/doi/10.5465/amp.2006.19873410

description:
A History of History [HIS-5013/ HIS-4013] [HIS-5013/ HIS-4013-1]

Faculty Name
Nayanjot Kaur Lahiri [nayanjot.lahiri@ashoka.edu.in] ,Rudrangshu Mukherjee [rudrangshu.mukherjee@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

This course seeks to impart a sense of the building blocks of the discipline of history, through important works of history and through the writings of historians on their craft. What ideas of the past can be seen from antiquity till the present?  How have the concerns of history changed? What constitute the facts of history and how are these ascertained? What constitute the protocols of historical discourse? These are questions that will be examined with reference to the works of various historians and scholars within and outside academia.  

 

Learning Outcomes

Tbrough a deep dive into the writings of historians, students will have a better understanding of the building blocks of history and how ideas of the past have changed over time.

Design Practices in CS [CS-3810] [CS-3810-1]

Faculty Name
Partha Pratim Das [partha.das@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

This course introduces students to structured design practices in computer science, bridging foundational knowledge in data structures, algorithms, and systems with the real-world challenges of software development. It emphasizes hands-on experience in designing, implementing, testing, and maintaining software systems through iterative project work.

Students will engage with the full software development lifecycle - from requirement analysis and modelling (using UML) to implementation (primarily in C/C++ as well as mixed languages), testing, debugging, and deployment. Alongside, they will explore essential tools and techniques, including version control (Git), build automation, documentation systems (LaTeX, Doxygen), and issue tracking.

The course also introduces emerging AI-based development tools that aid in coding, debugging, and maintenance. The projects will be completed individually or in small teams, encouraging collaboration, reuse of code, and design thinking. In the end, students will be equipped with the mindset and skills to approach software engineering tasks in a methodical and efficient way, preparing them for academic and industry-level software projects.

Learning Outcomes

This course familiarizes students with the design and development of software projects in collaborative mode, building on their learning of data structures, algorithms, systems, and other core CS courses. The students work individually or in small groups, start with a descriptive specification of the projects, and take them through the entire software development lifecycle.

By the end of this course, the students will learn:

  1. To handle software development life cycles comprising multiple stages like
    • Problem specification and requirement analysis
    • Software modelling (in UML) and design specification (with classes and interfaces)
    • Software implementation (coding) and debugging
    • Software testing and feedback analysis
  2. To use various common software tools for
    • Modelling & Design
    • IDE for Coding & Debugging
    • Documentation
    • Test planning & Testing
    • Issue Management
    • Version Control
  3. To use AI tools for software development, debugging, and maintenance
  4. To use and reuse libraries, to deploy & configure software, etc. 
  5. To deploy software systems on a cloud platform (AWS, Azure) and configure APIs, Databases, Static Storage, etc.
Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

It is necessary to have completed the following courses before attending this one. These are pre-requisites on AMS:

  1. Data Structures and Algorithms (DSA)
  2. Computer Organization and Systems (COS)

In addition, it is expected that the students attending this course have

  1. Strong familiarity of Database Management Systems (DBMS). While students will be permitted to attend this course without DBMS too, they will need to go through additional reading and discussion sessions to catch up on the concepts of relational databases and SQL.
  2. Good familiarity with handling on concurrency (as is typical in Operating Systems). Students not having these, would need to work additionally to catch up on the concepts of processes, threads, mutual exclusion, critical section, semaphore, etc. and programming with POSIX (or some similar thread models).
  3. Prior experience in programming in C and C++. Familiarity with Python, GUI design, and Web Development would be useful. Students not having these, would need to work additionally to catch up on these.
  4. Good familiarity with AI, ML, and LLMs. Students not having these, would need to work additionally to catch up on these, especially GenAI for coding.

Artificial Intelligence [CS-4440] [CS-4440-1]

Faculty Name
Lipika Dey [lipika.dey@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

Artificial Intelligence (AI) stands at the intersection of philosophy, logic, computation, and cognition - shaping the future of how people and machines interact with each other.  This course offers a comprehensive introduction to the core concepts and methodologies that define the field of AI. Beginning with the philosophical foundations of designing  intelligent agents that can perceive, reason, and act, the course will then delve into how knowledge is represented for reasoning with it. It will include logic-based systems, ontologies, and knowledge graphs. The course will then move over to discuss uncertainty, which is a key challenge in real-world. Different kinds of frameworks like Bayesian networks, probabilistic inference, and causal reasoning will be discussed. Foundational concepts of reinforcement learning and decision theory will be discussed to reveal how intelligent systems are designed to make choices under uncertainty and conflicting objectives. The course will conclude with discussions on Trustable AI examining fairness, transparency, accountability, and ethical concerns in AI systems.

Topics to be covered
1. Introduction - Philosophy of AI, Intelligent Agents
2. Problem Solving - Uninformed Search, Heuristic search, Adversarial search, Constraint
satisfaction problems
3. Knowledge Representation - Logic and reasoning, Ontology and knowledge graphs
4. Handling Uncertainty - Bayesian Networks, Learning and Inference over Bayesian
Networks, Introduction to Causality

5. Learning - Learning probabilistic models, Knowledge in learning, Reinforcement
Learning

6. Decision Theory - Simple and Complex Decision making

7. Agentic AI frameworks for building autonomous systems

8. Trustable AI

Learning Outcomes

1. Learn about representing real world problems as AI problems
2. Learn to apply AI techniques for problem solving

3. Learn Logic and reasoning
3. Judge applicability of AI techniques for solving real world problems
4. Is knowledgeable about the needs to make AI systems trustable

 

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Artificial Intelligence – A Modern Approach (3rd Edition) – By Stuart Russell & Peter Norvig

Cryptography [CS-3621] [CS-3621-1]

Faculty Name
Mahabir Prasad Jhanwar [mahavir.jhawar@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

Course Coverage:

Symmetric key cryptography: Symmetric Key Encryption, Pseudorandom number generators (PRG), Pseudorandom functions (PRF), Stream cipher, Block cipher, Modes of Operation, Security definitions for Encryption, Message integrity, Message authentication codes, Hash Functions.

Public key cryptography: Diffie-Hellman key exchange, Discrete logarithm problem and its variants. Public key encryption (PKE), security definition. ElGamal  PKE. Factoring and RSA problem. RSA PKE. Digital Signature. RSA and DSA signature schemes. Elliptic curves and ECDSA signature scheme. 

Efficient cryptographic operations and cryptanalysis algorithms: Modular arithmetic, modular inverse, modular exponents, prime number generation, picking generators for cyclic groups. Algorithms for discrete logarithm and factoring. 

Cryptography Applications: Public key infrastructure (PKI), Brief Introduction to TLS.

Advanced Cryptography Concepts (if time permits): Commitment Schemes, Secret Sharing, Oblivious Transfer, Zero knowledge Proofs, Multiparty Computation.

Course Outline:

Confidentiality/privacy of communication, symmetric-key encryption (SKE); basic security definition

Toy SKEs: shift cipher, affine cipher, substitution cipher

Exhaustive key search attack, large key space being necessary but not sufficient

Advanced security definitions for SKE

Computational vs Unconditional/Information theoretic Security 

Basics of Information theoretic security

Design of SKE with indistinguishability security (ind-security)

Pseudo random generator (PRG), PRG $\implies$ SKE with ind-security

Design of SKE with ind-cpa security

Pseudo random function (PRF), PRF $\implies$ SKE with ind-cpa security

Stream cipher, Block cipher, Modes of operation

Pseudo random permutation (PRP)

Construction framework: Substitution-permutation network (SPN)

Advanced encryption standard (AES)

Message Integrity, Message authentication codes (MAC), MAC security 

Construction of MACs from PRF, ECBC-MAC

Hash function, security, random-oracle construction

Merkle-Demgard construction for hash functions

MAC from hash function, HMAC

SKE with Ind-cca security 

Privacy + integrity: encrypt and authenticate; authenticate then encrypt; encrypt then authenticate 

Key exchange; Diffie-Hellman key exchange 

Discrete logarithm problem (DLP), Computational Diffie-Hellman (CDH) problem 

Algorithms for DLP

Public-key encryption (PKE) scheme, security definitions

ElGamal PKE, Ind-cpa security proof of ElGamal, Decision Diffie-Hellman Problem

Efficient algorithms for ElGamal components

RSA PKE

Efficient algorithms for RSA components

Digital Signature scheme, security definitions

RSA signature, Schnorr signature, DSA scheme

Public key infrastructure (PKI)

Transport layer security (TLS)

 

Learning Outcomes

Privacy, secrecy, and security are central to our emerging “information society”, and cryptography is a key technology for achieving them; it is also a fascinating field of study in its own right. This course serves as an introduction to modern cryptography.

Students will first understand the foundational goals of cryptography - confidentiality, integrity, and authenticity - and learn how to rigorously formalize these goals through precise security definitions. They will study key cryptographic primitives - encryption, hash/MACs, and digital signatures - as tools to achieve these goals.

They will explore the conceptual and historical progression of encryption: beginning with symmetric-key encryption, advancing to key exchange, and culminating in public-key encryption (PKE). Students will also understand why combining symmetric and public-key techniques, as in real-world protocols like TLS, offers both efficiency and security for secure internet communication.

Throughout the course, students will appreciate the role of mathematical hardness assumptions (like factoring and discrete log) in securing cryptographic systems, and how security proofs reduce cryptographic security to these underlying problems. They will also gain hands-on experience implementing core cryptographic primitives and applying them to build real-world applications where security is paramount.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Pre-requisites:

Introduction to Computer Science

Discrete Mathematics

Probability and Statistics. 

While not compulsory, prior completion of the Algebra 1 course offered by the Mathematics Department will be a significant advantage.

References:

Introduction to Modern Cryptography, Jonathan Katz and Yehuda Lindell, CRC Press

Cryptography - Theory and Practice, Douglas R. Stinson and Maura B. Paterson, CRC Press

Applied Cryptography, Dan Boneh and Victor Shoup

description:
Piecing Together Our Past: Archaeology, History and Science [HIS-3160] [HIS-3160-1]

Faculty Name
Akash Srinivas [akash.srinivas@ashoka.edu.in] ,Nayanjot Kaur Lahiri [nayanjot.lahiri@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

Course Description

This course aims to explore and combine archaeology, history and the application of sciences for the study of our past. What are the similarities and differences between archaeology and history? How have scientific methods extended the boundaries of our past? Diverse contexts - from city life in Rome and Pompeii to rock art sites in Australia and South Asia - will figure here. The specific areas of research that will be covered range from diseases and epidemics to investigating environments on the ground and through remote sensing, from the radiocarbon revolution to recovering the biological lives and lineages of past people. The course will be of interest to all students who are curious about how the past has been pieced together through the intersection of the humanities and the sciences.  Lectures,  book readings and film excerpts will be supplemented by a workshop on the science of making stone tools through hands-on exercises as also a field visit highlighting the conversations between archaeology and history on the ground.

Learning Outcomes

An appreciation and awareness that the past as we know it is an outcome of research and conversations across disciplines.

Readings will be emailed to students

courseTitle: History and the Art of Reading
description:
History and the Art of Reading [HIS-5850] [HIS-5850-1]

Faculty Name
Eloise Wright [eloise.wright@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

How is it the case that two people can read the same text and come up with contrasting interpretations? Why does a reader encountering a newly-written text find a different meaning in it than readers years or generations later? Can we ever really know what meaning an author intended? As historians, we read constantly: historical sources from different time periods and places, empirical and theoretical work by historians and scholars from other disciplines. We read in different languages and formats, on screens, paper, stone, or bronze, via images and material objects. In this class, we will examine the processes by which readers make meaning out of texts, that is, hermeneutics, in the context of historical scholarship.

In the first half of the class we will explore three historical hermeneutical traditions: German phenomenology, Chinese classicism, and Russian Marxism. By reading key texts from each tradition, we will encounter a range of approaches to the problems of reading and interpretation. In the second half of the class, we will consider these ideas (and others) applied to real-world situations: ethnographic studies of reading as an embodied practice, problems of translation between languages and scripts, and social practices of reading within the university context.

Tending Cloth [CVA-0104] [CVA-0104-1]

Overview

Taught by Kairvee

This course is a gentle invitation to slow down and listen—to cloth, to time, to the quiet stories held in a stain. Through simple acts of visible mending and staining, students will explore ways of extending the life of worn garments while honouring the histories they carry. Stains are often seen as blemishes, marks to be erased, but here, we will consider them as records of a body moving through time, of meals shared, of work done with love. Mending, too, is not merely repair but an offering, a visible trace of care and resilience. Together, we will embrace stitches as storytelling and stains as maps of lived experience, learning hand-sewing techniques and experimental staining methods using natural pigments and everyday spills. Through shared ceremonies, we will stain with intention, marking cloth collectively while exploring the personal and social meanings of stains. The students will leave the course with mended garments, a collection of memories through stained fabrics imbued with personal and collective meaning and a reimagined relationship with the objects they wear every day.

courseTitle: The Past is Never Truly Gone But Rather Lingers On in the Present
description:
The Past is Never Truly Gone But Rather Lingers On in the Present [CVA-0105] [CVA-0105-1]

Overview

Taught by Vikrant Kano

This course is about understanding how the past continues to influence our lives today. The student will explore the idea that history is not just something that happened long ago, but something that still lives on in our memories and stories. Offering students a chance to engage with history in a personal and creative way, students will learn how to explore it through sensory experiences– sounds, images, moving images, painting, collages and personal narratives.  Using personal histories documented through photo albums and documents, the course encourages students to collect and preserve these stories. The goal is to build an archive of memories and records that helps people better understand their socio-political environment and their own family histories.

courseTitle: The Material Speaks: Sculpture, Installation and Meaning
description:
The Material Speaks: Sculpture, Installation and Meaning [CVA-0106] [CVA-0106-1]

Overview

Taught by Ashra

The student is invited to explore the expressive and conceptual possibilities of three-dimensional art. Moving beyond conventional sculpture, students will work with a wide array of media—ranging from jute, cardboard, clay, and fabric to found and everyday objects—to discover how materials communicate meaning, memory, and emotion. Through hands-on experimentation and guided reflection, students will learn to observe how texture, structure, and context influence interpretation. Practical exploration is combined with discussions of key contemporary and historical works, introducing practices such as installation, assemblage, site-specific interventions, and performative sculpture. The course also encourages sustainability and personal storytelling, prompting students to think critically about material choices and their social and ecological resonances.

Digital Interventions in Art [CVA-0107] [CVA-0107-1]

Overview

Taught by Nischal Bhardwaj

What happens when traditional visual media meet real-time interaction, sound and moving images? This course explores the intersection between material art practices and emerging digital technologies. Crucial to the course are three powerful tools: TouchDesigner for real-time generative visuals, projection mapping techniques for site-specific installations, and Touch Board sensors that make painted and sculpted surfaces interactive and touch-responsive. Basic principles of visual programming and sound interaction, the prototyping of interactive paintings and projection-based installations will be imparted.  At the same time the contemplation of the implications of working at the intersection of the tangible and the virtual, questioning traditional notions of medium, viewer participation and sensory experience, will be encouraged.

description:
Form and Texture: Exploring Plaster Sculpture and Relief Work [CVA-0109] [CVA-0109-1]

Overview

Course Title- Form & Texture: Exploring Plaster Sculpture and Relief Work

Taught by Anuj Kumar Yadav

An introduction to the creative possibilities of plaster of Paris for sculptural and relief-based art, in this course students will learn casting, carving, moulding, and surface treatment. The emphasis is on the development of spatial reasoning and material understanding through the building  of foundational skills such as safe plaster handling, mould-making and basic relief work. Students will also experiment with low and high-relief sculpture, subtractive carving methods and advanced mould-making techniques. They will also learn how to combine plaster with other materials such as wood and fabric, and explore a variety of surface treatments including painting, staining, and embedding.

Katha: Performance and Story [CLA-0055] [CLA-0055-1]

Overview

Taught by Sandhydeep Tripathi

Through other people's stories we can understand our own stories better. This course is an exploration, a location and a sharing of stories or kathas- both your own as well as those of others- through the prism of subcontinental story-telling traditions.  All texts in the course are written in one of the tongues loosely grouped under the umbrella of Hindi. Starting from Ramlila and Kalidas, we will move forward, touching upon Kabir and many others until we reach Seedhe Maut, the rapper duo from Delhi. We will also look at how forms travel and transform, how a  “daastan" goes around. This will be done through historical examples, the Jataka Tales becoming  Arabian Nights, etc. The course involves performative speaking through the sharing of stories, the recitation of poems and the enactment of scenes from important contemporary plays in Hindi and Urdu.

* Fluency in Hindi is a prerequisite for this course.

courseTitle: Pakhawaj: Drum of Resonance and Rhythm
description:
Pakhawaj: Drum of Resonance and Rhythm [CPA-0105] [CPA-0105-1]

Overview

Taught by Mohan Shyam Sharma

This course is an experiential introduction to the rhythmic world of North Indian music through the lens of the pakhawaj, an ancient barrel-shaped drum associated with the Dhrupad tradition. Through a blend of vocal rhythm recitation (padhant), body movement, and hands-on practice on clay or wooden pakhāwaj drums, students will explore the structure and aesthetic logic of cyclical rhythm. A key element of the course is internalising rhythm not only through sound but also through gesture, repetition, and group coordination. Students will also learn basic compositional forms such as ṭhekā, tihāī, and paran, and will be encouraged to engage in guided improvisation and collaborative play.

Mohiniyattam: The Politics of Grace [CPA-0106] [CPA-0106-1]

Overview

Taught by Sreelekshmi 

An introduction to the basic practical aspects of this dance form will contribute to the learners’ awareness of body and movement quality. Through the practitioners’ bodies, the course also nudges the learners to reflect upon questions of gender, caste, positionality and nationalism intertwined in the state of this art form.  Mohiniyattam is synonymous with the idea of ‘grace’. However, the course through its practice mode investigates ‘what’ contributes to this grace and ‘who’ is considered graceful and ‘why’ is this grace relevant in today’s times in the evolution of the practice of the form. The course is ideal for anyone who is interested in the intersection of identity, body, movement and performance.

Taught by Kana Kitaoka

This course offers both a physical and intellectual understanding of Kalarippayattu, a traditional martial art from Kerala. The student will learn how this ancient art form intersects with modern globalised practices and how it may evolve in the future to become a universal and inclusive practice accessible to all.

Each class will begin by focussing on the active physicality of the art. By the end of the  course, students will be able to embody key animal movements and perform some movement sequences. Kalarippayattu’s cultural and historical contexts will also be introduced. In addition, this art’s current significance in contemporary fitness and sports industries as well as the distinction between performance arts and competitive sports will be discussed.

courseTitle: Kathak Se Kahan Tak: Dance in the everyday
description:
Kathak Se Kahan Tak: Dance in the everyday [CPA-0110] [CPA-0110-1]

Overview

Taught by Abhay Tole Trivedi

This course is an entry into kathak- a syncretic dance form that has assimilated many social, political, religious and artistic influences. Movement, voice, music and acting- our practice will draw from all of these. We will also integrate theatre games, ensemble work, yoga and even some crafts into our practice. The unique movement features of kathak dance will be introduced. Discussions about the history of kathak dance and the body will lead us to question the idea of form; is there something inherent to kathak that makes it a form? 

In addition, the course seeks to go beyond the otherwise rigid boundaries of form to explore the infinite expressive possibilities of the body in motion. The classes will be a  creative space for students to come as they are and “play” with kathak, making it a part of their “everyday” instead of the performative “classical” art that is forever out of reach.

courseTitle: India: A Short History of English News
description:
India: A Short History of English News [MS-2116] [MS-2116-1]

Faculty Name
Tisha Srivastav [tisha.srivastav@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

India: A short history of English news
This is a media literacy course on news in the English language and focuses on
the Indian news landscape only. It introduces its unique trajectory, broad
tendencies and landmark events. With key highlights in coverage over an 80-year period, from the
earliest reception of Ambedkar in the visual media of the 1930s to a generation of freedom fighters
writing columns in newspapers to the days of the Emergency.
As a general course on becoming literate about how news works and its coverage has evolved, it is
significantly different from the newswriting and reporting course, also offered once a year by the
Media Studies department. 

Course cap 25. This course has no prerequisites.

Learning Outcomes

Know India’s unique news history, without needing to become a journalist.
Offers a journalism history primer and tools to understand and analyse news.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Monday & Wednesday 11.50 - 1.20 pm

Week 1 - 5 1930 -1970s

Week 6 - 8 Emergency

Week 9 - 13 TV/ Emergence of the middle class/ Economy & Politics (Budget)/ Concentration of media ownership & era of self-censorship + Ratings

The course will include an immersive workshop with the Ashoka Archive of Contemporary India. There will also be a Guest Lecture by Himal's Editor in Chief

Mobility and Power in Eurasia, 800-1800 [HIS-3100/ SOA-3157/ POL-3119] [HIS-3100/ SOA-3157/ POL-3119-1]

Faculty Name
Pratyay Nath [pratyay.nath@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

What made monarchs constantly travel across their kingdoms with their camps and households? What has historically been the relationships between places, spaces, mobilities, and immobilities? What did the lavish tents and travelling households of rulers look like? How would military campaigns, hunting expeditions, and religious pilgrimage constantly intersect in the course of royal travel? These are some of the questions this course investigates. It offers a social understanding of mobility from the perspective of the political elite. Drawing upon the new field of mobility studies, it analyses the workings of mobility as a form of royal power, aristocratic lifestyle, and state governance in Eurasian history. Temporally, we will focus on the medieval and early modern periods (800-1800). Spatially, we will look at England, Europe, the Ottoman Empire, Iran, South Asia, China, and Central Asia. We will study journeys, roads, routes, as well as the camps and gardens as conduits and nodes in elite travel. We will explore the social world of the mobile encampment, the logistical roles of mobile human and nonhuman labour, and the myriad political, recreational, and performative functions of royal journeys. We will finish by studying how the advent of modernity impacted the politics of royal mobility.

NB: This History elective is cross-listed with Political Science and Sociology/Anthropology. There are no prerequisites for taking this course.

Learning Outcomes

By the end of the course, the students will be able to think critically about the politics and sociology of royal travel in history. This will enable them to rethink the workings of monarchical power, question the familiar sedentary forms of modern political power, reflect on the social world of travel, labour, and infrastructure, and venture into the new multidisciplinary field of mobility studies. 

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

India-China; Distant Neighbours [IR-3035] [IR-3035-1]

Faculty Name
Shivshankar Menon [shivshankar.menon@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

This twelve week course of lectures studies the dynamic and dissonance in India-China relations since 1950. India and China are both similar and different in fundamental ways in their politics, choice of development strategies, foreign economic and security choices, and in their dealings with each other and the outside world. The course first examines chronologically the factors that affected India-China relations, its international context, and the role of personalities, structures and strategic culture as it evolved over seven decades. It then focuses on the present, on the new geopolitics of Asia, China, India, and their interests and policy choices today. From a practitioners point of view, it considers how and why they are what they are today, and the increasingly important role that these re-risen Asian giants now play in international relations.

Learning Outcomes

The course seeks to give students a sense of Asian geopolitics, non-Western IR, and of the domestic and other drivers of policy choices in India and China.

courseTitle: Visual configurations of the Body, Gender and Identity in Indian Manuscript Paintings (1100-1900)
description:
Visual configurations of the Body, Gender and Identity in Indian Manuscript Paintings (1100-1900) [VA-2830] [VA-2830-1]

Faculty Name
Priyani Roy Choudhury [priyani.choudhury@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

Laur attempts to climb up to Chanda's bed chamber, Laur-Chanda, Rylands Collection, University of Manchester. c.1570.

This course explores pre- and early modern manuscript paintings in South Asia, focusing on the evolving artistic styles, cultural norms, and gendered representations within them. It offers a critical interrogation of the depiction of the human body, identity markers, and power dynamics in these paintings. Through thematic and visual analysis, students will examine how manuscript paintings portrayed bodies, social relationships, and power structures. The course will also discuss how gendered identities were visually represented in these artworks. The diverse collection of illustrated manuscripts from various cultural backgrounds spanning eight centuries will be studied to understand the adaptation of visual language and narrative traditions. Students will explore how textual and oral traditions influenced visual and poetic representations, shaping artistic and literary expressions over time. For a detailed overview of the course along with decriptions of each course module, please refer to the attachment.

There will be two museum visits. The course will end with a film screening and discussion.

 

Learning Outcomes

By the end of the course, students will be able to:

Learn how to “read” and analyse visual images.

Understand the stylistic development of manuscript painting in South Asia between 1100 and 1900, and identify and differentiate between various historical and regional styles.

Critically examine how visual representations of the body in manuscript paintings construct and communicate ideas of gender and identity within their historical and cultural contexts.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Essential and suggested readings for the theoretical framework*, museum visits**, and course modules will be uploaded and shared with those who choose to pursue the course.

* The theoretical framework  will provide students with a critical appraisal of Visual Studies research methodologies that incorporate gender studies discourses, particularly in the historical context of South Asia and Iran. Key concepts like ‘gender,’ ‘body,’ ‘identity,’ and other related discursive categories emerging from the diverse historical, socio-cultural, and aesthetic contexts of the course will be introduced.

** There will be two Museum Visits, one to the National Museum and another to the Humayun's Tomb Museum.
