Bewitched: Marginality, Perception, Insurrection [SOA-3158] [SOA-3158-1]

Faculty Name
Deepak Mehta [deepak.mehta@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

SOA 3158-1

Bewitched: Marginality, Perception, Insurrection

Overview and Course description: In anthropological accounts witchcraft and magic have been explored in a variety of ways. The problem of witchcraft is as old as the discipline itself. Classical descriptions propose that witchcraft is a safety valve protection against misfortune which must be understood through social categories that are internal to the society being studied. Alternate interpretations suggest that witchcraft functions to create fissions in traditional societies, marking ambiguities in kin relationships and the idea of a ‘home’. Here, witch hunts are forms of patriarchal control and gender disparity. Other versions argue that witchcraft is an effect of culture when it becomes incapable of addressing political violence (both colonial and capitalist) and the fear of disintegration.

The course will address this literature, but we will begin by discussing the figure of the witch, marked by enigma and paradox. As figure, the witch is the margin of the social, both inside and outside, hunter and hunted, sovereign and abject. We will show that the witch emerges from a founding disorder that constantly forces social networks to reorganize themselves. How is this disorder embodied by the witch and how does ethnographic description mark this inflection? These are questions that this course will address. We will also discuss how the witch is not merely a reversal of ordinary patterns of behaviour. Instead, she (witches are predominantly female) provides us with a way of thinking of the ‘outside’ of culture, law and settled norms of inhabiting the everyday. She is the reversal of the ordinary, a way of showing that which is entirely different.

Finally, as coda the course will discuss some ethnographic accounts that show the complicity of the discipline in domesticating this disorder. The trope of the anthropologist as ‘parlour savage’, in the service of a rational, objectivist truth will be addressed.

Learning Outcomes

We will work with a limited number of readings but they will have to be visited again and again. At the end of the course we hope to arrive at an understanding of how marginality, voice and the problem of 'self-making' is addressed.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

I will circulate an extensive reading list from which we will make a selection. Meanwhile, those interested in the literature may skim through 2 texts - Peter Geschiere: Witchcraft, Intimacy and Trust. 2013, Chicago University Press; James Siegel: Naming the Witch. 2006, Stanford University Press. A number of films explore witchcraft and students may want to view them.

Socrates [PHI-3439] [PHI-3439-1]

Faculty Name
Aditi Chaturvedi [aditi.chaturvedi@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

Despite never having written a single word — that we know of — Socrates remains one of the most quoted figures in the history of western philosophy. But who was Socrates? What’s the connection between the character who appears in the writings of Socrates and Xenophon (inter alia) and the historical figure? Why has he, for so long, served as such an important, and often inspirational, figure? We’ll begin to tackle some of these questions by focusing on the writings of Plato, Xenophon, and other fifth and fourth century Greek writers. We will closely read these historical texts, paying attention to their context, but we will also continually question the relevance of these temporally and spatially distant problems for our own lives — How should we respond to injustice? What does it mean to live well despite external persecution? How can we be epistemically virtuous?

The course will be organized around four questions:  i) Can we know anything? ii) What do we owe the state? iii) Why be moral? iv) What does it mean to live philosophically?

 

Learning Outcomes
Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Readings will include (extracts or in their entirety): Plato’s Meno, Gorgias, Theaetetus, Hippias Minor, Charmides, Laches, Apology, Crito, and Phaedo; Xenophon’s Memorabilia and Apology; Aristophanes’ Clouds; Thucydides’ History of the Peloponnesian Wars, and fragments from the pre-Platonic naturalists and sophists. We will also consider the reception of Socrates in the works of Montaigne, Kierkegaard, Nietzsche, Foucault, and Arendt.

Somatics [PA-3023] [PA-3023-1]

Overview

Taught by Navtej Johar

Somatics is derived from the Greek word ‘soma’, meaning ‘the body in its wholeness’. Somatics practice views the body as necessarily reciprocal, and therefore, an unstable entity. It is ever changing in relation to the contexts it inhabits and the objects it interfaces. To view the body just objectively is an impossibility. Its “wholeness” lies in the recognition of its ever changing subjectivities.

Somatics practice involves a fine mapping and scanning of the body in order to catch the murmurings that involuntarily emerge from within. It then proceeds to minutely document the body’s responses to suggestions made through words, images, shapes, shades, cadences, textures and so on, to piece together an abstraction of embedded subjectivities. Finally, while the course will examine the body’s compelling need for expression, movement and connectivity, it will also dwell upon its appetite for stillness, silence and isolation.

Percussion: World Rhythms [PA-2027] [PA-2027-1]

Overview

Taught by Rahul Sharma

This course explores rhythmic traditions from India, Indonesia and parts of West Africa. Students will experience rituals, storytelling and community building while also learning rhythmic structures from traditions such as Carnatic, Hindustani, and Gamelan music. Using simple rhythmic activities rooted in these systems, students will “speak rhythm” through syllables, movement, and repetition. Collective activities will include rhythm games, circle drumming and call-and-response chants. The course also introduces Sound Painting, a live composing sign language developed by Walter Thompson, allowing students to improvise in collective settings with spontaneity and group synergy at the core.

Students will also build simple instruments using bamboo and recycled materials, crafting tools like the Tongatong or a bamboo marimba, engaging directly with sustainable practices and material culture. Through rhythm, they will explore the intersections between music, ecology, and humanities, bridging ancestral practices and contemporary concerns in an experiential, inclusive format.

Performance and Light [PA-3022] [PA-3022-1]

Overview

Taught by Deepak Kurki Shivaswamy

This is an interdisciplinary course that merges movement practice with lighting design to explore performance as a living, luminous form. Through embodied training and creative exploration, students will investigate the expressive potential of the moving body and light as a sculptural element.

The course unfolds in two interwoven components: the first component Thaleem focuses on bodywork, physical conditioning, and compositional play rooted in contemporary dance, yoga, and Indian martial traditions. The second component Light in Performance examines light historically and practically—as energy, material, and metaphor—teaching students how to shape performance environments using light.

Students will engage in physical practice, spatial design, collaborative improvisation, and reflective analysis. Readings, visual art, and film will deepen conceptual understanding.

Analytical Chemistry [CHM-2013/ CHM-4013] [CHM-2013/ CHM-4013-1]

Faculty Name
Deepak Asthana [deepak.asthana@ashoka.edu.in] ,Santu Bera [santu.bera@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

Learning Objectives:

Analytical chemistry provides us with techniques and methods for identifying what something is. This course is designed to provide an in-depth understanding of Analytical Chemistry.

As a part of syllabus, students will be taught the theoretical principles and important applications of classical analytical methods within titration (acid/base titration, complexometric titration, redox titration, precipitation titration), and various techniques within gravimetric and coulometric methods. Through this course students will also learn the theoretical principles of selected instrumental methods within spectrometric and mass spectrometry methods, and main components in such analytical instruments. Methods of various separation techniques in chromatography, and typical applications of chromatographic techniques will also be taught.

To summarize, the aim of this course is to provide students with a broad understanding of the principles of analytical chemistry and their application in the areas of environmental and medicinal/pharmaceutical sciences and advanced materials.

By end of this course, we expect that students should be able to apply the conceptual understanding of the principles and implementation modes of several analytical instruments to chemical systems.

 

Course Contents:

  • Introduction

Analytical chemistry and its applications in various fields such as Healthcare, Environment, Agriculture, Materials and Forensics. Selecting a right analytical method & sample preparations 

  • Precision and accuracy of analysis

Units, types and sources of errors, absolute and relative uncertainty, significant figures and standard & random errors etc., statistical tests of data.

  • Chemical Equilibria and Activity:

pH, buffers, Titrations and Volumetric Analysis (Acid-base)

  • Electrochemical methods of analysis

CV and potentiometry

  • Chromatography

Paper chromatography, Thin layer chromatography, Column chromatography

General principle: High Pressure Liquid Chromatography (HPLC), Ion-exchange Chromatography (IEC), Gas Chromatography (GC):

  • Spectroscopic techniques for chemical analysis

Absorption & emission spectroscopy, FTIR & Raman Spectroscopy, NMR Spectroscopy, Mass Spectrometry

  • Diffraction methods for chemical analysis

Powder diffraction, Single crystal diffraction

  • Thermal methods for chemical analysis

TGA, DTA, DSC, ITC

Learning Outcomes

Learning outcomes:

At the end of the course, the learners should be able to solve problems based on various analytical concepts and can designexperiments with improved sample preparation, new measurement procedures and tools. Students should have learned following things:

  • Ability to identify different types and sources of error, perform relevant statistical analyses of experimental data, and draw appropriate conclusions from the results
  • Should be able to implement standard operating procedures to accurately and precisely prepare standard solutions, calibrate instrumentation, and select right methods of quantitative chemical analysis
  • Will acquire the basic knowledge of classical and instrumental analytical techniques

  • Principles and Practice of Analytical Chemistry, F. W. Fifield & D. Kealey, Wiley, 2000.
  • Fundamentals of Molecular Spectroscopy, Banwell & McCash, 4thEdn, Tata McGraw Hill, 2004
  • Organic Spectroscopy, W.Kemp, 3rdEdn, Mac, 2011

Gaming and Cognition [PSY-4022] [PSY-4022-1]

Faculty Name
Nandini Chatterjee Singh . [nandini.singh@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

Vision/Philosophy/Purpose

Digital gaming is the delivery of interactive learning and  entertainment experiences delivered through interactive digital formats. Gaming or play is a powerful cognitive tool since it promotes and stimulates activities like attention, motivation, reward, creativity and memory and social interaction. Consequently, digital game design is influenced by  an understanding of cognition. In recent years, research has shown that well-designed digital games can enhance cognitive abilities like attention, visuospatial skills, and working memory.  This course will provide an introduction to cognitive processes that influence game mechanics and followed by an application of this to learning. We will reflect on a range of guiding questions critical to game design in the context of learning and training. The course will adopt an interactive teaching-learning methodology with a mix of lectures and hands-on activities.

The course will be structured in four parts - 

In the first part students will be introduced to the concepts of perception, attention, memory examples of cognitive processes that are important for game design.

This part will cover how aspects of cognition are captured in digital games. Students will be introduced to critical theories like cognitive load theory and situated cognition.

It will cover how digital games are different from tabletop games, board games, and other analog games from the perspective of cognitive science.

The second part will introduce game mechanics and game elements. We will also discuss how both these aspects enhance engagement, cognitive flow and emotion

This part will introduce students to the role of learning theories in educational game design.

It will describe several aspects of a game (e.g., narrative, rewards, penalties).

The difference between gamification and game-based learning.

In part 3, we will discuss how well-designed digital games have emerged as  powerful tools for learning. Students will be introduced to theories from educational psychology and the learning sciences and how they can inform educational game design. Using examples, features of good and bad educational games will be explored.

To identify distinctive features of good educational games.

How multiple aspects of learning can be integrated into games

In the fourth and final part of the course students will be divided into groups where they will undertake a project to study and evaluate a game for its learning potential. 

Groups will be tasked to create an “educational game design document” of an existing game of their choice. A repository of educational games will be provided for reference.

Learning Outcomes

Students will be able to:

Develop their knowledge of the cognitive theories central to educational game design.

Recognise that games have the potential to be playgrounds for learning and assessing cognitive and social-emotional skills.

Understand that games can build knowledge, induce emotions, and attitudes towards academic and non-academic content.

Identify the emotional foundations and features of games that can aid in learning.

Understand the foundational role of learning theories in educational game design.

Identify features of “good” educational games and evaluate the educational potential of existing games.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Prescribed Texts: No prescribed texts. Supporting handouts will be provided. Some reference texts are listed below:

Ke, F. (2016). Designing and integrating purposeful learning in game play: A systematic review. Educational Technology Research and Development, 64(2), 219–244. https://doi.org/10.1007/s11423-015-9418-1

Plass, J. L., Homer ,Bruce D., & and Kinzer, C. K. (2015). Foundations of Game-Based Learning. Educational Psychologist, 50(4), 258–283. https://doi.org/10.1080/00461520.2015.1122533

Wen, R., & Dubé, A. (2023). Unlocking the Power of Emotions in Educational Games. Engaged Learning, 3(2). https://engaged-learning.com/unlocking-power-emotions-educational-games/

Philosophy of Perception [PHI-3191/ PSY-3028/ VA-3291] [PHI-3191/ PSY-3028/ VA-3291-1]

Faculty Name
Arindam Chakrabarti [arindam.chakrabarti@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

ABSENCES, SHADOWS, DARKNESS AND MIRROR-REFLECTIONS:

QUESTIONS IN PHILOSOPHY OF PERCEPTION

PHI-3191  Monsoon 2025 | Instructor: Arindam Chakrabarti

COURSE DESCRIPTION

Holes, silences, intermissions, omissions, gaps, recesses, waits, blanks, voids, bald patches, clearings, slits, gaping apertures, the eye of the needle – the observable world around us is replete with real lacks. But what do we really see when we see what’s missing? What exactly is “Dark” about dark matter and dark energy hotly debated and discussed in Astrophysics today?

Every morning when I look out of my window I see (and hear) a bunch of pigeons. Suddenly one morning if I see no pigeons, what is it that I shall be noticing (and noticing that I am noticing)? We start with the fascinating philosophical questions debated for a millennium in Indian Sanskrit philosophies, and for a decade now in contemporary Anglo-American metaphysics and epistemology: are absences directly perceived by our senses? We then go on to discuss our visual perception of shadows and darkness (is it just non-perception of light?). In this connection, we read and interpret critically Leonardo da Vinci’s Treatise on Painting Shadows and Light, and “learn to see” the “dark and deep” (what does darkness have to do with depth?) paintings of Caravaggio, Rembrandt, Odd Nerdrum and Francis Bacon. The last third of the course will deal with the optics, metaphysics, and phenomenology of mirror reflections, leading to the question: how can (or why can’t) the bodily self be both the subject and object of perception?

This course begins with the somewhat unsettling idea that absences, shadows, darkness, and mirror-reflections are not merely perceptual blind spots or metaphysical nothings, but presences unto themselves. Across cultures, centuries and disciplines we explore the perceptibility and reality of absences, of not-being-there. Drawing together logic, phenomenology, art, optics, astrophysics  and comparative metaphysics, the course invites students to rethink the boundaries of perception, presence, and reality.

REFERENCE TEXTS

Meyer H. Abrams, The Mirror and the Lamp

Richard L. Gregory, Mirrors in the Mind

Roberto Casati, The Visual World of Shadows

Roy Sorenson, Nothing: A Philosophical History

Roy Sorenson, Seeing Dark Things: The Philosophy of Shadows

Brian Clegg: Dark Matter & Dark Energy (the hidden 95% of the universe)

Helen YetterChappell, Seeing through eyes, mirrors, shadows and pictures

John Donne (poem) A Lecture upon the Shadow

Isabella Ratie: “An Indian Debate on Optical Reflections and Its Metaphysical Implications for

Śaiva Nondualism and the Mirror of Consciousness*

Mrinal Kaul :“Abhinavagupta on Reflections: Pratibimba”

Dimitry Shevchenko, Mirror of Nature, Mirror of Self: Models of Consciousness in Sāṃkhya, Yoga, and Advaita Vedānta

Critical Approaches in Digital Humanities [ENG-4346] [ENG-4346-1]

Overview

This seminar introduces students to the interdisciplinary field of Digital Humanities (DH), examining how digital tools, methods, and infrastructures are reshaping knowledge practices across the humanities. We will explore development of Digital Humanities (DH) as a field, its tools and infrastructures, and the ethical, political, and epistemological questions it raises. The course focus on topics such as text analysis, digital literature, and digital subaltern studies asking critical questions on access, authorship, and representation.   Key Themes: • Histories and Definitions of Digital Humanities • DH paradigms and methods, including text, images, mapping, networks, and big data • Text Analysis, Natural Language Processing (NLP), and Visualization • Digital Archives and Memory Practices • Electronic Literature and Experimental Narratives • Ethics, Access, and Platform Epistemologies • Working with Tools  Through critical readings, projects, and reflective discussion, students will gain both theoretical understanding and hands-on training with DH tools. No prior technical background is required.

Fictions of the List [ENG-2355] [ENG-2355-1]

Overview

Lists are among our earliest known writings and continue to saturate popular culture in the form of listicles, playlists, menus, and more. In this course we will encounter the list in various guises: as a record of everyday life (as in a shopping list), a bureaucratic tool (as in a census), a technology for information retrieval (as in an index), a form of financial management (as in double-entry bookkeeping) and as a poetic, creative, and artistic form. We will think about the aesthetic and political effects of different kinds of lists, and what lists might teach us about the ways in which we know and experience the world. Although the aim of this course is to provide an expansive overview of the list form, it offers a special foray into literary approaches to enumeration. We will read literary criticism on the list form (including an essay on the word “and”), and study the role of listing in fictional and poetic accounts of loss and exile, itineraries of travel, attempts at humour, and more. We will ask whether the list might be considered a form of story-telling (and consider its relationship to “narrative”), and, along the way, think philosophically about practices of naming, counting and accounting.

courseTitle: Fragments and Frames: Writing through Memory and Mediation
description:
Fragments and Frames: Writing through Memory and Mediation [CT-2357] [CT-2357-1]

Overview

What do we do when knowledge comes in fragments? How do we interpret partial, mediated, or generated texts? This course tries to understand the role of fragmentation and mediation in how we write, read, and make meaning. Moving across literature, visual media, historical accounts, and digital environments, we will explore how memory, identity, and authorship are shaped by technologies of representation ranging from ancient manuscripts to AI-generated stories. Through a series of writing exercises, students will learn to develop arguments, analyze evidence, and engage critically with different forms of cultural production. The course also includes a hands-on exploration of generative AI tools to think through questions of creativity, originality, and ethics in the context of contemporary writing practices. Key Themes: • Fragmentation in Literature and Historical Narratives • Writing and Memory in Mediated Contexts • Interpretation and Meaning-Making from Incomplete Sources • Visual and Digital Cultures of Representation • Generative AI, Creativity, and Authorship • Writing as Thinking: Drafting, Feedback, and Revision 

Learning Outcomes

Students will complete regular writing assignments and revisions, participate in peer- review sessions, and receive detailed instructor feedback. A dedicated module will focus on experimenting with and critically reflecting on the use of generative AI in writing.

Non Fiction Workshop [CW-3060] [CW-3060-1]

Faculty Name
Adam Klein [adam.klein@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

The field of nonfiction writing or writing at least theoretically based in fact, in “real” or reported experience, has never been as vast or wildly engaging as it is today. Cutting across the essay form, biography, memoir, diary, travel and anthropological writing, oral histories, philosophy, environmental and science writing, how-to and how-not-to books, the works we call nonfiction can enlarge the world or reduce it to the size of a cell. Nonfiction can act authoritatively or destabilize our ideas of what constitutes proof or reliability. In all its sub-genres, nonfiction can consider or call for, even if it’s unable to render, justice. It may rouse passion or equanimity or seduce with both small and large revelations. This course will introduce students to the variety, language, and posture of many of these works, beginning with those that first address how we read and write (Virginia Woolf, Mary Ruefle, Joan Didion), followed by those that explore the technologies that undergird our sense of the “real,” from the photograph (Susan Sontag) to physics (Benjamin Labatut) to neuroscience (Oliver Sacks). We’ll explore the ethics of crime reporting (Janet Malcolm, Maggie Nelson), and writings on place and politics (Ryszard Kapuściński, Svetlana Alexievich). We won’t leave out writing on race (James Baldwin, Hilton Als) or on love and art and secrets (Sarah Manguso, A.J.A Symons). And finally, we’ll delve into podcast journalism and other interdisciplinary conveyances of the “true story.” Students will produce original works utilizing examples drawn from our syllabus.

Readings are subject to change.

Overview

SOA 2250: Orders of Difference

*This course will be introduced in Monsoon 2025 as a required 2000 level Sociology and Anthropology course. It will apply as a required course for the incoming 2025 cohort and can be taken as an elective by other cohorts.

Course Description

This is a course about difference and stratification. Class, caste, tribe, ethnicity, gender are markers of difference, which constitute grounds for discrimination and inequality.  How do they find expression in everyday life in India? How do these identity categories intersect with each other? What is the role of the state here, and how does it produce these identities and, in turn, are produced by them?

This course explores key readings which explain how social stratification works in India. It is divided into three sections - Class, Caste, and Minorities. The first two sections will explore the historical basis, overlaps, and intersections between class and caste. The third section will explore how the Indian state defines minorities, focusing on scheduled castes, scheduled tribes, and religious minorities. Gender runs as a common thread across these sections, for people who identify with a gender minority (e.g. Dalit women) become doubly disadvantaged within an already disadvantaged category. 

This course will have the following evaluation components: Attendance (5), in-class quizzes (4x10=40), in-class mid-term exam (25), take-home end-term assignment (30).

Attendance policy: Above 75 percent attendance will get full 5 points. Below 75 percent and above 60 percent, will lose 5 points. Below 60 percent will get a grade cut.

Grading rubric: Relative grading based on assessment of student’s grade by comparison with peer performance.

Learning Outcomes

This course will teach students about caste, class, and minorities in India.

courseTitle: Reading Hegel: The Phenomenology of Spirit
description:
Reading Hegel: The Phenomenology of Spirit [ENG-4065] [ENG-4065-1]

Faculty Name
Huzaifa Omair Siddiqi [huzaifa.siddiqi@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

The greatness of a philosophical system is only measurable by the greatness of its opponents. By that standard, Hegel’s system stands singularly alone–counting amongst its philosophical opponents the greatest minds of Western philosophy: Schelling, Schopenhauer, Marx, Kierkegaard, Nietzsche, Heidegger, Deleuze, Derrida and Foucault. The futility of this opposition to Hegelianism was once remarked upon by Foucault who wrote: “we have to determine the extent to which our anti-Hegelianism is possibly one of his tricks directed against us, at the end of which he stands, motionless, waiting for us”. If Continental philosophy has been obsessed with Hegel since the publication of Phenomenology of Spirit, the repression of British Neo-Hegelianism in the early 20th century by Analytic philosophy seems to have come to an end with the publication of works by John McDowell, Robert Pippin, and of course Robert Brandom, who has ushered in Analytic philosophy from its Kantian to its Hegelian phase. There are perils in reading Hegel; there are even greater dangers in not reading him. For even if we have not read Hegel, Hegel seems to have read us. In this course we will go back to Hegel’s book, The Phenomenology of Spirit to read it not as a closed system of Absolute Knowledge, but as the culmination of the philosophical project of the West, which seeks to bind together the formal autonomy of reason and the ontological autonomy of the real. In doing so we will lay the ground for a deeper understanding of the anti-Hegelianism that follows.

Empirical Macroeconomics [ECO-6202] [ECO-6202-1]

Faculty Name
Anshumaan Tuteja [anshumaan.tuteja@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

This course is designed to introduce key methodologies used in empirical macroeconomics and apply them to examine policy-oriented research questions about monetary and fiscal policy. We will begin with a brief review of foundational topics such as univariate time series models, seemingly unrelated regressions and simultaneous equations. The core topics of the course include spectral analysis (business cycles), multivariate time series models, identification of structural shocks, and state space models. Students will learn to implement these methods through coding exercises in MATLAB.

Learning Outcomes

  1. Learn the techniques commonly used in empirical macroeconomics.

  2. Apply methods to evaluate issues in economic analysis.

Graph Theory and Network Science [CS-4231] [CS-4231-1]

Faculty Name
Bhargab Bikram Bhattacharya [bhargab.bhattacharya@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

Graph theory and network science provide essential tools for analyzing and understanding systems where entities are interconnected. This course introduces students to the mathematical foundations of graphs and networks, emphasizing their practical applications in modern data science. With the rapid growth of data from diverse scientific fields, the ability to model complex relationships through networks has become increasingly important. This course explores how graphs, composed of nodes and edges, can represent and analyze interactions in fields ranging from social networks to biological systems and knowledge graphs.
Key topics covered include fundamentals of graph theory, large networks and their behavior, search algorithms, community detection, and many real-world applications. Students will learn how to apply algorithmic techniques to tackle challenges in data science, particularly in social network analysis, biological networks, and machine learning. The course will also touch upon advanced topics such as Graph Neural Networks (GNNs), and graph-based partitioning and clustering, which are transforming the way we process and analyze network data. 

 

Learning Outcomes

By the end of the course, students will gain a comprehensive understanding of modern network sciences, equipping them with the skills to uncover hidden patterns, improve accuracy, and explore new research directions in these rapidly evolving fields.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Prerequisites: Introduction to Computer Science (ICS); Data Structures and Algorithms (DSA).

References:
 Douglas B. West: Introduction to Graph Theory, Second Edition, Pearson, Singapore, 2000.
 Arthur Benjamin, Gary Chartrand, and Ping Zhang: The Fascinating World of Graph Theory, Princeton University Press, 2015.
 M. E. J. Newman, Networks, An Introduction, 2nd Edition, Oxford, 2018.
 D. Easley and J. Kleinberg, Networks, Crowds, and Markets: Reasoning About a Highly Connected World, Cambridge University Press, 2010.

Computational Geometry: Algorithms and Applications [CS-4232] [CS-4232-1]

Faculty Name
Bhargab Bikram Bhattacharya [bhargab.bhattacharya@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

Computational Geometry is the study of geometric problems and the development of efficient algorithms for solving them. This course introduces undergraduate students to the fundamental concepts, techniques, and applications of computational geometry. Through a mix of theory and practical problem-solving, students will explore geometric algorithms and their relevance to various fields such as computer graphics, robotics, computer-aided design (CAD), geographic information systems (GIS), and data visualization.

Learning Outcomes

By the end of the course, students should acquire both theoretical knowledge and practical skills for designing and implementing geometric algorithms, preparing them for further studies or careers in areas that require geometric modelling and computation.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Prerequisites: Introduction to Computer Science (ICS); Data Structures and Algorithms (DSA).

Applied Ecology and Ecosystem Management [ES-2232] [ES-2232-1]

Faculty Name
Ghazala Shahabuddin [ghazala.shahabuddin@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

Ecosystem functions such as carbon sequestration, hydrological services, maintenance of biological diversity, pollination and food provisioning need to be conserved for the overall ecological security of human society. However, the pervasive human influence on ecosystems demands active management and remediation, based on a deep understanding of how ecosystems work as well as the specific ways in which human beings change/modify these properties. Further, many ecosystem properties are a result of historic human imprint upon natural landscapes and it is necessary to recognize these influences. It is also witnessed that the management goals for a given ecosystem are usually highly debated due to the large diversity of stakeholders benefiting from various resources and various types of management having different end-goals. Consequently, there are likely to be trade-offs amongst the different management goals for an ecosystem, between economic and ecological goals or between different social groups. Given the wide variety of threats faced by different ecosystems, complexity of ecological interactions and the large number of stakeholders, ecosystem management requires an imaginative and eclectic set of approaches based on not only a conceptual understanding of how ecosystems function, but also a recognition of the socio-political and economic contexts.

This course will attempt to build a holistic view of ecosystem structure, functioning and  the practice of ecosystem management. Students will be introduced to ecological concepts such as population growth, community diversity, plant-animal interactions, nutrient cycling and energy flow and the theoretical perspectives related to equilibrium theory, resilience, stability and disturbance ecology, which are relevant to ecosystem management.  During the second half of the course, students will go on to study specific issues in ecosystem management such as control of invasive species, rewilding, ecosystem restoration, wetland management, climate change mitigation and sustainable harvesting through well-illustrated case studies.

Applied ecology and Ecosystem Management is designed for students from a wide range of disciplinary backgrounds. The course will depend on a critical study of textbooks, journal papers and popular articles. A set of readings will form the basis for class discussions around current ecosystem management issues, which will form a significant component of learning and assessment in this course.

Prerequisite: Foundation Course in Environmental Studies

List of Modules/Topics:

Module 1: Discovering Ecology in the Anthropocene

The students will be introduced to ecology as a subject, using a historical perspective on ecological enquiry. Students will read travelogues from early and modern ecologists (Salim Ali, Alfred Wallace, Alexander von Humboldt and others) in order to understand the practice of ecology as a science. Discussion will be invited on the relevance and application of ecology as a science in the Anthropocene by exploring current ecological concerns.

Module 2: Humans and Nature: A History

In this module, we explore the varying views of humans in nature, using a range of approaches including palaeoecology, archaeology, and anthropology. Students will explore the contrasting views of social scientists and ecologists on the role and place of humans in nature.

Module 3,4: Ecosystems and Ecosystem Function

We will explore ecosystems and their different components. Concepts of energy flow and primary productivity will be covered in addition to basic tenets of ecology. The ecological concepts will be applied to understand climate change and its real-world implications for human ecology.

Module 5,6: The Physical Environment: Climate, Soil and Water

This module focusses on soils, and nutrient cycling, with the aim to introduce the students to ecosystem-level thinking. We study the underlying principles of flow of matter through ecosystems and the earth’s biogeochemical cycles, taking nitrogen, carbon and phosphorus as examples. Climate change will be a special focus of discussion in this module.

Module 7,8: Population Growth and Regulation

Concepts of populations, population structure, different parameters associated with populations, growth curves and population age structure will be covered. Mechanisms of population regulation will also be covered. Applications of key concepts in population ecology to the real-life challenge of Bengal tiger conservation will be discussed, based on recent articles and news on tigers.

Module 9,10: Community Diversity

This module will introduce students to the concept of biodiversity and its measurement. They will learn how to characterise communities through commonly used metrics such as species richness, abundance, evenness, diversity indices and similarity will be discussed. The ideas of ecological niche and resource partitioning  will be introduced. Patterns and drivers of community diversity and species turnover in space will be discussed, particularly with reference to anthropogenic influences.

Module 11,12: Predation, Trophic Cascades and Food Webs

Various interspecific interactions such as predator-prey relations and  competition will be covered in detail. Historic lab and field experiments in community ecology will be discussed. The second part of this module deals with food web theory, as a way to describe and understand the complexity in the ecological world.  The attributes of food webs that explain community persistence will be examined. The notion of ‘keystone species’ will be discussed. Debates on complexity-stability linkages and ecosystem degradation will be introduced, which are recurring themes in ecosystem management.

Module 13: Plant-animal Interactions

Interactions between plant and animal species have been the subject of much enquiry in the field of ecology. Processes such as seed dispersal, herbivory and pollination that involve co-evolution between specific plant and animal taxa are important to study from the point of view of ecosystem management and restoration. This module introduces the students to the pioneering research on plant-animal interactions, mainly based in tropical ecosystems which show numerous specialized mutualisms.  The applications to real-life conservation will also be discussed such as in the case of crop pollination.

Module 14: Ecological Succession as a Process

Many of the spatial patterns in communities that we observe today reflect historical and ongoing ecological processes. The plant and animal communities observed today are likely to be very different from those that  existed a few decades ago and bear the imprint of both ongoing ecological processes and human activities. We will explore the successional patterns in plant communities and how these patterns manifest in variations in communities of animals and plants that depend on them, in a range of terrestrial ecosystems. The applications of successional theory to restoration and rewilding will be pointed out.

Module 15: Balance of Nature: Ecosystem Equilibrium and Disequilibrium

This module will explore the competing notions of equilibrium and disequilibrium in relation to ecosystems, communities and populations. In this context, the role of disturbances such as fragmentation, climate change and fire  in maintaining biodiversity and ecological functioning will be studied. The question to be discussed is: Is it possible to reconcile the  opposing viewpoints on equilibrium and disequilibrium in the ecological literature?  We will also attempt to link equilibrium theory to the role of humans within ecosystems and the varying viewpoints from which this has been explored, thus connecting it to the literature of political ecology.  

Module 16,17: Invasive species and their Management

Invasive species present a useful system to understand basic ecological processes such as competition and population regulation. At the same time, invasive ecology has immense implications for socio-economic stability and ecosystem services, and requires detailed study. In this module, students will apply the basics of community ecology to understanding invasives and their socio-economic impacts and possible management techniques.

Module 18: Nature-based Solutions for Climate Change Mitigation

Nature-based solutions for climate change mitigation will be critically examined in terms of the science basis as well as implementation, particularly in developing countries.  The varied ways in which governments and communities have attempted to enhance carbon sequestration rates in a range of natural ecosystems, will be analysed and evaluated by the students based on ecological concepts.

Module 19,20: Principles of Ecosystem Restoration

Restoring forests on degraded land so as to recreate productive ecosystems is now being taken up on a large scale across the world. Effective restoration requires not just sound ecological knowledge of species and their interactions, but also recognition of the socio-economic matrix within which it is undertaken. Discussion will take place around three short videos on forest restoration from different parts of the world, in which the students will apply learning from previous modules on ecological processes. They will also compare and contrast the restoration philosophy underlying these three examples.

Module 21,22: Wildlife Reintroductions for Re-wilding

The reintroduction of wild fauna to sites from where they have been exterminated has become a widespread practice of governments worldwide. Faunal reintroductions have multiple dimensions from the ecological and socio-political perspectives. Ecologically, such reintroductions have an ecological goal- to restore ecosystem stability. Socially, such  projects are projected to bring a range of benefits for the local people in the protected areas where species are reintroduced. In this class, the students will  discuss and debate wildlife reintroductions based on learnings from earlier modules, and case studies from Yellowstone and Kruger National Parks.

Module 22,23: Sustainable Use of Wild Species and Ecosystems

Students will apply theories of population growth and regulation to sustainable harvest of wild species, including NTFP products, saltwater crocodiles and fuelwood. They will compare the socio-political and scientific contexts of sustainable harvest between two countries: Australia and India. Further, the larger landscape-level impacts of ecosystem use and species extraction, on diversity and ecosystem complexity, will be studied through a range of examples from tropical countries.

Module 24,25: Rangeland Management: Role of Grazing and Fire

Grasslands are one of the most widespread and biodiverse ecosystems worldwide, ranging from savannahs of East Africa to the alpine meadows of the Himalayas. Yet they are poorly understood in terms of ecology and human use. Further, pastoral communities who are dependent on these ecosystems have been as marginalised as the ecosystems themselves. In this module, the complex social ecology of grasslands will be explored, particularly the intertwined roles of herbivory and fire in nature. Students, through break-out sessions, will be asked to debate the policy changes that are required for long-term conservation.

Module 26: Management Goals, Trade-offs and Social Ecology: A Case Study on Wetlands

Wetlands are widespread and biodiverse ecosystems worldwide, ranging from rivers that can be seen as the fount of civilization, and human-made lakes created for everyday use.  Yet they are poorly understood in terms of ecology and human use, and subject to misuse, pollution and misgovernance. In this module, the complex social ecology of wetlands will be explored. Students, through break-out sessions, will be asked to debate the policy changes that are required for long-term conservation of wetlands that can imbibe both social and ecological values, based course readings and a documentary.

Learning Outcomes
  • The course will build a working knowledge of ecological concepts that are widely used in scientific management as well as sustainable policy-making for ecosystems.
  •  Students will learn to apply ecological principles to current management problems such as resource over-exploitation and rewilding.
  • Students will learn to critically analyse current ecological debates using a social-ecological lens.
Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

courseTitle: Studies in Translation: Caste in the Literary Imagination
description:
Studies in Translation: Caste in the Literary Imagination [ENG-2377] [ENG-2377-1]

Overview

How are casted experiences translated? And, more importantly, how does caste translate itself into being written? These are two questions we will meditate on through this course. We will think through novels and poems written in several languages (translated into English) as we study how experiences of caste are brought to the brim through expert translators, and how the work of caste gets concealed in texts originally written in English. The course will introduce students to Indian and western theories of translation and build an understanding of the casted nature of the languages we inhabit and the imaginative world-building we inherit. In their end-term papers students will present their reading of a literary reality of caste in texts they choose.

courseTitle: Critical Thinking Seminar: Politics of Persuasion
description:
Critical Thinking Seminar: Politics of Persuasion [CT-2378] [CT-2378-1]

Overview

I would like to offer a course that investigates the techniques and strategies of persuasive political rhetoric. Students will be introduced to foundational texts of rhetoric from the Greco-Roman and Sanskrit traditions, and contemporary theories of rhetoric and methods of analysis, in particular: the Burkean perspective on attending to drama and symbols, the cognitive linguistics perspective that considers metaphorical networks as structuring people’s political and social every day, and verbal content analysis that looks at tonal variations through frequency studies. We will read speeches that have gained fame or notoriety and, besides regular assessment, the final assignment would involve students presenting a situated analysis of the persuasive potential of one persuasive speech from their own linguistic background.

Overview

Professor Duncan Cordry

A philosophical examination of the nature and history of technology, as well as its complex impact on humans and the world. Topics covered will include the accelerating evolution of technology, the relation between technicity and thinking, and the transformation of society by digital technologies. Regular attendance required.

Research Methodology and Ethics [PHY-6900/ MAT-5201] [PHY-6900/ MAT-5201-1]

Faculty Name
Gautam Iqbal Menon [gautam.menon@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

Objectives

To familiarise students with some of the philosophical, psychological, methodological, and ethical aspects of research, in particular research done for a PhD. 

To develop some of the skills required for it, e.g. reading and writing research papers and grant proposals, and listening to and delivering scientific talks. 

Contents

Philosophical, psychological, methodological, and ethical aspects

The nature of scientific research. Choosing an area of research. Choosing an adviser. Finding and formulating a research problem. The relationship between research scholar and adviser. The different stages of solving a research problem. The creative process. Publishing: authorship, citation, acknowledgement, plagiarism. The research scholar as member of a community of scientists. Collaboration with other senior scientists, with peers, and with undergraduates. Independent work unconnected with main thesis problem. Evolution from dependence to independence.  The spectrum of ethical problems — recognising them and dealing with them. Sexism and other prejudices in the world of science. The importance and dangers of networking. The bureaucratic aspects of a PhD. Time-management. 

Skills

Making a CV. Maintaining a log-book. Reading papers. Writing papers. Writing a thesis. Writing a grant proposal. Using reference and citation repositories. Writing a letter of recommendation. Listening to scientific talks. Scientific interactions. Giving scientific talks. Writing for and speaking to the public. Teaching: conducting discussion sessions and labs. Interviewing and being interviewed. Interacting in person and online with senior scientists, peers, and undergraduates. Attending conferences. Reviewing papers. 

Learning Outcomes
Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

This course is open only to students enrolled for a PhD.

References

Advise to a Young Scientist, by P B Medawar

The Scientist’s Guide to Writing: How to Write more Easily and Effectively Throughout your Scientific Career, by S B Heard 

The Great Betrayal: Fraud in Science, by H F Judson

The Ethics of Science: an Introduction, by D B Resnik

Attendance

Regular attendance is expected. 

Excused absence(s) are not applicable in this course lecture.
Additional excused absence(s) are not applicable for sportspersons in this course lecture.
Additional Comments:

Regular attendance is expected. 

Grading
Grading Components
Grading Rubric

Weekly writing exercises: 40%; talks: 10%; mock interview: 10%; interview of practising scientist: 10%; mid-term paper: 10%; final paper: 20%.

courseTitle: Art and Ecology in the Wake of Climate Change
description:
Art and Ecology in the Wake of Climate Change [VA-2066/ ES-2038] [VA-2066/ ES-2038-1]

Faculty Name
Srinivas Adiya Mopidevi [srinivas.mopidevi@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

This course introduces the students to the history of art’s relationship with ecology. It argues that art has always had ecological considerations in its materiality and meaning. Beginning from Indigenous art practices that have always been in sync with the flows of nature, the course will delve into diverse movements from the 1960s, such as Land Art, Earth Art, Environmental Art, Bio-art, and community-based practices. The course also maps the shifts in artistic methodologies in the wake of climate change, where creative practice is a catalyst to educate the larger public about the shifting planetary realities. In its part-theoretical and part-practical approach, the course will include ‘material literacy’ sessions and workshops to unpack the potentiality of art in addressing ongoing concerns of climate adaptation and sustainability. 

 

Course Modules

Art and Ecology - An Overview 

The introductory module offers the students a comprehensive entry into the field of art and its particular relationship with ecology. This will encompass examples of early cave painting, Indigenous art practices, and movements such as Romanticism, Impressionism, Earth Art, and Land and Environmental Art. It will also speak about how contemporary art forges a multifaceted approach to addressing the planet's current ecological realities. 

Ravi Agarwal, Latika Gupta Ed., Art & Ecology, Marg - A Magazine of the Arts, Mumbai, Vol.71, No.3 2020. https://marg-art.org/product/UHJvZHVjdDo1Mjc3

Andrew Brown, Art & Ecology Now, Thames & Hudson, London, 2014

Alan C. Braddock, Implication: Theory and Practice in Ecocritical Art History, Yale University Press, New Haven, 2023.  

T.J. Demos,  Against the Anthropocene - Visual Culture and Environment Today, Sternberg Press, 2017. https://www.sternberg-press.com/product /against -the- anthropocene-visual-culture-and-environment-today/

Sugata Ray, Venugopal Maddipati Ed., Water Histories of South Asia: The Materiality of Liquescence, Routledge India, 2021.

 

Folk and Tribal / Indigenous / Aboriginal Cultural Practices

This module will discuss how the art practices of  Folk and Tribal, Indigenous, and Aboriginal communities have been responding to land and nature through art. It will draw examples from South Asia, Aboriginal Australia, and some First Nations in the United States. It will also discuss the limitations of art historical discourses that often see these living and contemporary practices relegated to tradition.  

Jyotindra Jain, Other Masters: Five Contemporary Folk and Tribal Artists of India, Crafts Museum and The Handicrafts and Handlooms Exports Corporation of India Ltd,  New Delhi, 1998.

Jyotindra Jain, Painted Myths of Creation: Art and Ritual of an Indian Tribe, Lalit Kala Akademi, 1984. 

Annapurna Garimella, Vernacular in the Contemporary, Exhibition Publications, Devi Art Foundation, New Delhi, 2010 - 11 https://deviartfoundation.org/exhibitions/vernacular-in-the-contemporary/

Forge Project, https://forgeproject.com/

Marie Geissler, Dreaming the Land: Aboriginal Art from Remote Australia, Thames & Hudson, 2023.   

“Visualizing Ecology: Adivasi Art and the Politics of Representation” – curated writing from Museum of Art & Photography (MAP) Bangalore https://map-india.org/understanding-adivasi-artists-in-the-contemporary-context/

 

‘Pedagogy of the Land’ - Shantiniketan and Beyond

Since its inception in the early 20th Century, Shantiniketan has been committed to the ethos of ‘land’ and its embodied knowledge. Drawing from the artistic and pedagogic methods of the ‘Bengal School of Art,’ this module will delve into the ecological considerations in the practices of Abanindranath Tagore, Rabindranath Tagore, Nandalal Bose, Ramkinkar Baij, Benod Behari Mukherjee, Sanchayan Ghosh, among others. 

R. Siva Kumar – Santiniketan: The Making of a Contextual Modernism https://www.academia.edu/42665455/Santiniketan_The_making_of_A_Contextual_Modernism_with_Notes

Aida Yuen Wong, Landscapes of Nandalal Bose (1882–1966): Japanism, Nationalism and Populism in Modern India, in Brij Tankha Ed., Okakura Tenshin and Pan-Asianism, Brill, 2009.

Shukla Sawant, Cultivating a Taste for Nature: Tagore's Landscape Paintings, Vol. 52, No. 19, 2017, pp.57-63. https://www.jstor.org/stable/26695612.

Art Practice as Pedagogy: Anudev Manoharan & Sanchayan Ghosh, https://hakara.in/anudev-manoharan/.

K G Subramanyan, The ‘Phenomenon’ ​​of Abanindranath Tagore, Critical Collective ​​https://criticalcollective.in/ArtistInner2.aspx?Aid=279&Eid=970.

Santhal Family: positions around an Indian sculpture, Anshuman Dasgupta, Monika Szewczyk, Grant Watson Ed., Museum van Hedendaagse Kunst Antwerpen (MuHKA), 2008.

 

Land Art, Earth, and Environmental Art 

This module will specifically discuss the movements of the 1960s with a range of artists from the West engaging with land and environment as sites of artistic practice. These include Christo, Robert Smithson, Nancy Holt, and James Turell. While some worked with found elements as material, others tried to reinvent the landscapes through spatial and architectural interventions. The discussion will also reflect on the gaze of these artists on the landscapes they were working with. 

Suzaan Boettger, Earthworks: Art and the Landscape of the Sixties, University of California Press, 2002. 

Christo, ‘Running Fence’, https://christojeanneclaude.net/artworks/running-fence/ 

Jack Flam Ed., Robert Smithson: Collected Writings, University of California Press, Los Angeles, 1996. https://monoskop.org/images/b/bd/ Smithson_Robert_Collected _Writings_no_OCR.pdf

Robert Smithson, Spiral Jetty, Robert Smithson at Dia: Spiral JettyYouTube · Dia Art Foundation26 Sept 2024

Nancy Holt, Sun Tunnels, 1970  Nancy Holt at Dia: Sun TunnelsYouTube · Dia Art Foundation24 Jul 2024

Lucy Lippard, Undermining: a wild ride through land use, politics, and art in the changing West, The New Press, New York, 2013.

https://archive.org/details/underminingwildr0000lipp/page/n5/mode/2up

James Turell, Roden Crater, 2024 Exploring James Turrell's Roden Crater and Quaker Meeting ...YouTube · Art2110 Dec 2024

 

Being One with the Landscape

Expanding from the legacies of land and environmental art, this module focuses on the works of Andy Goldsworthy, Olafur Elliason, and Anish Kapoor. It also maps how the shift into an active debate about climate change has altered artist's approach to land and landscape. 

Andy Goldsworthy, Rivers and Tides, 2001

https://www.goldsworthy.cc.gla.ac.uk/

Bridget Sutherland, “Cave To Cosmos: Mythological Animals In The Sculpture Of Anish Kapoor,” Green Letters, 25(1), 76–89. https://doi.org/10.1080/14688417.2021.1907209

Olafur Elliasson, Tate, https://www.tate.org.uk/art/artists /olafur-eliasson-5239/ yes-but-why-olafur-eliasson

Olafur Eliasson and climate change, light thinking, https://www.iguzzini.com/ lighthinking/ olafur-eliasson-and-climate-change/

 

Materiality, Art and Ecology

Materiality has been a key aspect in the history of artists working with ecology. This module will discuss contemporary South Asian art practitioners who have closely worked with these questions in diverse ways. It will unpack how the choice of materiality is crucial to speak about ongoing planetary realities. 

Mrinalini Mukherjee Archive, Asia Art Archive 

https://aaa.org.hk/en/collections/search/archive/mrinalini-mukherjee-archive

Abstracting Nature - Mrinalini Mukherjee and Jayashree Chakravarty

Abstracting Nature – Mrinalini Mukherjee and ...Kiran Nadar Museum of Arthttps://www.knma.in › abstracting-nature-–-mrinalini-mu…

Priya Ravish Mehra, Gallery Threshold https://www.gallerythreshold.com/artist/priya-ravish-mehra/

Sheba Chhachhi https://www.tate.org.uk/ research/in-focus/seven-lives-dream- sheba- chhachhi/conversation-with-sheba-chhachhi

Sheela Gowda, Tate, https://www.tate.org.uk/art/artists/ sheela-gowda-18148/sheela-gowda-studio-visit

 

Community-engagement and Collaboration 

Collaboration with communities has been one of the central aspects of artistic practices that have been engaging with questions of land and the environment. This module will look into how artists from South Asia have been immersed in collaboration and community engagement.   

Navjot Altaf, ‘Dialogue Interactive Artists Association,’ https://www.dialoguebastar.com/

Sreejata Roy, Profile, Khoj International Artists’ Association, https://khojstudios.org/person/sreejata-roy/. 

48 Degrees Celsius, Khoj International Artists’ Association, 2018. 

https://khojstudios.org/event/48-degrees-celsius/

Ravi Agarwal, Yamuna -Elbe Project, 2018 https://www.raviagarwal.com /2018/01/yamuna-elbe-public-art-outreach-2011/

T. J. Demos, Emily Eliza Scott, Subhankar Banerjee Ed., The Routledge Companion to Contemporary Art, Visual Culture, and Climate Change, Routledge, 2021.  upcoming-the-routledge-companion-to-contemporary-art-visual-culture-and-climate-change-edited-by-t-j-demos-emily-eliza-scott-subhankar-banerjee

 

Aesthetics of Waste

The aesthetics of waste has been a fascination for artists in India and the rest of the world. This particular interest has expanded in the wake of conversations around the importance of waste management in combating climate change. With a few visionary and some contemporary examples of artistic practices, this module will focus on the aesthetic languages of waste.    

Vivan Sundaram, Trash, Exhibition Publication, Chemould Prescott Road, 2008 https://www.gallerychemould.com/ exhibitions/83-trash-vivan-sundaram/

Vivan Sundaram, Gagawaka - Making Strange, Exhibition Publication, Chemould Prescott Road, 2011 - 2012 https://aaa.org.hk/en/ collections/search/library /vivan-sundaram- gagawaka-making-strange

Vibha Galhotra, Sediment and other untitled…, 2010-12 https://vibhagalhotra.com/cc/

HA Schult, Action: Trash People, https://www.haschult.de/action/trashpeople#content

Marina DeBris, Art made from waste, https://www.milanogreenforum.com/ en/ mostra/ marina-debris-art-made-from-waste/

Amol K Patil, https://www.project88.in/artists/49-amol-k-patil/biography/

 

Film, and Environmental Activism 

Film, particularly documentary, has had a unique relationship with environmental activism to bring forth voices from the grassroots that pledge to safeguard our forests and the ecosystem. This module looks at filmmakers who have spent time documenting movements and resistances in urban and rural contexts. 

Amar Kanwar, The Sovereign Forest, 2013 https://tba21.org/amar_the_sovereign_forest 

Shaunak Sen, All That Breathes, Docu Feature, 2022 https://www.allthatbreathes.com/

Sanjay Kak, Red Ant Dream, Documentary, 2013 https://www.youtube .com/watch?v= IMje28Fg0vk 

Wanuri Kahiu, For Our Land (Professor - Wangare Maathai Documentary,) 2009. https://vimeo.com/35631869 

 

“Black Ecologies” and “ Black Geographies” of Art

The existing discourses of “Black Ecologies” and “Black Geographies” contest the understandings of Black histories as additions to existing historical narratives. They speak of methods that acknowledge the ecological impacts of the history of slavery and call for a non-extractivist approach to nature and the environment. By discussing how climate change impacts communities that are already marginalized through race and caste, this module particularly unpacks the resistance from Black cultural practices that have been inverting the colonial gaze of looking at nature as a site of exploitation and ownership. 

Black Ecologies in Contemporary American Art, Exhibition https://www.pomona.edu/museum/exhibitions/2025/black-ecologies-contemporary-american-art

Global Black Ecologies, J. T. Roane, Hilda Lloréns, Justin Hosbey

https://www.berghahnjournals.com/view/journals/environment-and-society/13/1/ares130101.xml?ArticleBodyColorStyles=contentsummary-4283

Aida Muluneh, https://aidamuluneh.com/projects/

Imani Jacqueline Brown, https://imanijacquelinebrown.net/ (

Black Quantum Futurism, https://www.blackquantumfuturism.com/

Tiona Nekkia McClodden, https://www.tionam.com/

Kiluanji Kia Henda, Tate, https://www.tate.org.uk/art/artists/kiluanji-kia- henda-23100/introducing-kiluanji-kia-henda

 

 Ethics of Representation

In the past decades, several creative practitioners have been responding to the climate crisis, opening a debate around their intentions and ethical considerations. The questions of ethics have also been a site of concern across Indigenous and black discourses on ecology to resist the misappropriation and misinterpretation of their histories of struggles and resistance. This module revisits the artists discussed throughout the course to investigate their ethics and politics of representation.   

The Interaction of Ethics and Aesthetics in Environmental Art, Sandra Shapshay, Levi Tenen, Ted Nannicelli, The Journal of Aesthetics and Art Criticism, Volume 76, Issue 4, October 2018, Pages 497–506, https://doi.org/10.1111/jaac.12601

Emily Eliza Scott, Artists’ Platforms for New Ecologies, Third Text, http://thirdtext.org/artists-platforms-for-new-ecologies-arc

 

‘Material Literacy’ - Art and Sustainability

‘Material Literacy’ is a module co-mentored with Shubhi Sachan, the founder of the Material Library of India. It will take an interactive approach to illustrate the life of our everyday materials. It will propose a holistic understanding of materials, including the ones used in the making of art. 

Material Library of India, https://materiallibraryofindia.com/

 

Art, Research and Climate Action

This module draws from two ongoing research and exhibition projects, Climate Recipes, an international wisdom-gathering project initiated by Srinivas Mangipudi and Srinivas Aditya Mopidevi, and Sustaina India,  an art, science, and climate initiative co-founded by artists duo Thukral and Tagra with Centre on Energy, Environment and Water (CEEW). It unpacks how artistic research and exhibition-making can surface and disseminate the existing knowledge around sustainable livelihoods and climate adaptation.

Sustaina India https://sustainaindia.org/

Climate Recipes https://www.climate.recipes/

Learning Outcomes

Learning Objectives:

By the end of this course, students:

Will be well-versed in the history of art and its relationship to ecology.

Will develop an understanding of how the methodologies of art can contribute towards climate action.

Will be tuned to a clearer understanding of the ethics of representation.

Will learn the importance of researching, synthesizing, and sharing existing knowledge about planetary realities through art’s mediation. 

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

See Modules (above)

Attendance

Three absences are permitted. However, since grading will be based on continuous assessment throughout the semester, absences during participative seminars and presentations will result in a reduction in the overall grade.

Excused absence(s) are not applicable in this course lecture.
Additional excused absence(s) are not applicable for sportspersons in this course lecture.
Additional Comments:

Three absences are permitted. However, since grading will be based on continuous assessment throughout the semester, absences during participative seminars and presentations will result in a reduction in the overall grade.

Grading
Grading Components
Grading Rubric

Students will be graded on the basis of active participation in class, their choice of presentation topics, and written components as well as the realization of the final project.

Class/ Seminar Participation: 20%

One 500-word case study of any ecological concern students respond to: 15 %

One presentation that delves into any eco-art movement, project, or artist that they are inspired by: 15%

Final exhibition/research project presentation (group project format): 50 %

Asymmetric Information Models [ECO-6101/ ECO-4101] [ECO-6101/ ECO-4101-1]

Faculty Name
Suraj Shekhar [suraj.shekhar@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

This is an advanced course in microeconomics. Knowledge of basic game theory will be assumed. The objective of this course is to equip the students with the tools to build and analyse models of strategic behaviour in environments with asymmetric information. We will then take these tools and apply them to study real-life problems. Specific topics include Bayesian equilibrium, models of moral hazard and adverse selection, and applications to microfinance, insurance, herd behaviour and advertising.

courseTitle: Econometric Applications: Household, Individual Behavior and Gender
description:
Econometric Applications: Household, Individual Behavior and Gender [ECO-6502/ ECO-4502] [ECO-6502/ ECO-4502-1]

Faculty Name
Bipasha Maity [bipasha.maity@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

The aim of this course is to cover topics on decision making within the household and how individuals influence and in turn react to these decisions; with a focus on how these impact women and girls. Broad topics to be covered include intra-household bargaining, marriage markets including evolution of marriage market payments and marriage dissolution, fertility decisions, investments in human capital (health, education and skills) in children, as well as how larger political economy considerations and environmental shocks impact intra-household decision making and women’s welfare. 

Learning Outcomes
Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

ECO 5102 (Microeconomics II), ECO-5401 (Econometrics)/ECO 2102 (Microeconomic Theory II), ECO 2400 (Econometrics) are the pre-requisites for this course.

Most of the learning materials will involve economics journal articles that can be downloaded from Ashoka's e-library resources. The reading list will be provided during the first week of classes.

Monetary Theory [ECO-6200/ ECO-4200] [ECO-6200/ ECO-4200-1]

Faculty Name
Arghya Bhattacharya [arghya.bhattacharya@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

We start the course by asking a fundamental question: what is money and why is it essential? We will begin with a simple overlapping generations (OLG) model where intrinsically worthless objects are valued at equilibrium. This is fiat money.

After this, we will quickly graduate to the Lagos-Rocheteau-Wright (LRW) class of models a.k.a. New Monetarist models, and use them to understand different aspects of monetary economies and how a monetary economy interacts with other markets – labor markets, asset markets, and over-the-counter (OTC) markets. Time permitting, we will also study Choi and Rocheteau (2021) class of models, which are continuous time versions of LRW models and yield richer dynamics.

In the last phase of the course, we will discuss selected papers on important and interesting issues in monetary economics. Some of these might be “current issues”, while the rest are perennial questions. Students taking the course must select a paper from a predefined list and present it in class. The presentation will be followed by a Q&A.

 I will teach selected chapters from the book Money, Payments, and Liquidity (MIT Press) by Rocheteau and Nosal. This is a graduate textbook on LRW models.

Learning Outcomes
Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Books:

  • Money, Payments, and Liquidity by Ed Nosal and Guillaume Rocheteau. MIT Press (2017): this is a graduate textbook and the main reference for this course.

Suggested Papers (students will present them in class):

  • Monetary Equilibrium and the Cost of Banking Activity, by Paola Boel and Gabriele Camera, Journal of Money, Credit and Banking, 52(4) (2020), 653-683
  • Entrepreneurial Finance and Monetary Policy, by Paul Jackson and Florian Madison, European Economic Review (2022)
  • The Shadow Economy as an Equilibrium Outcome, by Pere Gomis-Porqueras, Adrian Peralta-Alva and Chris Waller. Journal of Economic Dynamics and Control (2014)
  • A New Monetarist Model of Fiat and E-Money, by Sebastien Lotz and Francoise Vasselin. Economic Inquiry (2019)
  • Payments on Digital Platforms: Resilience, Interoperability and Welfare by Jonathan Chiu and Russell Wong. Journal of Economic Dynamics and Control (Forthcoming)
  • Search and the market for ideas, by Rafael Silveira and Randy Wright. Journal of Economic Theory (2010)
  • Venture capital: A model of search and bargaining, by Rafael Silveira and Randy Wright. Review of Economic Dynamics (2016)
  • Innovation and growth with financial, and other frictions, by Randy Wright, Jonathan Chiu and Cesaire Meh. International Economic Review (2017)
  • An Information-based theory of international currency, by Cathy Zhang. Journal of International Economics (2014)
  • Asset Liquidity and International Portfolio Choice by Athanasios Geromichalos & Ina Simonovska. Journal of Economic Theory (2014)
  • An Over-the-Counter Approach to the FOREX Market by Athanasios Geromichalos and Kuk Mo Jung. International Economic Review (2018)
  • Marriage, markets, and money: A Coasian theory of household formation by K. Burdett, M. Dong, L. Sung and R. Wright. International Economic Review (2016)

Classical Mechanics [PHY-2210/ MAT-3210] [PHY-2210/ MAT-3210-1]

Faculty Name
Amin Ahmad Nizami [amin.nizami@ashoka.edu.in] ,Garima Mishra [garima.mishra@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

Lectures: Wed - Fri  (10:10 - 11:40)

Part 1- Newtonian Mechanics (Amin A. Nizami):  We will begin by formulating the primary concepts: the laws of motion and the dynamical equations as differential equations which need to be integrated to find the solutions of mechanical problems. We will stress the importance of conservation laws (energy, momentum and angular momentum) not only in the solution of otherwise intractable dynamical problems but also their wider scope beyond Newtonian dynamics.  As applications we will deal with central force motion and the harmonic oscillator. Besides their historical importance, these are rich and instructive examples illustrating the basic concepts. The basics of rotational dynamics will also be considered.

Brief outline of topics: Space and Time, Force and Inertia, Inertial frames, Newton’s Laws, equations of motion, Galilean transformations as symmetries - principle of relativity. Work-Energy Theorem, Kinetic and Potential Energy. Rotational motion: Torque, angular momentum and moment of inertia.
Harmonic Oscillator: simple, damped and driven oscillators.
Many particle systems: Energy, Momentum and Angular Momentum - their conservation laws and use in solving dynamical problems.
Law of Gravitation, Kepler’s Laws and Planetary Orbits: motion in a Central force.

 

Part 2 - Analytical Mechanics (Garima Mishra)

Introduction to Lagrangian Mechanics: Principle of least action, Lagrange's equations of motion, Constraints, generalized coordinates, Conservation Laws;
Rigid Body Dynamics: Euler angles and rotations, Moment of inertia tensor, Principal axes of inertia, Euler's equations for rigid body motion, Motion of a top;
Introduction to Hamiltonian Mechanics: Legendre transformations, Hamilton's equations of motion, Liouville's theorem, Poisson brackets

 

Learning Outcomes
Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

(Part 1)

Marion and Thornton, Classical Dynamics of particles and systems [Cengage]
R. Douglas Gregory, Classical Mechanics [CUP] These two texts cover most of the lectured material at essentially the same level.

Recommended preparatory/supplementary reading: Feynman lectures on Physics Vol. 1, upto chapter 21

(Part 2) Textbooks:

Classical Mechanics by H. Goldstein.
Classical Dynamics of Particles and Systems by S. T. Thornton and J. B. Marion.
Classical Mechanics : The Theoretical Minimum by L. Susskind.

Attendance

description:
Introduction to Machine Learning [CS-3410/ MAT-3211] [CS-3410/ MAT-3211-1]

Faculty Name
Lipika Dey [lipika.dey@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

This is a first level introductory course on Machine Learning. The aim is to familiarize students to the concepts of how machines learn, why machines learn and what do they learn.  The course will cover fundamentals of statistical machine learning as well as deep learning.  

Topics to be covered are - 

Linear Regression; Least Square Error,  Maximum Likelihood Estimate, Regularization,

Principal Component Analysis

Intro to Supervised and Unsupervised Learning

Clustering algorithms: Hierarchical, K means, Density-based clustering; Expectation Maximization

Supervised LearningMethods: Logistic Regression; Naïve Bayes Classifier; Decision Trees, Random Forest;

 Error Analysis – recall, precision, AUC, Model evaluation

 SVM, Kernel Functions; Perceptron, Back Propagation Network;  

 Deep Neural Networks; Activation functions; Stochastic gradient descent;   Loss functions

 CNN, Autoencoder, Variable autoencoder 

  Word embeddings as self-supervised learning, RNN

 Transformers, Attention Modelling;

 Generative Models

 Explainability – SHAP and LIME

 

Learning Outcomes

By the end of this course stendts can understand and execute the following:

The fundamentals of data driven model estimation for prediction, classification and content generation.   

  • Basic frameworks of supervised, unsupervised, self-supervised and reinforcement learning 
  • Basics of statistical estimation and inference
  • Computational and sample complexity of machine learning problems
  • Core learning algorithms and evaluation of model performance
  • Empirical validation of machine learning models
  • Foundations of advanced topics like deep learning, foundational models, Large Language Models and reinforcement learning
  • Some hands-on problem solving on real data sets.
Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Pre-requisites: Probability and Statistics; Linear Algebra; Calculus 

References:
1.Pattern Recognition and Machine Learning; Christopher M. Bishop
2. Pattern Classification (2nd ed.) Richard O. Duda, Peter E. Hart and David G. Stork; 1997
3. An Introduction to Statistical Machine Learning; Gareth James, Daniela Witten, Trebor Hastie, Robert Trebshirani, Jonathan Taylor; 2023
4. Machine Learning; Tom Mitchel, 1997
5. Deep Learning; Ian Goodfellow and Yoshua Bengio and Aaron Courville; MIT Press; 2016

description:
Discrete Mathematics [CS-1110/ MAT-2203] [CS-1110/ MAT-2203-1]

Faculty Name
Sandeep Sen [sandeep.sen@ashoka.edu.in];
Overview

Discrete mathematics is the study of mathematical structures that can be considered discrete (in a way analogous to discrete variables, having a bijection with the set of natural numbers) rather than continuous (analogous to continuous functions). A related but somewhat different interpretation of the phrase discrete mathematics denotes all those branches of mathematics that deal with discrete entities as opposed to continuous entities. For example, a typical undergraduate course on calculus will not be considered discrete in this sense, whereas probability theory is something that can come in both discrete and continuous flavors. 

A sound understanding of Discrete Mathematics is critical for all areas of Computer Science. Hence, this course attempts to lay the foundation for a curriculum in CS. Many of the thematic areas are covered like logic, recursive design, combinatorics (counting methods), graph theory, number theory, information theory, etc. – are deep and vast subject areas on their own. Interested students are encouraged to follow up on any area/s they might find interesting. However, everyone interested in pursuing CS must grasp the fundamentals in all these well.

Learning Outcomes

To lay the mathematical foundations for computational thinking for the core and elective courses including Data Structures and Algorithm, Design and Analysis of Algorithms, Programming Languages and Translation, Theory of Computation, Design Practices in CS, Introduction to Machine Learning, Data Science and Management, and Information Security to build on. The course:

  1. introduces students to mathematical structures, tools, techniques, and frameworks for algorithmic and computational thinking
  2. illustrates ways for problem formulation, representation, and analysis using mathematical models
  3. elucidates how mathematical rigour and formalism ensure soundness and completeness of computation
  4. also aims to build basic programming skills to code the mathematical notions using programming languages

The emphasis throughout the course is on teaching how various concepts and results of mathematics are used in correct, efficient, and robust computations. On the one hand, it trains students to think and reason about computation in a programming language-agnostic way; on the other, it illustrates concrete computations using a specific programming language. In the process, it complements the course on Introduction to Computer Science from mathematical perspective and thinking.

Requirements (Reading List and other materials)

Textbooks:

  1. Discrete Mathematics and its Applications, 7th Ed. by Kenneth H. Rosen (Primary Textbook)
  2. Logic in Computer Science: Modelling and Reasoning about Systems by Michael Huth and Mark Ryan, 2004 (Logic)
  3. The C Programming Language, 2nd Ed. by Brian W. Kernighan and Dennis Ritchie, 2015. (Primary Reference on C Language)

Supplementary studies, Practice Problems

  1. Logic for Computer Science by Steve Reeves and Mike Clarke, 2003 (Logic)
  2. Concrete Mathematics – A Foundation for Computer Science, 2nd Ed. by Ronald L. Graham, Donald E. Knuth, and Oren Patashnik, 1994. (Recurrence, Number Theory, Probability, Asymptotics)
  3. Discrete Mathematics for Computer Scientists and Mathematicians by Joe L. Mott, Abraham Kandel, and Theodore P. Baker, 2008. (Recurrence, Counting, Graph)
  4. Applied Combinatorics by Fred Roberts and Barry Tesman, 2009. (Advanced)
  5. Graph Theory with Applications to Engineering and Computer Science by Narsingh Deo, 1979. (Graph)
  6. Introduction to Graph Theory by Douglas B. West, 2001. (Graph)
  7. Elements of Information Theory, 2nd Ed. by Thomas M. Cover and Joy A. Thomas, 2006. (Information Theory)
  8. The Book of Statistical Proofs by Joram Soch, Wikimedia. https://zenodo.org/records/10495684
